source.name: Kronos
source.god_of: God of Earth, Sea, Sky & Time
source.notes: Castrated his father Ouranos for impregnating his mother Gaia every night when the sky fell to the earth. Ouranos warned him that his children will rise up against him just as he'd done to his father. Terrified of the prophecy coming true he ate his new born children, gobbling them down as soon as his wife Rhea gave birth. Rhea hid her last born, tricking Kronos into eating a black marble stone wrapped in swaddling clothes. This last born child was Zeus who would return and fulfill the prophecy. After defeat by Zeus in the Titan War he was condemned to count to infinity, god of time. Some scholars separate Kronos (Titan) and Chronos (Time). Titan meaning "the striving one", meant as an insult by Ouranos when condenming his son Kronos' ambition when castrating him.

source.name: Brontes
source.notes: Ouranos was so incensed at these offspring he put them back inside Gaia to suffer who would eventually get her revenge with the help of Kronos. They would eventually be raised by Zeus from Tartarus to fight in the Clash of the Titans against Kronos and the others. They would gift Thunder and Lightning to Zeus in respectful homage.

target.notes: Zeus' most powerful opponent in the Titan War he was punished to hold up the sky for eternity to separate heaven from earth. He solidified into the Atlas Mountains we call today. As the Hesperides were friends of Atlas he was able to retreive the Apples whilst Heracles held up the sky for him.

source.name: Helios
source.notes: Would become the sun's sole charioteer after Apollo gave up the job when his son Phaeton died trying to drive it. He mocked Phaeton for trying to drive the sun chariot, letting out a high-pitched hysterical squeak when he heard the ridiculous nature of his plan. The same high-pitched squeak that you get when you breathe in the gas named after him, helium.

target.name: Heracles
target.notes: Born Alcides, son of Zeus and Alcmene. Zeus had wanted a child in the blood line of Perseus as Hera had prophecised that a child of Perseus would save the Olympians. Hera was so incensed at yet another affair of Zeus that she swore eternal enmity against Alcides. Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

source.name: Epimetheus
source.notes: Brother of Prometheus. In a different take on the story of Prometheus giving fire to humankind, it is he and his brother that are tasked by the gods of giving each living creature gifts and skills that will help them live their lives. However, when they reach humans, the basket of available gifts is empty. This is when Prometheus decided to steal the arts from Athena and fire from Hephaestus. Mankind could master these to outwit the animals. Thus Prometheus can be seen as the founder of civilisation in a more subtle way than just giving mankind fire.

source.name: Prometheus
source.notes: Sided with Zeus in the Titan War. Prometheus means prescience or forethought. He formed the first humans out of clay from Zeus' orders (Metis pulling the strings). Athena would then breathe life into them. Zeus commanded Prometheus to not help them, specifically from teaching them how to make fire, "with fire they could rise up and challenge us" said Zeus. Prometheus lived with the humans but became concerned as to their lack of zest, he decided they needed fire, but not just normal fire, divine fire, which would enflame their sense of imagination and daring. He stole divine fire from Hephaestus's forge on Mount Olympus and taught mankind how to make use of it. Zeus would take his revenge by binding him on the Caucasus Mountains to be pecked at by vultures every day for eternity. As he was immortal he would heal overnight only to be tortured again the next day. He proclaimed that his love for mankind and seeing them flourish thanks to him would be balm for any pain. He would eventually be freed by Heracles and would tell him of his destiny to help the Olympians against the giants. He returned to Zeus and won his forgiveness.

source.notes: Sided with Zeus in the Titan War. Prometheus means prescience or forethought. He formed the first humans out of clay from Zeus' orders (Metis pulling the strings). Athena would then breathe life into them. Zeus commanded Prometheus to not help them, specifically from teaching them how to make fire, "with fire they could rise up and challenge us" said Zeus. Prometheus lived with the humans but became concerned as to their lack of zest, he decided they needed fire, but not just normal fire, divine fire, which would enflame their sense of imagination and daring. He stole divine fire from Hephaestus's forge on Mount Olympus and taught mankind how to make use of it. Zeus would take his revenge by binding him on the Caucasus Mountains to be pecked at by vultures every day for eternity. As he was immortal he would heal overnight only to be tortured again the next day. He proclaimed that his love for mankind and seeing them flourish thanks to him would be balm for any pain. He would eventually be freed by Heracles and would tell him of his destiny to help the Olympians against the giants. He returned to Zeus and won his forgiveness.

source.name: Prometheus
source.notes: Sided with Zeus in the Titan War. Prometheus means prescience or forethought. He formed the first humans out of clay from Zeus' orders (Metis pulling the strings). Athena would then breathe life into them. Zeus commanded Prometheus to not help them, specifically from teaching them how to make fire, "with fire they could rise up and challenge us" said Zeus. Prometheus lived with the humans but became concerned as to their lack of zest, he decided they needed fire, but not just normal fire, divine fire, which would enflame their sense of imagination and daring. He stole divine fire from Hephaestus's forge on Mount Olympus and taught mankind how to make use of it. Zeus would take his revenge by binding him on the Caucasus Mountains to be pecked at by vultures every day for eternity. As he was immortal he would heal overnight only to be tortured again the next day. He proclaimed that his love for mankind and seeing them flourish thanks to him would be balm for any pain. He would eventually be freed by Heracles and would tell him of his destiny to help the Olympians against the giants. He returned to Zeus and won his forgiveness.

target.name: Heracles
target.notes: Born Alcides, son of Zeus and Alcmene. Zeus had wanted a child in the blood line of Perseus as Hera had prophecised that a child of Perseus would save the Olympians. Hera was so incensed at yet another affair of Zeus that she swore eternal enmity against Alcides. Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

target.name: Athena
target.notes: Zeus would court Metis, transforming into various creatures to chase her. She hid in a deep cave but Zeus would transform into a snake and coil around her where she would become pregnant. Later she goaded him by transforming into a fly to escape, he transformed into a lizard and ate her (in a shocking Kronos eating his children repeat). Metis then worked inside his head crafting armour and weapons giving Zeus an almighty headache. Hephaestus and Prometheus conjured a plan to fix the pain. They forged an axe that split Zeus' head in two from which Athena emerged. (Zeus' head then healed itself). Athens is named after her after she gifted the city the world's first olive tree. Her signature appearance is with an owl on her shoulder, symbol of watchful wisdom, and the serpent coiled around her feet, symbol of guile, as shown by her father winning over her mother. Like Demeter, she would remain untouched by man. The Greek word for virgin, Parthenos, is often attached to her name, hence the Parthenon, her temple on the Acropolis.

source.name: Aphrodite
source.god_of: God of Love, Beauty, Pleasure & Procreation
source.notes: Child of Ouranos' genitals as they "impregnated" the sea when discarded by Kronos. Hence the image of Aphrodite emerging from the sea on a scallop (Botticelli). Kept safe by Zeus in the Titan War.

target.name: Ouranos
target.notes: Primordial god of the sky. Progenitor of the first generation of Titans.

source.name: Hestia
source.notes: Swallowed by Kronos when born due to Ouranos' curse on him that "Your own children will overthrow you as you overthrew me"

target.name: Kronos
target.god_of: God of Earth, Sea, Sky & Time
target.notes: Castrated his father Ouranos for impregnating his mother Gaia every night when the sky fell to the earth. Ouranos warned him that his children will rise up against him just as he'd done to his father. Terrified of the prophecy coming true he ate his new born children, gobbling them down as soon as his wife Rhea gave birth. Rhea hid her last born, tricking Kronos into eating a black marble stone wrapped in swaddling clothes. This last born child was Zeus who would return and fulfill the prophecy. After defeat by Zeus in the Titan War he was condemned to count to infinity, god of time. Some scholars separate Kronos (Titan) and Chronos (Time). Titan meaning "the striving one", meant as an insult by Ouranos when condenming his son Kronos' ambition when castrating him.

target.name: Rhea
target.notes: Mother of the Olympians. She conceals the existence of Zeus from Kronos so that he can overthrow his father and free the siblings that he ate.

source.name: Hades
source.god_of: God of The Dead, King of the Underworld
source.notes: Swallowed by Kronos when born due to Ouranos' curse on him that "Your own children will overthrow you as you overthrew me". His Judaeo-Christian name is Lucifer. In Dante's Inferno the city of hell is called Dis, another name for Hades. He would be the arbiter for a soul's final destination depending upon how they lived their lives.

source.name: Amalthea
source.notes: A she-goat that Rhea confers with to save her next child from Kronos. Zeus suckles from her whilst in hiding on Crete. Zeus accidentally snapped off one of her horns, to compensate he magically filled it with food and drink and it was destined never to be empty. This is the fabled Horn of Plenty known to the Romans as the Cornucopia.

source.name: Orpheus
source.notes: The greatest musician of the ancient world. He was rewarded for his bravery in the quest for the Golden Fleece with a wife, Eurydice. One day she was pursued by Aristaeus and she fell into a ditch trying to escape and was bitten by an adder and died. The grief caused Orpheus to stop playing his beautiful music, even the Gods wept. Finally his father Apollo told him to retrieve Eurydice from the underworld with a lyre strung with hairs from his own head. His mellifluous playing won over the hound of hell, Cerberus, and Charon, the ferryman of the dead, which enabled him to enter the palace of Hades itself. Queen of the underworld, Persephone, convinced her husband to let Orpheus play one song and if it moves them they shall release Eurydice. He played the most amazing song that transformed the underworld into a place of light and love. Hades agreed to let Eurydice go but on one condition, that she must follow ten paces behind and if he turns around to look at her, she will be kept in the underworld. He kept the correct pace right until the edge of the underworld, but unbeknownst to him, his last few steps had accelerated into a run, Eurydice, too far behind was still not over the threshold of the underworld when Orpheus looked back in triumph and she was pulled back into the darkness. Orpheus lived out the rest of his life shunning any advances from women eventually sparking the ire of the Ciconians, followers of Dionysus who found his music an affront to their dark dances. They tore him apart in a Bacchic frenzy. His head ended up on the island of Lesbos where it was taken to a cave where people would come from all around to seek guidance and to hear his music once more. Apollo, jealous that the shrine was becoming more popular than his own Delphic oracle, finally silenced him. Finally at peace, his spirit descended to the underworld where he could be with Eurydice at last.

target.name: Apollo
target.god_of: God of Mathematics, reason, logic, poetry, medicine, knowledge, prophecy, archery & music
target.notes: He kills a Python sent by Hera to eat him and his sister. The Python came from the landing site of the magnetite stone that Kronos ate thinking it was the infant Zeus. As the Python was born of Gaia and under divine protection he had to be punished by Zeus. He was exiled for eight years to the snake's birthplace beneath Mount Parnassus to replace the snake as guardian of the Omphalos (the spiritual centre of Greece, whose name he would change to Delphi and establish an oracle where anyone could come to ask the god or his appointed priestess, known as a Sibyl or Pythia, questions about the future) and to atone for his crime. Here he would go on to organise The Pythian Games every four years. Apollo was gifted music by Hermes (a tortoise shell with cow guts as strings, the first lyre) as a show of repentence after he stole Apollo's cattle.

target.name: Jason
target.notes: Smuggled out of Iolcos when he was a baby due to Pelias and Neleus laying siege to the city believeing they were the rightful heirs to the throne and not his father, Aeson. He was brought up by his mother's (Alcimede) friend, the great centaur, Chiron. Met Bellerophon, who was seeking help from Chiron for Pegasus burned skin at the hands of Chimera. He filled his head with heroic feats which influenced Jason in his formative years. When his tutelage with Chiron was finished he ventured back to Iolcos. On the journey he lost a sandal helping an old lady (Hera in disguise) across a river. It was prophecised to Pelias to beware of a man arriving from the country with one sandal so when he arrived in Iolcos, Pelias knew immediately who he was. Pelias agreed to let him take the throne but lied to him, telling him the land was cursed and that the only way to lift the curse was to retrieve the Golden Fleece. He arranged a mighty ship, the Argo, and a great crew, the Argonauts, to sail to Colchis and retrieve the fleece. When the Argonauts arrived at Colchis, King Aeëtes demanded three tests of Jason before he could take it. To tame the fire breathing bulls, the Khalkotauroi, to sow some dragon's teeth from Cadmus and defeat the army that sprouts from the ground, and to kill the dragon that guards the fleece. He managed these feats thanks to his new lover, Medea, whom Hera had had Eros strike her with his cupid's arrow. They escaped with the fleece back to Pelias where they realised he was never going to give up the throne so Medea tricked his nine daughters into killing him, believing they were being taught a magic trick and would be brought back to life. They had to flee Iolcos after this blood killing and sought refuge in Corinth. Here Jason fell for the King's daughter, Creusa. Medea, so enraged at this betrayal after everything she had done for him killed Creusa and her father, King Creon. In a terrible denouement she even killed her children. A broken Jason lived on Corinth until his old friend Peleus persuaded him to return to Iolcos and overthrow Acastus, the King. They managed this and he was finally on the throne of Iolcos. This didn't last long however as one day, asleep under the Argo, a rotten beam fell on him and killed him. It was an ironic twist as he was warned years before during the voyage to repair the damage caused during the crossing of the Bosporus, but who knew this would be the deadly outcome.

source.name: Kerberos
source.notes: Acquired by Hades to guard the underworld. Heracles was ordered to retrieve the dog as the final one of his twelve labours. He ingratiated himself to Persephone, the Queen of the underworld, by taking part in a celebration of her rising back to the heavens. Through this he was able to gain access to Hades where he told him of the need for Cerberus to appease Hera. Hades reluctantly agreed and Heracles was able to wrestle Cerberus into submission and fulfill his final labour.

target.name: Typhon
target.notes: A monstrous storm giant who laid siege to the heavens in the clash of the Titans but was defeated by Zeus.

source.name: Kerberos
source.notes: Acquired by Hades to guard the underworld. Heracles was ordered to retrieve the dog as the final one of his twelve labours. He ingratiated himself to Persephone, the Queen of the underworld, by taking part in a celebration of her rising back to the heavens. Through this he was able to gain access to Hades where he told him of the need for Cerberus to appease Hera. Hades reluctantly agreed and Heracles was able to wrestle Cerberus into submission and fulfill his final labour.

target.name: Echidna
target.notes: A monstrous she-dragon with the head and breast of a woman and the tail of a serpent. She represents the corruptions of the earth, rot, slime, fetid water, illness and disease.

source.name: Kerberos
source.notes: Acquired by Hades to guard the underworld. Heracles was ordered to retrieve the dog as the final one of his twelve labours. He ingratiated himself to Persephone, the Queen of the underworld, by taking part in a celebration of her rising back to the heavens. Through this he was able to gain access to Hades where he told him of the need for Cerberus to appease Hera. Hades reluctantly agreed and Heracles was able to wrestle Cerberus into submission and fulfill his final labour.

target.name: Heracles
target.notes: Born Alcides, son of Zeus and Alcmene. Zeus had wanted a child in the blood line of Perseus as Hera had prophecised that a child of Perseus would save the Olympians. Hera was so incensed at yet another affair of Zeus that she swore eternal enmity against Alcides. Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

source.name: Hydra
source.notes: A nine-headed serpent, one of which was immortal, which haunted the swamps of Lerna. For every head that was cut off, Hydra grew two more. Each head was capable of spraying jets of deadly poison. Heracles was ordered to pacify her as one of his labours. He managed, with the help of his nephew Iolaus, to slice of the head and cauterise the stump to prevent a new head from forming. He then buried the immortal head deep underground where her poisonous vapors still breathe up their sulphurous gas today by the waters of Lake Lernea. Heracles coated the tips of his arrows with her posionous blood, which would go on to have tragic consequences.

source.name: Persephone
source.god_of: Queen of the underworld, god of Spring
source.notes: Was kidnapped by Hades in a chariot. This led to a great famine as her mother Demeter neglected her harvest duties to search for her. Helios had witnessed Hades kidnapping her and told Zeus. He demanded the return of Persephone to end the famine. Hades reluctantly agreed but not before feeding her six pomegranate seeds which fated her to return to the underworld for six months of each year. From this we get the seasons, six months of spring and summer growth as Demeter is overjoyed at the return of her daughter, and six months of autumn and winter of Demeter's grieving as Persephone is returned back to the underworld.

target.name: Hades
target.god_of: God of The Dead, King of the Underworld
target.notes: Swallowed by Kronos when born due to Ouranos' curse on him that "Your own children will overthrow you as you overthrew me". His Judaeo-Christian name is Lucifer. In Dante's Inferno the city of hell is called Dis, another name for Hades. He would be the arbiter for a soul's final destination depending upon how they lived their lives.

source.name: Hephaestus
source.god_of: God of  Fire, Blacksmiths, Artisans, Sculptors & Metalworkers
source.notes: To Hera's dismay, wanting to give birth to the greatest of the gods, saw the child was so ugly that she hurled him down Mount Olympus in disgust. He would forge a golden throne that would bind Hera and come and unlock it to get back to Olympus. He would wed Aphrodite as a reward.

source.name: Melisseus
source.notes: Gifted honey to Zeus and Hera at their wedding. He was rewarded with a sting to defend herself when collecting it, but such a selfish and hubristic demand of the Gods was punished with death if used. Meliss is still the Greek word for honey. A specially blessed honey is given the name Ambrosia, meaning immortality. In fermented, drinkable form, it is called Nectar in honour of the flowers it comes from.

source.name: Athena
source.notes: Zeus would court Metis, transforming into various creatures to chase her. She hid in a deep cave but Zeus would transform into a snake and coil around her where she would become pregnant. Later she goaded him by transforming into a fly to escape, he transformed into a lizard and ate her (in a shocking Kronos eating his children repeat). Metis then worked inside his head crafting armour and weapons giving Zeus an almighty headache. Hephaestus and Prometheus conjured a plan to fix the pain. They forged an axe that split Zeus' head in two from which Athena emerged. (Zeus' head then healed itself). Athens is named after her after she gifted the city the world's first olive tree. Her signature appearance is with an owl on her shoulder, symbol of watchful wisdom, and the serpent coiled around her feet, symbol of guile, as shown by her father winning over her mother. Like Demeter, she would remain untouched by man. The Greek word for virgin, Parthenos, is often attached to her name, hence the Parthenon, her temple on the Acropolis.

target.name: Metis
target.notes: Helped train Zeus to take revenge on Kronos. She would eventually be consumed by Zeus becoming his wise counsellor, see Athena for how this happened.

source.name: Apollo
source.god_of: God of Mathematics, reason, logic, poetry, medicine, knowledge, prophecy, archery & music
source.notes: He kills a Python sent by Hera to eat him and his sister. The Python came from the landing site of the magnetite stone that Kronos ate thinking it was the infant Zeus. As the Python was born of Gaia and under divine protection he had to be punished by Zeus. He was exiled for eight years to the snake's birthplace beneath Mount Parnassus to replace the snake as guardian of the Omphalos (the spiritual centre of Greece, whose name he would change to Delphi and establish an oracle where anyone could come to ask the god or his appointed priestess, known as a Sibyl or Pythia, questions about the future) and to atone for his crime. Here he would go on to organise The Pythian Games every four years. Apollo was gifted music by Hermes (a tortoise shell with cow guts as strings, the first lyre) as a show of repentence after he stole Apollo's cattle.

target.name: Atlas
target.god_of: God of Astronomy & Bearer of the Heavens
target.notes: Zeus' most powerful opponent in the Titan War he was punished to hold up the sky for eternity to separate heaven from earth. He solidified into the Atlas Mountains we call today. Heracles sought his aid during one of his labours to retrieve the Golden Apples of the the Hesperides. As the Hesperides were friends of Atlas he was able to retreive the Apples whilst Heracles held up the sky for him.

source.name: Human Beings
source.notes: The first humans were made by Prometheus on Zeus' orders (Metis pulling the strings). He fashioned them from the four elements, Earth (Gaia's clay), Water (Zeus' spittle), Fire (the Sun of Apollo), and Air (the breath of Athena).

target.name: Gaia
target.notes: Mother Earth. Progenitor of the first generation of Titans.

source.name: Human Beings
source.notes: The first humans were made by Prometheus on Zeus' orders (Metis pulling the strings). He fashioned them from the four elements, Earth (Gaia's clay), Water (Zeus' spittle), Fire (the Sun of Apollo), and Air (the breath of Athena).

target.name: Zeus
target.god_of: King of the Gods, god of sky, weather & fate
target.notes: Rhea tricked Kronos into eating a piece of magnetite and escaped to Crete to have Zeus. She vowed that he'd take revenge on Kronos. He gives Kronos poison where he regurgitates all 5 children that he ate

source.name: Human Beings
source.notes: The first humans were made by Prometheus on Zeus' orders (Metis pulling the strings). He fashioned them from the four elements, Earth (Gaia's clay), Water (Zeus' spittle), Fire (the Sun of Apollo), and Air (the breath of Athena).

target.name: Apollo
target.god_of: God of Mathematics, reason, logic, poetry, medicine, knowledge, prophecy, archery & music
target.notes: He kills a Python sent by Hera to eat him and his sister. The Python came from the landing site of the magnetite stone that Kronos ate thinking it was the infant Zeus. As the Python was born of Gaia and under divine protection he had to be punished by Zeus. He was exiled for eight years to the snake's birthplace beneath Mount Parnassus to replace the snake as guardian of the Omphalos (the spiritual centre of Greece, whose name he would change to Delphi and establish an oracle where anyone could come to ask the god or his appointed priestess, known as a Sibyl or Pythia, questions about the future) and to atone for his crime. Here he would go on to organise The Pythian Games every four years. Apollo was gifted music by Hermes (a tortoise shell with cow guts as strings, the first lyre) as a show of repentence after he stole Apollo's cattle.

source.name: Human Beings
source.notes: The first humans were made by Prometheus on Zeus' orders (Metis pulling the strings). He fashioned them from the four elements, Earth (Gaia's clay), Water (Zeus' spittle), Fire (the Sun of Apollo), and Air (the breath of Athena).

target.name: Athena
target.notes: Zeus would court Metis, transforming into various creatures to chase her. She hid in a deep cave but Zeus would transform into a snake and coil around her where she would become pregnant. Later she goaded him by transforming into a fly to escape, he transformed into a lizard and ate her (in a shocking Kronos eating his children repeat). Metis then worked inside his head crafting armour and weapons giving Zeus an almighty headache. Hephaestus and Prometheus conjured a plan to fix the pain. They forged an axe that split Zeus' head in two from which Athena emerged. (Zeus' head then healed itself). Athens is named after her after she gifted the city the world's first olive tree. Her signature appearance is with an owl on her shoulder, symbol of watchful wisdom, and the serpent coiled around her feet, symbol of guile, as shown by her father winning over her mother. Like Demeter, she would remain untouched by man. The Greek word for virgin, Parthenos, is often attached to her name, hence the Parthenon, her temple on the Acropolis.

source.name: Human Beings
source.notes: The first humans were made by Prometheus on Zeus' orders (Metis pulling the strings). He fashioned them from the four elements, Earth (Gaia's clay), Water (Zeus' spittle), Fire (the Sun of Apollo), and Air (the breath of Athena).

target.name: Prometheus
target.notes: Sided with Zeus in the Titan War. Prometheus means prescience or forethought. He formed the first humans out of clay from Zeus' orders (Metis pulling the strings). Athena would then breathe life into them. Zeus commanded Prometheus to not help them, specifically from teaching them how to make fire, "with fire they could rise up and challenge us" said Zeus. Prometheus lived with the humans but became concerned as to their lack of zest, he decided they needed fire, but not just normal fire, divine fire, which would enflame their sense of imagination and daring. He stole divine fire from Hephaestus's forge on Mount Olympus and taught mankind how to make use of it. Zeus would take his revenge by binding him on the Caucasus Mountains to be pecked at by vultures every day for eternity. As he was immortal he would heal overnight only to be tortured again the next day. He proclaimed that his love for mankind and seeing them flourish thanks to him would be balm for any pain. He would eventually be freed by Heracles and would tell him of his destiny to help the Olympians against the giants. He returned to Zeus and won his forgiveness.

source.name: Pandora
source.notes: The first mortal female. Pandora was created by the Gods as part of Zeus's cunning plan to punish mankind and Prometheus for stealing divine fire. She was bestowed with a gift presented by Zeus himself, a container filled with secrets which she was ordered never to open. She would marry Epimetheus, Prometheus's brother. Unable to resist temptation she eventually opened the container releasing illness, violence, deceit, misery, and want upon the world, bringing an end to the Golden Age.

target.name: Aphrodite
target.god_of: God of Love, Beauty, Pleasure & Procreation
target.notes: Child of Ouranos' genitals as they "impregnated" the sea when discarded by Kronos. Hence the image of Aphrodite emerging from the sea on a scallop (Botticelli). Kept safe by Zeus in the Titan War.

source.name: Pandora

She was bestowed with a gift presented by Zeus himself, a container filled with secrets which she was ordered never to open. She would marry Epimetheus, Prometheus's brother. Unable to resist temptation she eventually opened the container releasing illness, violence, deceit, misery, and want upon the world, bringing an end to the Golden Age.

target.name: Hera
target.god_of: Queen of the Gods, god of Marriage, Women, the Sky & Stars of Heaven
target.notes: Swallowed by Kronos when born due to Ouranos' curse on him that "Your own children will overthrow you as you overthrew me". Married to Zeus.

target.name: Hephaestus
target.god_of: God of  Fire, Blacksmiths, Artisans, Sculptors & Metalworkers
target.notes: To Hera's dismay, wanting to give birth to the greatest of the gods, saw the child was so ugly that she hurled him down Mount Olympus in disgust. He would forge a golden throne that would bind Hera and come and unlock it to get back to Olympus. He would wed Aphrodite as a reward.

target.name: Hermes
target.god_of: God of Messengers, thievery, medicine, herds & trade
target.notes: This infant prodigy gives his name to anything "mercurial". Would become "chief conductor of souls" for the most important human spirits.

source.name: Pandora
source.notes: The first mortal female. Pandora was created by the Gods as part of Zeus's cunning plan to punish mankind and Prometheus for stealing divine fire. She was bestowed with a gift presented by Zeus himself, a container filled with secrets which she was ordered never to open. She would marry Epimetheus, Prometheus's brother. Unable to resist temptation she eventually opened the container releasing illness, violence, deceit, misery, and want upon the world, bringing an end to the Golden Age.

target.name: Epimetheus
target.notes: Brother of Prometheus. In a different take on the story of Prometheus giving fire to humankind, it is he and his brother that are tasked by the gods of giving each living creature gifts and skills that will help them live their lives. However, when they reach humans, the basket of available gifts is empty. This is when Prometheus decided to steal the arts from Athena and fire from Hephaestus. Mankind could master these to outwit the animals. Thus Prometheus can be seen as the founder of civilisation in a more subtle way than just giving mankind fire.

source.name: Elpis
source.notes: Elpis (hope) was inside Pandora's box. When she opened it all the demon spirits escaped except for Elpis who remained behind to comfort mankind. Zeus had intended hope to be released to forever torment mankind that there were better things to come. Inside the box, we were free to live without any aspirations or illusions of hope.

target.name: Nyx
target.notes: Primoridal god of the night. Commanded by Hades after defeat in the Titan War.

target.name: Lycaon
target.notes: One of the first human rulers, Lycaon, King of Arcadia was son of the Pelsagos who had been one of the original clay figures formed by Prometheus. He killed his own son Nyctimus as an offering to the gods. Zeus was so revolted he brought the boy back to life and turned Lycaon into a wolf. However, Nyctimus's brothers ravaged the land so Zeus brought about massive floods to drown the whole of Greece and the Mediterranean, all, save Deucalion and Pyrrha, who thanks to Prometheus's foresight, survived aboard a wooden chest.

source.name: Human Beings 2.0
source.notes: True civilisation could now begin as men and women were now created equally. These humans were now mortal thanks to the demons that escaped from Pandora's box.

source.name: Minos I
source.notes: Upon their deaths they were appointed Judges of the Underworld, taking over from Hades as arbiters of a soul's final destination. The righteous would end up at Elysian Fields (Isles of the Blessed). The vast majority were placed in the Meadows of Asphodel. The sinners were placed in the Fields of Punishment in the depths of Tartarus to be tortured for eternity.

target.name: Europa
target.notes: One day whilst playing she discovered a beautiful white bull, taking it by the horns it flew her over the lands west of her parent's kingdown of Tyre in modern day Lebanon, towards the Greek islands (the journey was so remarkable that the landmass she flew over is named after her in honour, Europe). The bull was none other than Zeus. Europa finally settled on Crete bearing Zeus three children, Minos, Rhadamanthus, and Sarpedon.

target.notes: Rhea tricked Kronos into eating a piece of magnetite and escaped to Crete to have Zeus. She vowed that he'd take revenge on Kronos. He gives Kronos poison where he regurgitates all 5 children that he ate

source.name: Aeacus
source.notes: Upon their deaths they were appointed Judges of the Underworld, taking over from Hades as arbiters of a soul's final destination. The righteous would end up at Elysian Fields (Isles of the Blessed). The vast majority were placed in the Meadows of Asphodel. The sinners were placed in the Fields of Punishment in the depths of Tartarus to be tortured for eternity.

target.name: Aigina
target.notes: Fresh water counterparts of the Nereids, found in lakes, streams and running water.

source.name: Europa
source.notes: One day whilst playing she discovered a beautiful white bull, taking it by the horns it flew her over the lands west of her parent's kingdown of Tyre in modern day Lebanon, towards the Greek islands (the journey was so remarkable that the landmass she flew over is named after her in honour, Europe). The bull was none other than Zeus. Europa finally settled on Crete bearing Zeus three children, Minos, Rhadamanthus, and Sarpedon.

target.name: Agenor
target.notes: King of Tyre, modern day Lebanon.

target.name: Telephassa

source.name: Sisyphus
source.notes: Horrible, nasty Sisyphus. He despised his brother, Salmoneus, more than anything. He married his brother's daughter, Tyro, because the Delphic Oracle told him that the result of that union would bring his brother down. This was foiled when his wife discovered the plan, took revenge by drowning their two children, and fled back to her father. He angered the gods so much that Zeus personally sent Thanatos to take him to the underworld. However, proud of his cunning, he tricked Thanatos into handcuffing himself by mocking his shackles and saying that they wouldn't work. He then kept Thanatos prisoner in his wardrobe. Knowing that without death, the gods would be on his tail sooner or later, he made a pact with his new wife to not make offerings to the gods when he did eventually die so that he couldn't cross the River Styx. When Thanatos was finally rescued he came for him again and took him to the underworld. When he couldn't cross the Styx he swam across, looking the worse for wear on the other side he spoke with Persephone, Queen of the underworld, and told her that his appearance was due to his wife's neglect in not making offerings to the gods to enable his passage. A shocked Persephone wanted to punish his wife, but Sisyphus tricked her into sending him back to life to take revenge on her in person. They would go on to live happily ever after. When his wife died and Persephone's decree finally expired, Thanatos came for him a third time, but this time Hermes offered him a deal, in cheating death twice you have earned a chance at immortality. All you have to do is push this boulder up the slope and out of the opening at the top to attain immortality, or, you can go to Elysium and live a happy afterlife. Sisyphus thought that the task was possible so that's what he chose. He is still there to this day, in the halls of Tartarus, pushing the boulder up the hill only to fail and see it come crashing down again.

target.name: Aeolus

source.name: Hermaphroditus
source.notes: Fathered by Hermes and Aphrodite, hence the name. Was wooed by the nymph Salmacis who proclaimed to the gods that they should never be parted. The gods duly obliged and they did indeed become one, fusing into a single body. One body, two sexes.

target.name: Aphrodite
target.god_of: God of Love, Beauty, Pleasure & Procreation
target.notes: Child of Ouranos' genitals as they "impregnated" the sea when discarded by Kronos. Hence the image of Aphrodite emerging from the sea on a scallop (Botticelli). Kept safe by Zeus in the Titan War.

source.name: Anteros
source.notes: The Greeks untangled love's complexity by naming each strand and providing divinities to represent them. These are the Erotes, a retinue of winged godlings that accompany the supreme goddess of love and beauty Aphrodite.

source.name: Silenus
source.notes: Fathered by Hermes and an unknown nymph, Silenus was a snub-nosed, donkey-tailed lecher who would grow up to become a bearded, pot-bellied old drunk. A popular subject in paintings and sculptures.

target.name: Hermes

source.name: Eros
source.notes: Fell in love with Psyche after a botched Cupid's arrow attempt. When Psyche's parents consulted the Oracle at Delphi as to why Psyche hadn't yet married, they were ordered to give her up to one of the Gods or else their subjects would live on in misery. They duly obliged and the God that took her away was none other than Eros. When he was defied by Psyche when she snook a look at him he fell into a great sadness. Couples were no longer getting together which Aphrodite noticed and found out that her original plan to punish Psyche had backfired so badly. She would punish Psyche to carry out impossible tasks. When Eros found out he pleaded with Zeus who showed Aphrodite that she was still God of all beauty. She relented and Zeus immortalised Psyche by giving her ambrosia from his cup. They would go on to wed.

source.name: Calanthe
source.notes: Jealous of her sister Psyche for finding love with Eros, she tricked her into defying his demand not to see him and whilst he slept she snook a look at him in lamplight. Examining one of his arrows she cut herself and consequently fell deeply in love with Eros in return as he had for her. Unhappy at this defiance Eros departed and Psyche lost everything. Psyche eventually got her revenge by tricking her that it was her that Eros desired all along, not Psyche. Instructing her to to the top of a mountain to let Zephyrus take her to Eros, the west wind didn't appear and she fell to her death on the rocks below.

source.name: Psyche
source.notes: Was of such beauty that people abandoned the cult of Aphrodite to worship her. In her vengeance she ordered her son Eros to strike her with his arrow and make sure the first thing she sees is the foulest smelling pig you can find. However, in a botched cupid attempt he scratched himself with his own arrow as the pig squealed, Psyche awoke, Eros saw Psyche and fell deeply in love with her. His love for her was so complete that he couldn't bear to trick her so he left. Psyche was non the wiser and went back to sleep. She would eventually end up with Eros but agreed to his demand that she could never see him in person. Tricked by her sisters into looking at Eros she lost everything. She would exact revenge, see Zona and Calanthe.

target.name: Inachus
target.notes: One of the very earliest rulers in Greece. He was the first King of Argos in the Peloponnese peninsula.

source.name: Io
source.notes: The first human to attract the attention of Zeus. He transformed her into a hiefer to escape the attention of Hera but Hera's keen eye spotting this straight away. She ordered Argus, Io's nephew to watch over her. Zeus then got Hermes to help him distract Argus, which he did by killing him, the Gods were capable of great cruelty. Io was set free but Hera, who witnessed the whole episode, sent a gadfly to sting her repeatedly. She galloped away in pain, far from Zeus's reach across Greece into Turkey (the river Bosporus being named after her, which translates as the cow crossing) ending at the Caucasas mountains where Prometheus comforted her that things will get better and she would eventually return to human form.

source.name: Argus
source.notes: Argus, son of Mycene and Arestor was commanded by Hera to watch over Io after she was transformed into a heifer by Zeus who wanted his wicked way with her. His nickname was Panoptes, the all-seeing. His 100 eyes made him well suited to the task. Hermes, on Zeus's orders, played music to him to fall asleep on his watch and stabbed him in the heart. Devestated by the death of her loyal subject, Hera took Argus's hundred bright eyes and fixed them onto the tail of an old fowl, transforming it into a peacock.

source.name: Erechtheus
source.notes: Hephaestus, after helping to bring Athena into the world by splitting open Zeus's head, became infatuated with her. One day, unable to control himself he tried to force himself on her, managing in his excitement to spill his seed on her. Athena removed her headband, wiped up the mess and threw it down the mountain. This landed on the ground and made Gaia pregnant, from which Erechtheus was born. Athena deemed that he should be immortal and he would grow up to be the legendary founder of Athens, Erechthonius.

target.name: Gaia
target.notes: Mother Earth. Progenitor of the first generation of Titans.

source.name: Erechtheus
source.notes: Hephaestus, after helping to bring Athena into the world by splitting open Zeus's head, became infatuated with her. One day, unable to control himself he tried to force himself on her, managing in his excitement to spill his seed on her. Athena removed her headband, wiped up the mess and threw it down the mountain. This landed on the ground and made Gaia pregnant, from which Erechtheus was born. Athena deemed that he should be immortal and he would grow up to be the legendary founder of Athens, Erechthonius.

target.name: Hephaestus
target.god_of: God of  Fire, Blacksmiths, Artisans, Sculptors & Metalworkers
target.notes: To Hera's dismay, wanting to give birth to the greatest of the gods, saw the child was so ugly that she hurled him down Mount Olympus in disgust. He would forge a golden throne that would bind Hera and come and unlock it to get back to Olympus. He would wed Aphrodite as a reward.

source.name: Erechtheus
source.notes: Hephaestus, after helping to bring Athena into the world by splitting open Zeus's head, became infatuated with her. One day, unable to control himself he tried to force himself on her, managing in his excitement to spill his seed on her. Athena removed her headband, wiped up the mess and threw it down the mountain. This landed on the ground and made Gaia pregnant, from which Erechtheus was born. Athena deemed that he should be immortal and he would grow up to be the legendary founder of Athens, Erechthonius.

target.name: Athena
target.notes: Zeus would court Metis, transforming into various creatures to chase her. She hid in a deep cave but Zeus would transform into a snake and coil around her where she would become pregnant. Later she goaded him by transforming into a fly to escape, he transformed into a lizard and ate her (in a shocking Kronos eating his children repeat). Metis then worked inside his head crafting armour and weapons giving Zeus an almighty headache. Hephaestus and Prometheus conjured a plan to fix the pain. They forged an axe that split Zeus' head in two from which Athena emerged. (Zeus' head then healed itself). Athens is named after her after she gifted the city the world's first olive tree. Her signature appearance is with an owl on her shoulder, symbol of watchful wisdom, and the serpent coiled around her feet, symbol of guile, as shown by her father winning over her mother. Like Demeter, she would remain untouched by man. The Greek word for virgin, Parthenos, is often attached to her name, hence the Parthenon, her temple on the Acropolis.

source.name: Herse
source.notes: Charged by Athena with looking after Erechtheus, the future founder of Athens, she was shocked to find him kept company by a snake in his basket. This was Athena's doing to endow immortality upon him (all snakes were sacred to Athena) and promptly threw herself off the Acropolis.

source.name: Phaeton
source.notes: Son of Apollo who he never saw, he was raised by the human Merops. One day, tired of the boasting of his friend Epaphus about his father Zeus, he lied that his father was going to let him drive the sun chariots across the sky. After pleading with Apollo he was given permission. During the drive he tried to fly down to show off to Epaphus but lost control scorching the Earth in the area of Africa now known as the Sahara Desert but to Greeks as the place that Phaeton scorched. Losing all control he then shot up too high plunging Earth into darkness and a big freeze. The Gods complained to Zeus who struck Phaeton down with a thunderbolt to bring the situation, and Earth, back under control but not before the Earth had newly acquired ice caps and deserts as a result. Apollo took Phaeton's death hard and vowed never again to ride the sun chariot, passing on this duty to Helios. A tragic parable on lies getting out of hand, his epitaph reads, "Here Phaeton lies who in the sun-god's chariot fated. And though greatly he failed, more greatly he dared."

target.name: Apollo
target.god_of: God of Mathematics, reason, logic, poetry, medicine, knowledge, prophecy, archery & music
target.notes: He kills a Python sent by Hera to eat him and his sister. The Python came from the landing site of the magnetite stone that Kronos ate thinking it was the infant Zeus. As the Python was born of Gaia and under divine protection he had to be punished by Zeus. He was exiled for eight years to the snake's birthplace beneath Mount Parnassus to replace the snake as guardian of the Omphalos (the spiritual centre of Greece, whose name he would change to Delphi and establish an oracle where anyone could come to ask the god or his appointed priestess, known as a Sibyl or Pythia, questions about the future) and to atone for his crime. Here he would go on to organise The Pythian Games every four years. Apollo was gifted music by Hermes (a tortoise shell with cow guts as strings, the first lyre) as a show of repentence after he stole Apollo's cattle.

target.name: Epaphus
target.notes: Cruelly taunted his friend Phaeton which led to his death when he tried to drive the sun chariot in a doomed attempt to show off.

source.name: Cygnus
source.notes: Friend and lover of Phaeton. Was so distraught when Phaeton died trying to drive the sun chariot that he would let out a horrific wail. Apollo, Phaeton's father, was so distraught at this that he turned him into a beautiful swan out of pity, fated to live in silence until his own death when he would let out a melancholic goodbye, his swan song. In honour of Cygnus all young swans are of course called cygnets.

target.name: Ixion
target.notes: Ixion, already angering the gods to breaking point by refusing one of their most strongly held beliefs, the spirit of hospitality, or xenia, and by killing his father-in-law, Deioneus, King of Phocis and committing the first blood murder, would go on to anger them even further. Invited to a banquet by Zeus he tried it on with his wife, Hera. An angry Zeus then tested him the day after by animating a cloud shaped Hera look-a-like and presenting it to Ixion. He duly impregnated her. This was the final straw and Zeus bound him to a wheel of fire and sent him down to the depths of Tartarus where he revolves, spread-eagled and roasting in agony to this day. "Thou art a soul in bliss,but I am bound Upon a wheel of fire, that mine own tears Do scald like molten lead." King Lear.

source.name: Cadmus
source.notes: Charged with rescuing his sister Europa who had ridden off on a bull (Zeus) to Crete. He met his future wife Harmony on his quest. Consulting the Delphic Oracle he was told to give up the search and instead follow a heifer marked with a half moon. Where it drops, there you must build. Later he would be told to enter the Phocian Games where he would win a cow which, lo and behold, had a half moon shaped mark on its back. He followed the cow to a place where the Ismenian Dragon, sacred to the god of war, Ares, was. He bravely killed the dragon but made a mighty enemy in the process. Athena came to his and Harmony's aid and ordered them to plant the teeth from which sprouted soldiers, which he called Spartoi. He built the city of Thebes on this site and the Spartoi would be his lords. Ares, not to be outdone, would plague Cadmus's happiness from then on, eventually wearing him down so much he begged for it to come to an end. Ares duly obliged turning him into a snake. Athena took pity on Harmony and turned her into a snake also. The couple would go on to live together in a temple sacred to Athena.

target.name: Atlas
target.god_of: God of Astronomy & Bearer of the Heavens
target.notes: Zeus' most powerful opponent in the Titan War he was punished to hold up the sky for eternity to separate heaven from earth. He solidified into the Atlas Mountains we call today. Heracles sought his aid during one of his labours to retrieve the Golden Apples of the the Hesperides. As the Hesperides were friends of Atlas he was able to retreive the Apples whilst Heracles held up the sky for him.

target.name: Cadmus
target.notes: Charged with rescuing his sister Europa who had ridden off on a bull (Zeus) to Crete. He met his future wife Harmony on his quest. Consulting the Delphic Oracle he was told to give up the search and instead follow a heifer marked with a half moon. Where it drops, there you must build. Later he would be told to enter the Phocian Games where he would win a cow which, lo and behold, had a half moon shaped mark on its back. He followed the cow to a place where the Ismenian Dragon, sacred to the god of war, Ares, was. He bravely killed the dragon but made a mighty enemy in the process. Athena came to his and Harmony's aid and ordered them to plant the teeth from which sprouted soldiers, which he called Spartoi. He built the city of Thebes on this site and the Spartoi would be his lords. Ares, not to be outdone, would plague Cadmus's happiness from then on, eventually wearing him down so much he begged for it to come to an end. Ares duly obliged turning him into a snake. Athena took pity on Harmony and turned her into a snake also. The couple would go on to live together in a temple sacred to Athena.

source.name: Harmonia

target.name: Athena
target.notes: Zeus would court Metis, transforming into various creatures to chase her. She hid in a deep cave but Zeus would transform into a snake and coil around her where she would become pregnant. Later she goaded him by transforming into a fly to escape, he transformed into a lizard and ate her (in a shocking Kronos eating his children repeat). Metis then worked inside his head crafting armour and weapons giving Zeus an almighty headache. Hephaestus and Prometheus conjured a plan to fix the pain. They forged an axe that split Zeus' head in two from which Athena emerged. (Zeus' head then healed itself). Athens is named after her after she gifted the city the world's first olive tree. Her signature appearance is with an owl on her shoulder, symbol of watchful wisdom, and the serpent coiled around her feet, symbol of guile, as shown by her father winning over her mother. Like Demeter, she would remain untouched by man. The Greek word for virgin, Parthenos, is often attached to her name, hence the Parthenon, her temple on the Acropolis.

source.name: Pelagon

target.name: Amphidamas

source.name: Echion
source.notes: Cadmus, after slaying the Ismenian Dragon, planted the teeth to assuage the wrath of Ares whose guardian it was. From which sprouted the Spartoi of which five survived to become the founding Lords of Thebes, named after the place where they sprouted.

target.name: Ismenian Dragon
target.notes: A giant serpent that guarded the sacred spring of Ares near Thebes. Cadmus killed it and to placate Ares, on instructions from Athena, sowed the dragon's teeth, which produced a crop of fully-grown, armed warriors called the Spartoi who would go on to become the ancestral lords of Thebes. Ares would have his revenge later, transforming Cadmus and his wife into serpents.

source.name: Ino
source.notes: She suckled her sister Semele's child by Zeus (the infant Dionysus). Married King Athamas of Boetia. She wanted her own children and not her step-children Phrixus and Helle to take the throne of Boetia so she contrived a famine and claimed that only the sacrifice of Phrixus would end it (Helle wouldn't be parted and agreed to die with him). When their mother Nephele heard about this she sent a golden ram to rescue them from the sacrifical altar. Athamas eventually discovered her wicked plot and killed her son Learchus in the ensuing frenzy. He cornered Ino and her other child, Melicertes and they threw themselves over the cliffs in despair. Dionysus, ever grateful to his step-mother, transformed her into the immortal Leucothea, the 'white-goddess' of the sea.

source.name: Ino
source.notes: She suckled her sister Semele's child by Zeus (the infant Dionysus). Married King Athamas of Boetia. She wanted her own children and not her step-children Phrixus and Helle to take the throne of Boetia so she contrived a famine and claimed that only the sacrifice of Phrixus would end it (Helle wouldn't be parted and agreed to die with him). When their mother Nephele heard about this she sent a golden ram to rescue them from the sacrifical altar. Athamas eventually discovered her wicked plot and killed her son Learchus in the ensuing frenzy. He cornered Ino and her other child, Melicertes and they threw themselves over the cliffs in despair. Dionysus, ever grateful to his step-mother, transformed her into the immortal Leucothea, the 'white-goddess' of the sea.

target.name: Harmonia
target.notes: Wife of Cadmus, Prince of Tyre and King of Thebes. When he was finally worn down by Ares for killing the Ismenian Dragon and turned into a snake, Athena turned her into a snake also so they could live out their days together.

source.name: Ino
source.notes: She suckled her sister Semele's child by Zeus (the infant Dionysus). Married King Athamas of Boetia. She wanted her own children and not her step-children Phrixus and Helle to take the throne of Boetia so she contrived a famine and claimed that only the sacrifice of Phrixus would end it (Helle wouldn't be parted and agreed to die with him). When their mother Nephele heard about this she sent a golden ram to rescue them from the sacrifical altar. Dionysus, ever grateful to his step-mother, transformed her into the immortal Leucothea, the 'white-goddess' of the sea.

target.name: Dionysus
target.notes: Produced the world's first vintage from his lover and friend Ampelos (vine in Greek). Replaced Hestia in the quorum of twelve Olympians after she retired. The Gods were happy to have Dionysus for his wine and debauchery, all except Hera, as Dionysus was the result of Zeus's affair with Semele. Hera swore never to drink from Dionysus's cup and would later curse his son Priapus with ugliness and impotence.

source.name: Semele
source.notes: A lover of Zeus. Upon Hera discovering yet another affair, she tricked Semele into doubting if it really was Zeus she was in love with, and that she should find out for sure by asking him to show himself in his true form. He duly obliged transforming into the mightiest and brightest thundercloud that struck Semele dead. Upon hearing Hera's wicked, vengeful laugh, Zeus rescued their unborn child from Semele's womb and kept it safe in his thigh. This child would be born Dionysus.

target.name: Cadmus
target.notes: Charged with rescuing his sister Europa who had ridden off on a bull (Zeus) to Crete. He met his future wife Harmony on his quest. Consulting the Delphic Oracle he was told to give up the search and instead follow a heifer marked with a half moon. Where it drops, there you must build. Later he would be told to enter the Phocian Games where he would win a cow which, lo and behold, had a half moon shaped mark on its back. He followed the cow to a place where the Ismenian Dragon, sacred to the god of war, Ares, was. He bravely killed the dragon but made a mighty enemy in the process. Athena came to his and Harmony's aid and ordered them to plant the teeth from which sprouted soldiers, which he called Spartoi. He built the city of Thebes on this site and the Spartoi would be his lords. Ares, not to be outdone, would plague Cadmus's happiness from then on, eventually wearing him down so much he begged for it to come to an end. Ares duly obliged turning him into a snake. Athena took pity on Harmony and turned her into a snake also. The couple would go on to live together in a temple sacred to Athena.

target.name: Zeus
target.god_of: King of the Gods, god of sky, weather & fate
target.notes: Rhea tricked Kronos into eating a piece of magnetite and escaped to Crete to have Zeus. She vowed that he'd take revenge on Kronos. He gives Kronos poison where he regurgitates all 5 children that he ate

source.name: Pentheus
source.notes: King of Thebes after Cadmus and Harmonia departed. Was torn to pieces by his mother's sisters for their failure to venerate Dionysus.

target.name: Agave
target.notes: Was torn to pieces by her sisters, her son Pentheus also died with her, for their failure to honour the god Dionysus.

source.name: Beroë
source.god_of: Nurse of the gods, god of the city of Beirut
source.notes: Gave her name to the city of Beirut.

target.name: Aphrodite
target.god_of: God of Love, Beauty, Pleasure & Procreation
target.notes: Child of Ouranos' genitals as they "impregnated" the sea when discarded by Kronos. Hence the image of Aphrodite emerging from the sea on a scallop (Botticelli). Kept safe by Zeus in the Titan War.

source.name: Beroë
source.god_of: Nurse of the gods, god of the city of Beirut
source.notes: Gave her name to the city of Beirut.

target.name: Adonis
target.notes: The result of incestuous love between Theias, King of Cyprus, and his daughter Smyrna. He attracted the attention of Aphrodite, who had caused his birth in the first place by cursing his mother with incestuous thoughts due to Theias's neglect of her sacred birth place of Cyprus. He was killed by a wild boar, some say this was a jealous Ares in disguise. A distraught Aphrodite vowed from then on that love would be forever tinged with tragedy as she prophesised whilst holding a dying Adonis in her arms, "Sorrow on love hereafter shall attend..., It shall be cause of war and dire events, And set dissension 'twixt the son and sire..., They that love best their loves shall not enjoy."

source.name: Beroë
source.god_of: Nurse of the gods, god of the city of Beirut
source.notes: Gave her name to the city of Beirut.

target.name: Poseidon
target.god_of: God of Seas, Earthquakes, Floods, Droughts & Horses
target.notes: Swallowed by Kronos when born due to Ouranos' curse on him that "Your own children will overthrow you as you overthrew me". Giften the weapon of a Trident by the Cyclopes.

target.name: Silenus
target.notes: Fathered by Hermes and an unknown nymph, Silenus was a snub-nosed, donkey-tailed lecher who would grow up to become a bearded, pot-bellied old drunk. A popular subject in paintings and sculptures.

source.name: Chiron
source.notes: Possibly taught Dionysus how to make wine from grapes.

target.name: Kronos
target.god_of: God of Earth, Sea, Sky & Time
target.notes: Castrated his father Ouranos for impregnating his mother Gaia every night when the sky fell to the earth. Ouranos warned him that his children will rise up against him just as he'd done to his father. Terrified of the prophecy coming true he ate his new born children, gobbling them down as soon as his wife Rhea gave birth. Rhea hid her last born, tricking Kronos into eating a black marble stone wrapped in swaddling clothes. This last born child was Zeus who would return and fulfill the prophecy. After defeat by Zeus in the Titan War he was condemned to count to infinity, god of time. Some scholars separate Kronos (Titan) and Chronos (Time). Titan meaning "the striving one", meant as an insult by Ouranos when condenming his son Kronos' ambition when castrating him.

source.name: Chiron
source.notes: Possibly taught Dionysus how to make wine from grapes.

target.name: Phylira
target.notes: Lover of Kronos, she tried to rebut his advances but he transformed into a mighty stallion and took her against her will. The great Centaur, Chiron was the offspring of this union.

source.name: Ampelos
source.notes: Dionysus was so besotted with Ampelos that he would let him win all games between them. Ampelos would become spoiled as a result and once boasted that he rode his wild bull better than Selene, the goddess of the moon. Selene struck him down causing the bull to trample and gore Ampelos. Dionysus could not save him but instead watched his corpse transform magically into a winding, climbing plant replete with drops of blood which solidified into berries. He had become a vine from which Dionysus would produce the world's first wine.

target.name: Dionysus
target.notes: Produced the world's first vintage from his lover and friend Ampelos (vine in Greek). Replaced Hestia in the quorum of twelve Olympians after she retired. The Gods were happy to have Dionysus for his wine and debauchery, all except Hera, as Dionysus was the result of Zeus's affair with Semele. Hera swore never to drink from Dionysus's cup and would later curse his son Priapus with ugliness and impotence.

source.name: Staphylos
source.notes: King of Assyria, he gave a banquet in Dionysus's honour and promptly died of the world's first hangover. In his honour Dionysus named bunches of grapes after him, staphylos.

Hera swore never to drink from Dionysus's cup and would later curse his son Priapus with ugliness and impotence.

source.name: Priapus
source.god_of: God of Phalluses, Male Genitalia & Vegetable Gardens
source.notes: Cursed by Hera as he was the son of Dionysus, who was the result of an affair by Zeus. She cursed him with ugliness and impotence and had him cast from Olympus. Priapus is the god of male genitalia, cursed to wander in a state of excitement which would fail him when he tried to do anything about it. The irony that his father is the god of alcohol is not lost on the gods, the gift to the world that 'provokes desire but takes away the performance'.

target.name: Aphrodite
target.god_of: God of Love, Beauty, Pleasure & Procreation
target.notes: Child of Ouranos' genitals as they "impregnated" the sea when discarded by Kronos. Hence the image of Aphrodite emerging from the sea on a scallop (Botticelli). Kept safe by Zeus in the Titan War.

source.god_of: God of Phalluses, Male Genitalia & Vegetable Gardens
source.notes: Cursed by Hera as he was the son of Dionysus, who was the result of an affair by Zeus. She cursed him with ugliness and impotence and had him cast from Olympus. source.name: Aristaeus
source.god_of: God of Cheesemaking, Beekeeping, Hunting & Olive-growing
source.notes: Minor deity of bee-keeping, agriculture and other country crafts. He pursued Orpheus' wife, Eurydice. She ran away and fell into a ditch where she was bitten by an adder and killed. Thus began the hero Orpheus' quest to retrieve her from the underworld.

target.name: Apollo
target.god_of: God of Mathematics, reason, logic, poetry, medicine, knowledge, prophecy, archery & music
target.notes: He kills a Python sent by Hera to eat him and his sister. The Python came from the landing site of the magnetite stone that Kronos ate thinking it was the infant Zeus. As the Python was born of Gaia and under divine protection he had to be punished by Zeus. He was exiled for eight years to the snake's birthplace beneath Mount Parnassus to replace the snake as guardian of the Omphalos (the spiritual centre of Greece, whose name he would change to Delphi and establish an oracle where anyone could come to ask the god or his appointed priestess, known as a Sibyl or Pythia, questions about the future) and to atone for his crime. Here he would go on to organise The Pythian Games every four years. Apollo was gifted music by Hermes (a tortoise shell with cow guts as strings, the first lyre) as a show of repentence after he stole Apollo's cattle.

source.name: Actaeon
source.notes: Stumbled upon Artemis bathing in a lake whilst out hunting. She, the goddess of chastity, couldn't bear anyone to see her naked so she ordered him to never speak another word. He duly forgot and was turned into a stag by Artemis. Actaeon's original hunting party then caught up with him and killed him.

target.name: Autonoë
target.notes: nan

target.name: Chiron
target.notes: Possibly taught Dionysus how to make wine from grapes.

source.name: Mestra
source.notes: Mestra, daughter of Erysicthon, King of Thessaly, was a former lover of Poseidon, who had rewarded her with the ability to alter her shape at will. She used this gift to help her father who had been cursed by Demeter and Limos, the demon of famine and starvation, to being in a state of constant hunger. She would be sold to a suitor so her father could raise money to appease his insatiable hunger, transform into one animal or another and escape, ready to be sold again.

target.name: Erysichthon
target.notes: King of Thessaly. He angered Demeter, the goddess of the harvest, by chopping down a sacred tree. Demeter sent Limos, one of the monsters released from Pandora's jar to curse him. Limos was a demon of famine and starvation and cursed Erysichthon with constant, unsatiated hunger. He was reduced to selling his daughter Mestra to raise money to try and appease his impossibe appetite. Eventually he ate himself and Demter was avenged.

source.name: Mestra

source.name: Coronis
source.notes: Princess of Phlegyantis, she was a lover of Apollo, but whilst pregnant with his child she cheated on him with a mortal, Ischys. One of Apollo's white crows witnessed the affair and reported back to Apollo. Apollo asked his sister Artemis to enact revenge on the kingdom for this betrayal. The crow informed Apollo that Coronis lay dying but she didn't ask for forgiveness, only to save their child. The crow crowed once too many times and Apollo lost his temper and turned it black, all crows have been that colour ever since. Apollo did save the baby, who would be called Asclepius.

The crow informed Apollo that Coronis lay dying but she didn't ask for forgiveness, only to save their child. target.name: Ischys
target.notes: Lover of Coronis who cheated on Apollo whilst pregnant with his child.

source.name: Asclepius
source.notes: Son of Apollo and Coronis, who was avenged for having an affair whilst pregnant with Asclepius but the baby was saved from her womb by Apollo. He was raised by Chiron who nurtured his precocious talent of medicine and healing. Once he healed a bruised snake with a potion of his own making. This pleased Athena, to whom snakes were sacred, and the snake whispered into Asclepius's ear the many secrets of healing and medicine. To this day, many ambulances and clinics can be seen with an emblem bearing a wooden staff (staff of Ascelpius) entwined with a serpent. Athena also presented a jar of Gorgon's blood as a reward. This famed liquid that keeps the gods immortal, is deadly to humans, but can bring the dead back to life. Later in life, unable to resist temptation, Asclepius started to use the blood on his patients. This angered Hades who complained that there were no more dead being delivered to him. Zeus agreed and struck Asclepius dead with a bolt of thunder. This angered Apollo, his father, so much that he struck the cyclopes Brontes, Steropes, and Arges dead (it was the cyclopes that manufactured Zeus's thunderbolts). Such rebelliousness was punished by Zeus and Apollo was commanded to serve the Thessalian King Admetus in a lowly position for one whole year.

target.notes: Possibly taught Dionysus how to make wine from grapes.

source.name: Epione
source.notes: Her name means 'soothing', or 'relief from pain'. She married Asclepius, the master of medicine and healing.

target.name: Asclepius
target.notes: Son of Apollo and Coronis, who was avenged for having an affair whilst pregnant with Asclepius but the baby was saved from her womb by Apollo. He was raised by Chiron who nurtured his precocious talent of medicine and healing. Once he healed a bruised snake with a potion of his own making. This pleased Athena, to whom snakes were sacred, and the snake whispered into Asclepius's ear the many secrets of healing and medicine. To this day, many ambulances and clinics can be seen with an emblem bearing a wooden staff (staff of Ascelpius) entwined with a serpent. Athena also presented a jar of Gorgon's blood as a reward. This famed liquid that keeps the gods immortal, is deadly to humans, but can bring the dead back to life. Later in life, unable to resist temptation, Asclepius started to use the blood on his patients. This angered Hades who complained that there were no more dead being delivered to him. Zeus agreed and struck Asclepius dead with a bolt of thunder. This angered Apollo, his father, so much that he struck the cyclopes Brontes, Steropes, and Arges dead (it was the cyclopes that manufactured Zeus's thunderbolts). Such rebelliousness was punished by Zeus and Apollo was commanded to serve the Thessalian King Admetus in a lowly position for one whole year.

source.notes: Daughter of Asclepius, the master of medicine and healing. She was trained in the practices of cleanliness, diet and physical exercise that are today named 'hygiene' after her.

target.name: Epione

source.name: Admetus
source.notes: Thessalian King, he had won the approval of Zeus for his exceptionally warm hospitality. When Apollo was punished for killing the cyclopes that helped kill his son Asclepius, he was sent to Admetus to serve under him for one whole year. The two became great friends, again due to his warm hospitality. Apollo made a deal with the Moirai to make him immortal, he just had to find someone to die in his place. His loving wife Alcestis agreed to die for him. Filled with remorse, he tried to stop her, but the will of the Moirai could not be overturned. It was at her funeral that Heracles arrived to stay with Admetus. Finding out about the tragic events, he promised to rescue Alcestis from the underworld. He found Thanatos, the god of death at her tomb and wrestled him to the ground, rescuing Alcestis and taking her back to Admetus.

source.name: Admetus
