target.name: Apollo
target.god_of: God of Mathematics, reason, logic, poetry, medicine, knowledge, prophecy, archery & music
target.notes: He kills a Python sent by Hera to eat him and his sister. The Python came from the landing site of the magnetite stone that Kronos ate thinking it was the infant Zeus. As the Python was born of Gaia and under divine protection he had to be punished by Zeus. He was exiled for eight years to the snake's birthplace beneath Mount Parnassus to replace the snake as guardian of the Omphalos (the spiritual centre of Greece, whose name he would change to Delphi and establish an oracle where anyone could come to ask the god or his appointed priestess, known as a Sibyl or Pythia, questions about the future) and to atone for his crime. Here he would go on to organise The Pythian Games every four years. Apollo was gifted music by Hermes (a tortoise shell with cow guts as strings, the first lyre) as a show of repentence after he stole Apollo's cattle.

source.name: Admetus
source.notes: Thessalian King, he had won the approval of Zeus for his exceptionally warm hospitality. When Apollo was punished for killing the cyclopes that helped kill his son Asclepius, he was sent to Admetus to serve under him for one whole year. The two became great friends, again due to his warm hospitality. Apollo made a deal with the Moirai to make him immortal, he just had to find someone to die in his place. His loving wife Alcestis agreed to die for him. Filled with remorse, he tried to stop her, but the will of the Moirai could not be overturned. It was at her funeral that Heracles arrived to stay with Admetus. Finding out about the tragic events, he promised to rescue Alcestis from the underworld. He found Thanatos, the god of death at her tomb and wrestled him to the ground, rescuing Alcestis and taking her back to Admetus.

target.name: Heracles
target.notes: Born Alcides, son of Zeus and Alcmene. Zeus had wanted a child in the blood line of Perseus as Hera had prophecised that a child of Perseus would save the Olympians. Hera was so incensed at yet another affair of Zeus that she swore eternal enmity against Alcides. Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

source.name: Dia
source.notes: Wife of Ixion, the King of Lapiths and daughter of Deioneus, King of Phocis. Ixion angered the gods when he refused to pay the dowry for Dia to Deioneus.

target.name: Deioneus
target.notes: King of Phocis. His daughter, Dia, was married to Ixion, the King of Lapiths. When Ixion refused to pay the agreed bride-price for his daughter, he took revenge but was thrown into a fiery pit by Ixion.

source.name: Dia
source.notes: Wife of Ixion, the King of Lapiths and daughter of Deioneus, King of Phocis. Ixion angered the gods when he refused to pay the dowry for Dia to Deioneus.

target.name: Ixion
target.notes: Ixion, already angering the gods to breaking point by refusing one of their most strongly held beliefs, the spirit of hospitality, or xenia, and by killing his father-in-law, Deioneus, King of Phocis and committing the first blood murder, would go on to anger them even further. Invited to a banquet by Zeus he tried it on with his wife, Hera. An angry Zeus then tested him the day after by animating a cloud shaped Hera look-a-like and presenting it to Ixion. He duly impregnated her. This was the final straw and Zeus bound him to a wheel of fire and sent him down to the depths of Tartarus where he revolves, spread-eagled and roasting in agony to this day. "Thou art a soul in bliss,but I am bound Upon a wheel of fire, that mine own tears Do scald like molten lead." King Lear.

source.name: Centauros
source.notes: His father Ixion had angered Zeus by sleeping with Nephele thinking it was Hera, Zeus's wife. Centauros was the result of Nephele's and Ixion's liasion. An ugly and misshapen boy he turned his back on humans and instead roamed with the wild mares of Mount Pelion. The result was a progeny of untameable and savage animals, part man, part horse named after him, Centaurs.

target.name: Nephele
target.notes: Zeus, angered by Ixion who tried to seduce Hera, sent Nephele to Ixion with the appearance of Hera as a trap. He coupled with her incurring Zeus's wrath in the process who bound him to a burning wheel in the depths of Tartarus for eternity. The result of this coupling was a son, Centauros.

source.name: Phylira

target.name: Kronos
target.god_of: God of Earth, Sea, Sky & Time
target.notes: Castrated his father Ouranos for impregnating his mother Gaia every night when the sky fell to the earth. Ouranos warned him that his children will rise up against him just as he'd done to his father. Terrified of the prophecy coming true he ate his new born children, gobbling them down as soon as his wife Rhea gave birth. Rhea hid her last born, tricking Kronos into eating a black marble stone wrapped in swaddling clothes. This last born child was Zeus who would return and fulfill the prophecy. After defeat by Zeus in the Titan War he was condemned to count to infinity, god of time. Some scholars separate Kronos (Titan) and Chronos (Time). Titan meaning "the striving one", meant as an insult by Ouranos when condenming his son Kronos' ambition when castrating him.

source.name: Iphimedia
source.notes: Lover of Poseidon she bore him twin sons, Otus and Ephialtes.

target.name: Poseidon
target.god_of: God of Seas, Earthquakes, Floods, Droughts & Horses
target.notes: Swallowed by Kronos when born due to Ouranos' curse on him that "Your own children will overthrow you as you overthrew me". Giften the weapon of a Trident by the Cyclopes.

source.name: Otus
source.notes: Giants in every sense of the word, Otus and his twin Ephialtes were instructed by their father Poseidon to test heaven by building their own mountain. Zeus heard about this devious plan to challenge his authority and he sent Apollo to fell them with arrows. Their punishment in the underworld was to be bound to pillars with writhing snakes.

He coupled with her incurring Zeus's wrath in the process who bound him to a burning wheel in the depths of Tartarus for eternity. The result of this coupling was a son, Centauros.

source.name: Athamas
source.notes: Boeotian king married to the cloud nymph Nephele of Hera doppelgänger fame.

target.name: Ino
target.notes: She suckled her sister Semele's child by Zeus (the infant Dionysus). Married King Athamas of Boetia. She wanted her own children and not her step-children Phrixus and Helle to take the throne of Boetia so she contrived a famine and claimed that only the sacrifice of Phrixus would end it (Helle wouldn't be parted and agreed to die with him). When their mother Nephele heard about this she sent a golden ram to rescue them from the sacrifical altar. Athamas eventually discovered her wicked plot and killed her son Learchus in the ensuing frenzy. He cornered Ino and her other child, Melicertes and they threw themselves over the cliffs in despair. Dionysus, ever grateful to his step-mother, transformed her into the immortal Leucothea, the 'white-goddess' of the sea.

source.name: Athamas
source.notes: Boeotian king married to the cloud nymph Nephele of Hera doppelgänger fame.

target.name: Sisyphus
target.notes: Horrible, nasty Sisyphus. He despised his brother, Salmoneus, more than anything. He married his brother's daughter, Tyro, because the Delphic Oracle told him that the result of that union would bring his brother down. This was foiled when his wife discovered the plan, took revenge by drowning their two children, and fled back to her father. He angered the gods so much that Zeus personally sent Thanatos to take him to the underworld. However, proud of his cunning, he tricked Thanatos into handcuffing himself by mocking his shackles and saying that they wouldn't work. He then kept Thanatos prisoner in his wardrobe. Knowing that without death, the gods would be on his tail sooner or later, he made a pact with his new wife to not make offerings to the gods when he did eventually die so that he couldn't cross the River Styx. When Thanatos was finally rescued he came for him again and took him to the underworld. When he couldn't cross the Styx he swam across, looking the worse for wear on the other side he spoke with Persephone, Queen of the underworld, and told her that his appearance was due to his wife's neglect in not making offerings to the gods to enable his passage. A shocked Persephone wanted to punish his wife, but Sisyphus tricked her into sending him back to life to take revenge on her in person. They would go on to live happily ever after. When his wife died and Persephone's decree finally expired, Thanatos came for him a third time, but this time Hermes offered him a deal, in cheating death twice you have earned a chance at immortality. All you have to do is push this boulder up the slope and out of the opening at the top to attain immortality, or, you can go to Elysium and live a happy afterlife. Sisyphus thought that the task was possible so that's what he chose. He is still there to this day, in the halls of Tartarus, pushing the boulder up the hill only to fail and see it come crashing down again.

source.name: Phrixus
source.notes: His cruel step-mother Ino, wanted her own children to inherit the throne of Boetia so she contrived a famine and informed her husband King Athamas that the only way to end it was to sacrifice Phrixus (his sister Helle wouldn't be parted and agreed to be sacrificed alongside). When their mother Nephele heard about this she sent the Golden Ram to rescue them from the sacrifical altar.

target.name: Nephele
target.notes: Zeus, angered by Ixion who tried to seduce Hera, sent Nephele to Ixion with the appearance of Hera as a trap. He coupled with her incurring Zeus's wrath in the process who bound him to a burning wheel in the depths of Tartarus for eternity. The result of this coupling was a son, Centauros.

source.name: Phrixus

When their mother Nephele heard about this she sent the Golden Ram to rescue them from the sacrifical altar.

target.name: Athamas
target.notes: Boeotian king married to the cloud nymph Nephele of Hera doppelgänger fame.

source.name: Phrixus
source.notes: His cruel step-mother Ino, wanted her own children to inherit the throne of Boetia so she contrived a famine and informed her husband King Athamas that the only way to end it was to sacrifice Phrixus (his sister Helle wouldn't be parted and agreed to be sacrificed alongside). When their mother Nephele heard about this she sent the Golden Ram to rescue them from the sacrifical altar.

target.name: Golden Ram
target.notes: Nephele sent the Golden Ram to rescue her children Phrixus and Helle from being sacrificed. Helle was killed when she fell from the ram but Phrixus survived and sacrificed the ram to Zeus and presented Aeëtes, King of Colchis, where Phrixus sought refuge, with its golden fleece. Zeus, pleased with the offering, raised the noble creature to the firmament as Aries, the Ram.

source.name: Helle
source.notes: Her cruel step-mother Ino, wanted her own children to inherit the throne of Boetia so she contrived a famine and informed her husband King Athamas that the only way to end it was to sacrifice her brother Phrixus (Helle wouldn't be parted and agreed to be sacrificed alongside). When their mother Nephele heard about this she sent the Golden Ram to rescue them from the sacrifical altar. A gust of wind caused Helle to fall from the ram and she plummeted to hear death in the sea below. The Greeks call this spot 'the Hellespont, or Sea of Helle' in her honour (now known as the Dardanelles).

target.name: Atlas
target.god_of: God of Astronomy & Bearer of the Heavens
target.notes: Zeus' most powerful opponent in the Titan War he was punished to hold up the sky for eternity to separate heaven from earth. He solidified into the Atlas Mountains we call today. Heracles sought his aid during one of his labours to retrieve the Golden Apples of the the Hesperides. As the Hesperides were friends of Atlas he was able to retreive the Apples whilst Heracles held up the sky for him.

source.name: Dione
source.notes: nan

target.name: Tantalus
target.notes: Ruler of the kingdom of Lydia, modern day Anatolia in Turkey, he grew immensely rich from local mineral deposits. He abused Zeus's hospitality (one of the most serious offences in the eyes of the gods) by stealing ambrosia and nectar from Olympus. He offered to put on a feast to appease the gods as this was the time of Demeter's search for her daughter Persephone, a time of famine across the Earth. In a cruel twist, Tantalus offered his own son, Pelops, as part of the feast. Demeter took a bite from his shoulder and noticed there was something amiss. Zeus understood and summoned Clotho, the spinner, to put the body parts back together. Demeter had Hephaestus carve him a new shoulder from ivory and Zeus reanimated him. Tantalus was dispatched straight to Tartarus and cursed for eternity to have a bough of a tree laden with luscious fruits dangle above his head, just out of reach, and a pool of water up to his waist that would sink when he tried to drink from it. He could not move away as above him hovered a great stone that threatened to crush him if he did (this stone material would later be named tanatlum). There Tantalus stands to this day, plagued by thirst and hunger, yet so close to food and water, yet cannot quite reach them, so tantalisingly close (also named after him).

source.name: Dione
source.notes: nan

target.name: Dionysus
target.notes: Produced the world's first vintage from his lover and friend Ampelos (vine in Greek). Replaced Hestia in the quorum of twelve Olympians after she retired. The Gods were happy to have Dionysus for his wine and debauchery, all except Hera, as Dionysus was the result of Zeus's affair with Semele. Hera swore never to drink from Dionysus's cup and would later curse his son Priapus with ugliness and impotence.

source.name: Pelops
source.notes: King of Pisa in the Peloponnese. Murdered by his father and offered to the gods during a feast. The gods were so angered they dispatched Tantalus to Tartarus for eternity and brought Pelops back to life, endowing him with a new shoulder made of ivory to replace the one that was mistakenly eaten. He took in Laius as a baby who was smuggled out of Thebes when his father, Labdacus was overthrown. Laius took Pelops' son, Chrysippus with him when he finally returned to Thebes to reclaim his throne. This wasn't a consensual relationship so Chrysippus took his own life. Pelops swore a curse on Laius and his line for ever.

source.name: Niobe
source.notes: Angered Leto, the titaness and mother of the gods by comparing her own motherhood to hers. She claimed a real mother would raise more than two children, she herself had managed fourteen. When Leto heard about this her children Artemis and Apollo went straight to Thebes and hunted down every one of Noibe's fourteen children and wiped them out. Her grief was uncontollable. The gods themselves couldn't even bear her unending lamentations and turned her to stone. But not even solid stone could hold the tears back. Even now, visitors to the place she was turned to stone, Mount Spil, can see the rock formation bears her resemblance and the gushing waters that flow from it.

source.name: Tyro
source.notes: Wife of Sisyphus and daughter of his brother Salmoneus (yes, he married his niece). Sisyphus only married her because the Delphic Oracle told Sisyphus that "Sons of Sisyphus and Tyro rise to slay Salmoneus". Salmoneus was his brother whom he despised more than anything. One day Tyro found out the real reason for their marriage. Feeling a stronger attachment to her father rather than her husband, she drowned their children in the river before fleeing back to her father.

target.name: Salmoneus

target.name: Sisyphus
target.notes: Horrible, nasty Sisyphus. He despised his brother, Salmoneus, more than anything. He married his brother's daughter, Tyro, because the Delphic Oracle told him that the result of that union would bring his brother down. This was foiled when his wife discovered the plan, took revenge by drowning their two children, and fled back to her father. He angered the gods so much that Zeus personally sent Thanatos to take him to the underworld. However, proud of his cunning, he tricked Thanatos into handcuffing himself by mocking his shackles and saying that they wouldn't work. He then kept Thanatos prisoner in his wardrobe. Knowing that without death, the gods would be on his tail sooner or later, he made a pact with his new wife to not make offerings to the gods when he did eventually die so that he couldn't cross the River Styx. When Thanatos was finally rescued he came for him again and took him to the underworld. When he couldn't cross the Styx he swam across, looking the worse for wear on the other side he spoke with Persephone, Queen of the underworld, and told her that his appearance was due to his wife's neglect in not making offerings to the gods to enable his passage. A shocked Persephone wanted to punish his wife, but Sisyphus tricked her into sending him back to life to take revenge on her in person. They would go on to live happily ever after. When his wife died and Persephone's decree finally expired, Thanatos came for him a third time, but this time Hermes offered him a deal, in cheating death twice you have earned a chance at immortality. All you have to do is push this boulder up the slope and out of the opening at the top to attain immortality, or, you can go to Elysium and live a happy afterlife. Sisyphus thought that the task was possible so that's what he chose. He is still there to this day, in the halls of Tartarus, pushing the boulder up the hill only to fail and see it come crashing down again.

target.name: Gaia
target.notes: Mother Earth. Progenitor of the first generation of Titans.

source.name: Nycteus
source.notes: One of the original Theban Spartoi who sprouted from the dragon's teeth.

target.name: Ismenian Dragon
target.notes: A giant serpent that guarded the sacred spring of Ares near Thebes. Cadmus killed it and to placate Ares, on instructions from Athena, sowed the dragon's teeth, which produced a crop of fully-grown, armed warriors called the Spartoi who would go on to become the ancestral lords of Thebes. Ares would have his revenge later, transforming Cadmus and his wife into serpents.

source.name: Nycteus
source.notes: One of the original Theban Spartoi who sprouted from the dragon's teeth.

target.name: Cadmus
target.notes: Charged with rescuing his sister Europa who had ridden off on a bull (Zeus) to Crete. He met his future wife Harmony on his quest. Consulting the Delphic Oracle he was told to give up the search and instead follow a heifer marked with a half moon. Where it drops, there you must build. Later he would be told to enter the Phocian Games where he would win a cow which, lo and behold, had a half moon shaped mark on its back. He followed the cow to a place where the Ismenian Dragon, sacred to the god of war, Ares, was. He bravely killed the dragon but made a mighty enemy in the process. Athena came to his and Harmony's aid and ordered them to plant the teeth from which sprouted soldiers, which he called Spartoi. He built the city of Thebes on this site and the Spartoi would be his lords. Ares, not to be outdone, would plague Cadmus's happiness from then on, eventually wearing him down so much he begged for it to come to an end. Ares duly obliged turning him into a snake. Athena took pity on Harmony and turned her into a snake also. The couple would go on to live together in a temple sacred to Athena.

source.name: Heracles
source.notes: Born Alcides, son of Zeus and Alcmene. Zeus had wanted a child in the blood line of Perseus as Hera had prophecised that a child of Perseus would save the Olympians. Hera was so incensed at yet another affair of Zeus that she swore eternal enmity against Alcides. Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

source.name: Heracles
source.notes: Born Alcides, son of Zeus and Alcmene. Zeus had wanted a child in the blood line of Perseus as Hera had prophecised that a child of Perseus would save the Olympians. Hera was so incensed at yet another affair of Zeus that she swore eternal enmity against Alcides. Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

target.name: Alcmene
target.notes: Impregnated by Zeus as he wanted to guard against Hera's prophecy that someone from the line of Perseus would save the Olympians. He decided that who would be better than a descendant of Perseus and a son of his own? He disguised himself as Electryon, Alcmene's husband. Hera, angered at yet another dalliance, ordered her daughter Eileithyia, the goddess of childbirth to prevent the offspring being born. Alcemene got help from Galanthis and Historis who tricked Eileithyia into thinking the baby had been born. She was then able to give birth to twins, Alcides (later to become Heracles) and Iphicles, Alcides by Zeus, and Iphicles by Electryon.

source.name: Marsyas
source.notes: A satyr, a follower of Dionysus he found Athena's aulos, a woodwind instrument that she had discarded from Olympus because she couldn't get a good enough sound from it. He mastered the instrument and in a foolish moment of hubris he challenged the god of the lyre, Apollo, to a competition. Apollo, obviously, won the contest and punished Marsyas by flaying the skin right off him (the gods hated hubris although some scholars suggest it was his hide that he removed and not his actual skin) but the 'Flaying of Marsyas' would become a favourite subject of painters, poets and sculptors from then on. A parable on the impossibility of outdoing the divine.

target.name: Apollo
target.god_of: God of Mathematics, reason, logic, poetry, medicine, knowledge, prophecy, archery & music
target.notes: He kills a Python sent by Hera to eat him and his sister. The Python came from the landing site of the magnetite stone that Kronos ate thinking it was the infant Zeus. As the Python was born of Gaia and under divine protection he had to be punished by Zeus. He was exiled for eight years to the snake's birthplace beneath Mount Parnassus to replace the snake as guardian of the Omphalos (the spiritual centre of Greece, whose name he would change to Delphi and establish an oracle where anyone could come to ask the god or his appointed priestess, known as a Sibyl or Pythia, questions about the future) and to atone for his crime. Here he would go on to organise The Pythian Games every four years. Apollo was gifted music by Hermes (a tortoise shell with cow guts as strings, the first lyre) as a show of repentence after he stole Apollo's cattle.

source.name: Marsyas
source.notes: A satyr, a follower of Dionysus he found Athena's aulos, a woodwind instrument that she had discarded from Olympus because she couldn't get a good enough sound from it. He mastered the instrument and in a foolish moment of hubris he challenged the god of the lyre, Apollo, to a competition. Apollo, obviously, won the contest and punished Marsyas by flaying the skin right off him (the gods hated hubris although some scholars suggest it was his hide that he removed and not his actual skin) but the 'Flaying of Marsyas' would become a favourite subject of painters, poets and sculptors from then on. A parable on the impossibility of outdoing the divine.

target.name: Dionysus
target.notes: Produced the world's first vintage from his lover and friend Ampelos (vine in Greek). Replaced Hestia in the quorum of twelve Olympians after she retired. The Gods were happy to have Dionysus for his wine and debauchery, all except Hera, as Dionysus was the result of Zeus's affair with Semele. Hera swore never to drink from Dionysus's cup and would later curse his son Priapus with ugliness and impotence.

source.name: Arachne
source.notes: Dared to compare her talent for weaving to that of the goddess Athena. Athena challenged her to a weave-off. Athena went first and made a tapestry depicted of mortals' foolish attempts to challenge the gods as a thinly veiled warning. Arachne responded in a trance like state depicting the excesses of the gods and their lustful ways. Athena knew this couldn't go unpunished but before she could decide Arachne's fate, Arachne awoke from her trance like state, realised what she'd done and ran out of the house with a length of rope and hung herself from the nearest tree. Taking pity, Athena transformed her into a creature that would forever spend its days spinning and weaving, the first spider came into being and the word arachnid, named after her would apply to all spiders.

source.name: Arachne

Taking pity, Athena transformed her into a creature that would forever spend its days spinning and weaving, the first spider came into being and the word arachnid, named after her would apply to all spiders.

target.name: Athena
target.notes: Zeus would court Metis, transforming into various creatures to chase her. She hid in a deep cave but Zeus would transform into a snake and coil around her where she would become pregnant. Later she goaded him by transforming into a fly to escape, he transformed into a lizard and ate her (in a shocking Kronos eating his children repeat). Metis then worked inside his head crafting armour and weapons giving Zeus an almighty headache. Hephaestus and Prometheus conjured a plan to fix the pain. They forged an axe that split Zeus' head in two from which Athena emerged. (Zeus' head then healed itself). Athens is named after her after she gifted the city the world's first olive tree. Her signature appearance is with an owl on her shoulder, symbol of watchful wisdom, and the serpent coiled around her feet, symbol of guile, as shown by her father winning over her mother. Like Demeter, she would remain untouched by man. The Greek word for virgin, Parthenos, is often attached to her name, hence the Parthenon, her temple on the Acropolis.

source.name: Rhodope
source.notes: Queen of Thrace, transformed into a mountain for daring to compare her and her husband's grandeur with that of Hera and Zeus. They were woven into a tapestry by Athena as a warning to Arachne to not challenge the gods.

target.name: Hera
target.god_of: Queen of the Gods, god of Marriage, Women, the Sky & Stars of Heaven
target.notes: Swallowed by Kronos when born due to Ouranos' curse on him that "Your own children will overthrow you as you overthrew me". Married to Zeus.

source.name: Antigone
source.notes: A Trojan citizen, not the daughter of Oedipus who had the same name. She angered the gods in a show of hubris and had her hair turned to snakes as a result. She was woven into a tapestry by Athena as a warning to Arachne that the gods should not be challenged.

target.name: Athena
target.notes: Zeus would court Metis, transforming into various creatures to chase her. She hid in a deep cave but Zeus would transform into a snake and coil around her where she would become pregnant. Later she goaded him by transforming into a fly to escape, he transformed into a lizard and ate her (in a shocking Kronos eating his children repeat). Metis then worked inside his head crafting armour and weapons giving Zeus an almighty headache. Hephaestus and Prometheus conjured a plan to fix the pain. They forged an axe that split Zeus' head in two from which Athena emerged. (Zeus' head then healed itself). Athens is named after her after she gifted the city the world's first olive tree. Her signature appearance is with an owl on her shoulder, symbol of watchful wisdom, and the serpent coiled around her feet, symbol of guile, as shown by her father winning over her mother. Like Demeter, she would remain untouched by man. The Greek word for virgin, Parthenos, is often attached to her name, hence the Parthenon, her temple on the Acropolis.

source.name: Antigone
source.notes: Daughter of Oedipus and Jocasta, Oedipus' mother and wife. After Oedipus' demise her brothers, Eteocles and Polynices, agree to power share the throne of Thebes. But Eteocles reneged on the deal and Polynices raises an army (the so called Seven against Thebes) where both are killed in the ensuing battle. Polynices is denied proper burial as he was considered the agressor. Antigone, distraught at the idea of this attempts to cover the corpse but is caught and sentenced to death. Her sentence is commuted at the last minute but she hanged herself before she could get the news.

target.name: Oedipus
target.notes: His father, Laius, had received a prophecy that his son would kill him, so he had him imprisoned on the top of Mount Cithaeron as a baby. He was rescued and taken to Corinth where he was raised by the King and Queen, Polybus and Merope. They named him Oedipus which means 'swollen foot' after the scars on his once shackled ankles. During his life he heard rumours that he was adopted so he consulted with the Delphic oracle. Instead of being told who his real parents were, in typical oracular cryptic fashion he was told, "Oedipus will kill his father and mate with his mother". He decided to leave Corinth to avoid the possibility of the prophecy coming true. Whilst on the road he got into a fight with a man in a chariot who had hurled abuse at him to get out of the way, Oedipus killed him and his entourage during the ensuing fight. He ended up making his way toward Thebes, he answered one of the Sphinx's riddles on the way to reopen the road and lift the curse. He was welcomed into the city as a hero and welcomed by Queen Jocasta, unbeknownst to Oedipus, this was his real mother. She told him that her husband had been killed on the road by a gang of robbers, this was the very same fight that Oedipus had gotten into, part of the prophecy had come true. In time he fell in love with Jocasta. He became King and they married and had four children, thus completing the prophecy. Later in his reign he again sought the advice of the Delphic oracle about a vicious plague that had swept through the kingdom. The Pythia answered, "Thebes will be relieved when the murderer of King Laius is named and found." Oedipus sent for Laius' servant, Antimedes, who was the sole survivor of the fight that fateful day. As soon as Antimedes set eyes on Oedipus the whole horrendous truth came out. Oedipus discovered his true parents, his being abandoned by his mother and now wife, Jocasta, and the fact that the horrible prophecies had all come true. Jocasta ran away and hanged herself in the bedroom. Oedipus found her and thrust her gold brooch dress pins into his eyes in anguish.

source.name: Antigone
source.notes: Daughter of Oedipus and Jocasta, Oedipus' mother and wife. After Oedipus' demise her brothers, Eteocles and Polynices, agree to power share the throne of Thebes. But Eteocles reneged on the deal and Polynices raises an army (the so called Seven against Thebes) where both are killed in the ensuing battle. Polynices is denied proper burial as he was considered the agressor. Antigone, distraught at the idea of this attempts to cover the corpse but is caught and sentenced to death. Her sentence is commuted at the last minute but she hanged herself before she could get the news.

target.name: Jocasta
target.notes: Queen of Thebes. Her husband, King Laius had discarded their child, Oedipus, to avoid a prophecy which stated that his son would end up killing him. Oedipus was raised in Corinth but fate would have it that he would return to Thebes and he ended up marrying Jocasta after Laius had been killed. All of this was unbeknownst to the both of them. When a plague hit Thebes Oedipus sought the advice of the Delphic oracle where he was told that the plague would be lifted when the killer of Laius was named. Oedipus was the killer. He had gotten into a fight on the road years before and Laius was killed in the scuffle. Antimedes, Laius' servant and the only survivor of the fight was called by Oedipus to help find the killer. As soon as he saw Oedipus the truth came out about his real parents, his being abandoned by Jocasta and Laius and the fact that the prophecies had all come true, he had killed his father and slept with his mother. Jocasta ran away in anguish and hanged herself.

target.name: Creon
target.notes: King of Thebes, ruling after King Laius was murdered by Oedipus, unbeknownst to him at the time, Laius was Oedipus' father. He abdicated the throne for Oedipus when he married Queen Jocasta, his mother. At the time of his reign, Thebes was being hounded by a viscious fox that couldn't be caught, the Cadmean Vixen. Creon begged Cephalus to let him use his hunting dog Lailaps to hunt the fox down.

target.name: Laius

He married Jocasta but found he was unable to father a child. He visited the Delphic oracle for advice who warned him that, "The son of Laius and Jocasta shall kill his father". He decided it best to abstain from the marriage bed until one day he got drunk and Jocasta became pregnant. He had the child imprisoned on the top of Mount Cithaeron.

target.name: Acrisius

In sheer terror he locked up his daughter in a sealed bronze chamber but Zeus, who had his eye on Danaë, transformed into a shower of golden rain to get through the chamber and impregnate her.

source.name: Erigone
source.notes: Dionysus disguised himself as a cluster of grapes to win her love.

target.name: Dionysus
target.notes: Produced the world's first vintage from his lover and friend Ampelos (vine in Greek). Replaced Hestia in the quorum of twelve Olympians after she retired. The Gods were happy to have Dionysus for his wine and debauchery, all except Hera, as Dionysus was the result of Zeus's affair with Semele. Hera swore never to drink from Dionysus's cup and would later curse his son Priapus with ugliness and impotence.

source.name: Alcathoë
source.notes: Transformed into a bat when daring to prefer a contemplative life to one of Dionysian revelry.

source.name: Scylla
source.notes: Princess Scylla, daughter of King Nisus. She fell in love with King of Minos of Crete when he invaded their kingdom. So in love, she stole her father's lock of purple hair which had granted him invincibility to give to Minos. Her father, now mortal, was then killed in a palace uprising. Minos was far from pleased by her disloyalty and vowed to have nothing to do with her.  She couldn't give up and tried to swim after him, crying so much that she was turned into a gull. To the amusement of the gods her deceased father was turned into a sea-eagle and he has harried his daughter ever since.

target.name: Nisus
target.notes: King of Megara in Attica, he had been granted invincibility in the form of a single lock of purple hair. His kingdom was attacked by King Minos of Crete. Nisus's daughter, Princess Scylla, fell in love with Minos and stole the lock of hair to give to Minos. Nisus became mortal at once and was later killed in a palace uprising.

source.name: Scylla

To the amusement of the gods her deceased father was turned into a sea-eagle and he has harried his daughter ever since.

target.name: Aphrodite
target.god_of: God of Love, Beauty, Pleasure & Procreation
target.notes: Child of Ouranos' genitals as they "impregnated" the sea when discarded by Kronos. Hence the image of Aphrodite emerging from the sea on a scallop (Botticelli). Kept safe by Zeus in the Titan War.

source.name: Charybdis
source.notes: A sea-monster whose gigantic whirlpool swirled in the straits of Messina opposite the cliffs of the monster Scylla to form an almost impassable barrier to sailors between Sicily and the Italian mainland.

source.name: Callisto
source.notes: Raised as a nymph dedicated to the virgin huntress Artemis. Zeus so wanted her that he transformed his image into the exact one of Artemis herself and coupled with her. Artemis, disgusted with her impurity, discarded her from the group. She gave birth to a son, Arcas. In a double punishment Hera, never one to idly sit by and watch Zeus's dalliances, transformed Callisto into a bear. Some years later, Arcas almost killed Callisto when out hunting but was prevented from doing so by Zeus. He sent them both to the heavens as Ursa Major and Ursa Minor, the constellations Great Bear and Little Bear. Hera, still angry, deemed that they shall never share the same part of the sky, hence their permanently opposing positions.

target.name: Lycaon
target.notes: One of the first human rulers, Lycaon, King of Arcadia was son of the Pelsagos who had been one of the original clay figures formed by Prometheus. He killed his own son Nyctimus as an offering to the gods. Zeus was so revolted he brought the boy back to life and turned Lycaon into a wolf. However, Nyctimus's brothers ravaged the land so Zeus brought about massive floods to drown the whole of Greece and the Mediterranean, all, save Deucalion and Pyrrha, who thanks to Prometheus's foresight, survived aboard a wooden chest.

source.name: Arcas
source.notes: Son of Zeus and Callisto, his mother was transformed into a bear by Hera angry at yet another one of Zeus's affairs. He would later almost commit an act of unknowing matricide whilst out hunting, but Zeus prevented it and sent him and his mother up to the heavens as the constellations Great Bear and Little Bear (Ursa Major and Minor). Hera, still angry, deemed that they shall never share the same part of the sky, hence their permanently opposing positions.

source.name: Procne
source.notes: Wife of Tereus, King of Thrace who raped her sister Philomela and cut out her tongue to prevent her speaking of it. Philomela managed to show Procne what had happened in the form of a tapestry. Filled with a unquenching thirst for revenge, she murdered her own son, Ictys, the only person that Tereus loved. Ictys was served to Tereus as a stew which he lapped up. After he'd realised what had happened he gave chase but Procne was transformed into a swallow by the gods so she could make her escape.

source.name: Philomela
source.notes: She was raped by her sister's (Procne) husband, the evil King Tereus of Thrace. She then had her tongue ripped out so she couldn't tell her sister. She managed to depic the horrific event in a tapestry and showed her sister. They sought revenge by murdering the only thing Tereus loved, his son Ictys. They served Ictys in a stew which Tereus ate. When he found out he gave chase but Philomela was transformed into a nightingale by the gods so she could escape. Female nightingales to this day, remain mute.

source.name: Tereus
source.notes: King of Thrace, he was a despicable man who raped his wife's (Procne) sister, Philomela. Terrified that she would tell her sister, he tore out her tongue. Philomela managed to depict the horrific event in a tapestry and when her sister saw it they plotted revenge. They knew the only thing  Tereus would miss was his son, Ictys. Overwhelmed with revenge they murdered him and served him to Tereus at a banquet. Tereus found out, but not after eating most of his son and whilst chasing the sisters was transformed into a hoopoe bird, his yells of pain sounding like forlorn whoops.

source.name: Cephalus
source.notes: A fine, heroic youth, he caught the attention of Eos, the goddess of dawn, who abducted him. Cephalus was deeply unhappy, missing his wife Procris dreadfully. Eos decided to return him to his wife but was full of resentment, "how could a mere mortal be more irresistible than I?" She sowed seeds of doubt in Cephalus's mind as to his wife's faithfulness, convincing him to test her by appearing in disguise to see what she would do. When his wife finally submitted to this "stranger's" advances, Cephalus threw off his disguise and confronted her. Procris ran off to the woods in despair where she would be comforted by Artemis. Procris would eventually return to Cephalus with Artemis's blessing. In a tragic ending, Procris overheard him calling out to Zephyrus, the west wind. Mistaking his lascivious words for adultery, she shrieked in anguish and started Cephalus who reached for his hunting spear (a gift from Artemis to his wife that never missed its mark) and killed her.

target.name: Eos
target.notes: Goddess of dawn, she opened the gates to let the sun chariot out each morning. Had a disastrous affair with Ares, the god of war. Aphrodite, Ares' jealous lover, found out and cursed Eos never to find love.

source.name: Procris
source.notes: Wife of Cephalus who was abducted by Eos. Cephalus missed her so much that Eos agreed to return him to her. But, full of resentment, she tricked Cephalus into testing his wife's faithfulness. Cephalus was conned into wearing a disguise when he returned to her, and she eventually gave in to this "stranger's" overtures. Distraught when Cephalus removed his disguise she ran away to the woods. There she was comforted by Artemis who taught her the pleasures of shunning men, but eventually she admitted that she had to return to her beloved Cephalus. Artemis gave her blessing and bestowed upon her a gift of a remarkable hunting dog called Lailaps and a hunting spear that never missed its mark. Later in life she mistakingly overheard her husband's lascivious comments (he was talking to Zephyrus, the west wind, merely wanting to feel the wind on his skin), she mistook it as adultery and let out a shriek. Startled, Cephalus threw the hunting spear and killed her.

target.name: Erechtheus
target.notes: Hephaestus, after helping to bring Athena into the world by splitting open Zeus's head, became infatuated with her. One day, unable to control himself he tried to force himself on her, managing in his excitement to spill his seed on her. Athena removed her headband, wiped up the mess and threw it down the mountain. This landed on the ground and made Gaia pregnant, from which Erechtheus was born. Athena deemed that he should be immortal and he would grow up to be the legendary founder of Athens, Erechthonius.

But, full of resentment, she tricked Cephalus into testing his wife's faithfulness. Cephalus was conned into wearing a disguise when he returned to her, and she eventually gave in to this "stranger's" overtures. Distraught when Cephalus removed his disguise she ran away to the woods. There she was comforted by Artemis who taught her the pleasures of shunning men, but eventually she admitted that she had to return to her beloved Cephalus. Artemis gave her blessing and bestowed upon her a gift of a remarkable hunting dog called Lailaps and a hunting spear that never missed its mark. Later in life she mistakingly overheard her husband's lascivious comments (he was talking to Zephyrus, the west wind, merely wanting to feel the wind on his skin), she mistook it as adultery and let out a shriek. Startled, Cephalus threw the hunting spear and killed her.

source.name: Lailaps
source.notes: Lailaps, a dog, was a gift from Artemis to Procris. A remarkable dog, it could catch anything that it pursued. It was loaned to Creon, King of Thebes, to hunt down a ferocious fox that was terrorising his kingdom. The fox, Alopex Teumesios (Cadmean Vixen) was divined never to be captured. What happens when the proverbial irresistible force meets immovable object? They were locked in an endless loop of chase and evade. Zeus, perplexed by this paradox, turned them to stone and brought them up to the heavens where they can be seen today as the constellations Canis Major and Canis Minor (Greater and Lesser Dogs).

source.name: Creon
source.notes: King of Thebes, ruling after King Laius was murdered by Oedipus, unbeknownst to him at the time, Laius was Oedipus' father. He abdicated the throne for Oedipus when he married Queen Jocasta, his mother. At the time of his reign, Thebes was being hounded by a viscious fox that couldn't be caught, the Cadmean Vixen. Creon begged Cephalus to let him use his hunting dog Lailaps to hunt the fox down.

target.name: Oedipus
target.notes: His father, Laius, had received a prophecy that his son would kill him, so he had him imprisoned on the top of Mount Cithaeron as a baby. He was rescued and taken to Corinth where he was raised by the King and Queen, Polybus and Merope. They named him Oedipus which means 'swollen foot' after the scars on his once shackled ankles. During his life he heard rumours that he was adopted so he consulted with the Delphic oracle. Instead of being told who his real parents were, in typical oracular cryptic fashion he was told, "Oedipus will kill his father and mate with his mother". He decided to leave Corinth to avoid the possibility of the prophecy coming true. Whilst on the road he got into a fight with a man in a chariot who had hurled abuse at him to get out of the way, Oedipus killed him and his entourage during the ensuing fight. He ended up making his way toward Thebes, he answered one of the Sphinx's riddles on the way to reopen the road and lift the curse. He was welcomed into the city as a hero and welcomed by Queen Jocasta, unbeknownst to Oedipus, this was his real mother. She told him that her husband had been killed on the road by a gang of robbers, this was the very same fight that Oedipus had gotten into, part of the prophecy had come true. In time he fell in love with Jocasta. He became King and they married and had four children, thus completing the prophecy. Later in his reign he again sought the advice of the Delphic oracle about a vicious plague that had swept through the kingdom. The Pythia answered, "Thebes will be relieved when the murderer of King Laius is named and found." Oedipus sent for Laius' servant, Antimedes, who was the sole survivor of the fight that fateful day. As soon as Antimedes set eyes on Oedipus the whole horrendous truth came out. Oedipus discovered his true parents, his being abandoned by his mother and now wife, Jocasta, and the fact that the horrible prophecies had all come true. Jocasta ran away and hanged herself in the bedroom. Oedipus found her and thrust her gold brooch dress pins into his eyes in anguish.

source.name: Creon
source.notes: King of Thebes, ruling after King Laius was murdered by Oedipus, unbeknownst to him at the time, Laius was Oedipus' father. He abdicated the throne for Oedipus when he married Queen Jocasta, his mother. At the time of his reign, Thebes was being hounded by a viscious fox that couldn't be caught, the Cadmean Vixen. Creon begged Cephalus to let him use his hunting dog Lailaps to hunt the fox down.

target.name: Cephalus
target.notes: A fine, heroic youth, he caught the attention of Eos, the goddess of dawn, who abducted him. Cephalus was deeply unhappy, missing his wife Procris dreadfully. Eos decided to return him to his wife but was full of resentment, "how could a mere mortal be more irresistible than I?" She sowed seeds of doubt in Cephalus's mind as to his wife's faithfulness, convincing him to test her by appearing in disguise to see what she would do. When his wife finally submitted to this "stranger's" advances, Cephalus threw off his disguise and confronted her. Procris ran off to the woods in despair where she would be comforted by Artemis. Procris would eventually return to Cephalus with Artemis's blessing. In a tragic ending, Procris overheard him calling out to Zephyrus, the west wind. Mistaking his lascivious words for adultery, she shrieked in anguish and started Cephalus who reached for his hunting spear (a gift from Artemis to his wife that never missed its mark) and killed her.

source.name: Alopex Teumesios
source.notes: The Cadmean Vixen. This ruthless fox was the scourge of Thebes. The King, Creon, begged Cephalus for his marvellous hunting dog Lailaps to give chase to the fox. In the ensuing paradoxical chase, the fox, divined never to be caught, couldn't be captured by the dog, divined to catch everything it hunted. Round and round they went in an endless loop until Zeus, perplexed by this paradox, decided to turn them to stone, immortalising their endless chase for eternity. He brought them up to the heavens where they are to this day, the constellations Canis Major and Canis Minor, Greater and Lesser Dogs.

target.name: Lailaps
target.notes: Lailaps, a dog, was a gift from Artemis to Procris. A remarkable dog, it could catch anything that it pursued. It was loaned to Creon, King of Thebes, to hunt down a ferocious fox that was terrorising his kingdom. The fox, Alopex Teumesios (Cadmean Vixen) was divined never to be captured. What happens when the proverbial irresistible force meets immovable object? They were locked in an endless loop of chase and evade. Zeus, perplexed by this paradox, turned them to stone and brought them up to the heavens where they can be seen today as the constellations Canis Major and Canis Minor (Greater and Lesser Dogs).

source.name: Endymion
source.notes: This young, handsome shepherd caught the eye of Selene, the moon goddess. The sight of him was so beautiful that she cried out to Zeus, Endymion's father, that he should never change and she wanted to see him like that every night. Zeus granted the wish and Endymion stayed just where he was. Each new moon, Selene would come down and make love to him. This story forms the subject of Keats's poem, Endymion.

target.name: Zeus
target.god_of: King of the Gods, god of sky, weather & fate
target.notes: Rhea tricked Kronos into eating a piece of magnetite and escaped to Crete to have Zeus. She vowed that he'd take revenge on Kronos. He gives Kronos poison where he regurgitates all 5 children that he ate

target.name: Selene
target.notes: Titan god of the moon. She rode the moon chariot every night with her lunar crescent adorning her head.

source.name: Cleitus
source.notes: Another one of Eos's conquests, he died in a short time which caused Eos a lot of heartache. Unbeknownst to her, it was the curse of Aphrodite in full swing.

target.name: Eos
target.notes: Goddess of dawn, she opened the gates to let the sun chariot out each morning. Had a disastrous affair with Ares, the god of war. Aphrodite, Ares' jealous lover, found out and cursed Eos never to find love.

source.name: Laomedon
source.notes: Nephew of Zeus's beloved cupbearer Ganymede and King of Troy. He angered Heracles when he refused payment for one of his labours. Heracles sought revenge and killed him, sacking the city in the process.

target.name: Ilos
target.notes: King of Troy.

source.name: Laomedon
source.notes: Nephew of Zeus's beloved cupbearer Ganymede and King of Troy. He angered Heracles when he refused payment for one of his labours. Heracles sought revenge and killed him, sacking the city in the process.

target.name: Heracles
target.notes: Born Alcides, son of Zeus and Alcmene. Zeus had wanted a child in the blood line of Perseus as Hera had prophecised that a child of Perseus would save the Olympians. Hera was so incensed at yet another affair of Zeus that she swore eternal enmity against Alcides. Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

source.name: Tithonus
source.notes: Lover of Eos, goddess of dawn. Eos, who unbeknownst to her had been cursed in love by Aphrodite for an affair with Ares, Aphrodite's lover, was forever unlucky in love. Determined for it not to happen again, she begged Zeus for Tithonus's immortality. He grinned, the curse of Aphrodite was at work, and granted the request. Later on, Eos, playfully stroking Tithonus's head, noticed a grey hair. Back she went to Zeus demanding an explanation. "You only asked for immortality, you said nothing about ageing", replied Zeus. Distraught, Eos had to watch her beloved Tithonus live on in extreme old age, unable to die. His wrinkled and shrivelled form was finally transformed by Eos, unable to bear it any more, into a grasshopper. Eos watched him skip away into the grass and somewhere Aphrodite let out a cruel laugh. A parable on being careful what you wish for,

source.name: Emathion
source.notes: Son of Eos, goddess of dawn, and Tithonus. Would go on to rule Arabia.

source.name: Hyacinthus
source.notes: A beautiful Spartan prince, Hyacinthus was courted by two divinities, Zephyrus, the west wind, and Apollo. Hyacinthus rebuffed Zephyrus' charms much preferring Apollo. One day Apollo and Hyacinthus were participating in athletic events and Zephyrus, in a fit of jealous rage, blew Apollo's discus off course and struck Hyacinthus in the head, killing him. In tears of grief, Apollo mixed the blood that gushed from his beloved's head with his own tears. The resulting liquid seeped into the soil below and from it bloomed a magnificent flower, a flower that bears Hyacinth's name to this day.

target.name: Apollo
target.god_of: God of Mathematics, reason, logic, poetry, medicine, knowledge, prophecy, archery & music
target.notes: He kills a Python sent by Hera to eat him and his sister. The Python came from the landing site of the magnetite stone that Kronos ate thinking it was the infant Zeus. As the Python was born of Gaia and under divine protection he had to be punished by Zeus. He was exiled for eight years to the snake's birthplace beneath Mount Parnassus to replace the snake as guardian of the Omphalos (the spiritual centre of Greece, whose name he would change to Delphi and establish an oracle where anyone could come to ask the god or his appointed priestess, known as a Sibyl or Pythia, questions about the future) and to atone for his crime. Here he would go on to organise The Pythian Games every four years. Apollo was gifted music by Hermes (a tortoise shell with cow guts as strings, the first lyre) as a show of repentence after he stole Apollo's cattle.

The resulting liquid seeped into the soil below and from it bloomed a magnificent flower, a flower that bears Hyacinth's name to this day.

target.name: Zephyrus
target.notes: Transported Psyche to Eros.

source.name: Crocus
source.notes: Pined for the nymph Smilax without success. Out of pity was turned into the saffron flower that bears his name, whilst Smilax became a brambly vine that bears her name.

target.name: Hermes
target.god_of: God of Messengers, thievery, medicine, herds & trade
target.notes: This infant prodigy gives his name to anything "mercurial". Would become "chief conductor of souls" for the most important human spirits.

source.name: Smilax
source.notes: Pined for, without success, by Crocus. Out of pity Crocus was turned into the saffron flower that bears his name, whilst Smilax became a brambly vine that bears her name.

target.name: Dionysus
target.notes: Produced the world's first vintage from his lover and friend Ampelos (vine in Greek). Replaced Hestia in the quorum of twelve Olympians after she retired. The Gods were happy to have Dionysus for his wine and debauchery, all except Hera, as Dionysus was the result of Zeus's affair with Semele. Hera swore never to drink from Dionysus's cup and would later curse his son Priapus with ugliness and impotence.

source.name: Smilax
source.notes: Pined for, without success, by Crocus. Out of pity Crocus was turned into the saffron flower that bears his name, whilst Smilax became a brambly vine that bears her name.

target.name: Crocus

source.name: Cenchreis
source.notes: nan

target.name: Theias
target.notes: King of Cyprus. Aphrodite, to which Cyprus was sacred, became angry with him for neglecting to make offerings to her. She cursed his daughter, Smyrna, with incestuous lust. One night when drunk, Smyrna's maid, Hippolyte, who was under a spell cast by Aphrodite, delivered Smyrna to her father's bed. Unknowingly he committed incest. The result of which was Adonis.

source.name: Smyrna
source.notes: Cursed with lustful feelings for her father Theias, King of Cyprus, by Aphrodite who was unhappy with his neglect of her sacred birth place. She was eventually lured into her father's bed by Hippolyte, her maid, who was under a spell cast by Aphrodite. Her drunken father had no idea it was his daughter, but she, so distraught with what had happened begged the gods to put an end to this misery. She was transformed into a weeping myrrh tree. After ten months, the tree burst open and out came a baby boy, Adonis.

source.name: Hippolyte

target.name: Smyrna

After ten months, the tree burst open and out came a baby boy, Adonis.

source.name: Adonis
source.notes: The result of incestuous love between Theias, King of Cyprus, and his daughter Smyrna. He attracted the attention of Aphrodite, who had caused his birth in the first place by cursing his mother with incestuous thoughts due to Theias's neglect of her sacred birth place of Cyprus. He was killed by a wild boar, some say this was a jealous Ares in disguise. A distraught Aphrodite vowed from then on that love would be forever tinged with tragedy as she prophesised whilst holding a dying Adonis in her arms, "Sorrow on love hereafter shall attend..., It shall be cause of war and dire events, And set dissension 'twixt the son and sire..., They that love best their loves shall not enjoy."

target.name: Aphrodite
target.god_of: God of Love, Beauty, Pleasure & Procreation
target.notes: Child of Ouranos' genitals as they "impregnated" the sea when discarded by Kronos. Hence the image of Aphrodite emerging from the sea on a scallop (Botticelli). Kept safe by Zeus in the Titan War.

source.name: Cassandra
source.notes: A Trojan prophetess (select mortals were also blessed with the gift of prophecy). Although gifted with entirely accurate prophecies, they were tempered by the fact that they would always be entirely unbelieved by the recipient.

Apollo was gifted music by Hermes (a tortoise shell with cow guts as strings, the first lyre) as a show of repentence after he stole Apollo's cattle.

source.name: Tiresias
source.notes: Born male, he was turned into a female by Hera as a punishment for striking two mating snakes with a stick. She was then brought up to Olympus to arbitrate a wager between Zeus and Hera as to who enjoyed sex the most, males or females. Having experience of both she was best placed to answer this question. She answered that it was females who enjoyed sex more. This enraged Hera who wanted to prove it was men who enjoyed it more, probably due to Zeus's unconquerable libido. For this heinous crime Hera struck Tiresias blind. Having sympathy, Zeus awarded him the gift of second sight, prophecy.

target.name: Hera
target.god_of: Queen of the Gods, god of Marriage, Women, the Sky & Stars of Heaven
target.notes: Swallowed by Kronos when born due to Ouranos' curse on him that "Your own children will overthrow you as you overthrew me". Married to Zeus.

target.name: Oceanus
target.notes: God of the earth-encircling River Oceanus, the source of all of the earth's fresh water.

source.name: Cephissus
source.notes: nan

target.name: Tethys
target.notes: Goddess of the sea.

source.name: Narcissus
source.notes: Blessed with stunning beauty, his mother, the nymph Liriope, was concerned. Stunning beauty made him a target of the gods so she consulted with the prophet Tiresias who told them that "as long as Narcissus doesn't recognise himself, he will live a long and happy life". He grew to hate the concept of love, believing it to render its subjects stupid and helpless. One day whilst near a lake he was approached by Echo, a nymph cursed by Hera to be only able to repeat words spoken to her. Annoyed at her advances he chased her away. He looked into the lake and noticed his reflection. He fell deeply in love but every time he approached the reflection to kiss it, it would disappear into a thousand ripples. This curse of longing for one's self and how one appears in other's eyes gives us the modern day mental condition, narcissism.

source.name: Echo
source.notes: Echo, blessed with the gift of talking and a beatiful, mellifluous voice, lied to Hera to protect Zeus who was having an affair with a nymph nearby. When Hera found out she cursed Echo's gift of talking. From then on she could only repeat what people said to her. One day she stumbled upon Narcissus and fell instantly in love with him. Unable to do anything but repeat his words, she angered him and was chased away. Aphrodite took pity on her and relieved her of her human form that was bound in pain of unrequited love, which just left her voice behind which can still be heard in empty rooms and caves to this day.

target.name: Aphrodite
target.god_of: God of Love, Beauty, Pleasure & Procreation
target.notes: Child of Ouranos' genitals as they "impregnated" the sea when discarded by Kronos. Hence the image of Aphrodite emerging from the sea on a scallop (Botticelli). Kept safe by Zeus in the Titan War.

source.name: Echo
source.notes: Echo, blessed with the gift of talking and a beatiful, mellifluous voice, lied to Hera to protect Zeus who was having an affair with a nymph nearby. When Hera found out she cursed Echo's gift of talking. From then on she could only repeat what people said to her. One day she stumbled upon Narcissus and fell instantly in love with him. Unable to do anything but repeat his words, she angered him and was chased away. Aphrodite took pity on her and relieved her of her human form that was bound in pain of unrequited love, which just left her voice behind which can still be heard in empty rooms and caves to this day.

target.name: Hera
target.god_of: Queen of the Gods, god of Marriage, Women, the Sky & Stars of Heaven
target.notes: Swallowed by Kronos when born due to Ouranos' curse on him that "Your own children will overthrow you as you overthrew me". Married to Zeus.

source.name: Echo
source.notes: Echo, blessed with the gift of talking and a beatiful, mellifluous voice, lied to Hera to protect Zeus who was having an affair with a nymph nearby. When Hera found out she cursed Echo's gift of talking. From then on she could only repeat what people said to her. One day she stumbled upon Narcissus and fell instantly in love with him. target.name: Narcissus
target.notes: Blessed with stunning beauty, his mother, the nymph Liriope, was concerned. Stunning beauty made him a target of the gods so she consulted with the prophet Tiresias who told them that "as long as Narcissus doesn't recognise himself, he will live a long and happy life". He grew to hate the concept of love, believing it to render its subjects stupid and helpless. One day whilst near a lake he was approached by Echo, a nymph cursed by Hera to be only able to repeat words spoken to her. Annoyed at her advances he chased her away. He looked into the lake and noticed his reflection. He fell deeply in love but every time he approached the reflection to kiss it, it would disappear into a thousand ripples. This curse of longing for one's self and how one appears in other's eyes gives us the modern day mental condition, narcissism.

source.name: Ameinias
source.notes: Fell in love with Narcissus, but the love was sadly not reciprocated. He hung himself from a tree outside Narcissus's house.

source.name: Pyramus
source.notes: Fell in love with Thisbe, who was daughter of his family's hated rivals in Babylon. They maintained a secret liason until one day they decided to elope together away from their warring families. At the rendezvous point, Thisbe encountered a lion and ran away. When Pyramus arrived he saw Thisbe's veil on the ground, lion paw prints, and blood from the lion's meal earlier that day. Fearing that his beloved Thisbe had been eaten, he fell on his own sword in despair. When Thisbe returned she puts the tragic pieces of the puzzle before her back together. Condenming the gods for not allowing them to be together, she takes Pyramus's sword and kills herself. The grief of both families ending up uniting them in peace.

source.name: Leucippos
source.notes: Born a girl, her father only wanted boys, and told her mother, Galatea, that if she gave birth to a girl she should kill it. Galatea hid the truth from Lampros until she reached the age when it would start to show. She took Leucippos to the temple of Leto, where she prayed that her daughter might change sex. Leto answered and Leucippos was transformed into a man.

target.name: Leto
target.notes: Cursed by Hera, who asked Gaia to not let her give birth on any land as Zeus had cheated on her, she made her way, thanks to Poseidon, to Delos, a floating island in the Cyclades where she would give birth to twins Artemis and Apollo.

source.name: Oenomaus
source.notes: King of Pisa in the Peloponnese. It was prophecised that he would be killed by a son-in-law. Being the greatest charioteer in the land, he challenged any would be suitor of his daughter, Hippodamia, to a race, if they lost, they paid with their life.

target.name: Ares
target.notes: He and Aphrodite would form a couple (Venus and Mars, love and war).

source.name: Leucippos
source.notes: Another Leucippos of sex changing fame, this one had the temerity to fall in love with the naiad Daphne, who was courted by Apollo. Leucippos disguised himself as a girl to gain entry to the retinue of nymphs. The nymphs discovered his secret and speared him to death.

source.name: Daphne
source.notes: Pursued by Leucippos, who tried to slip into her group of nymphs disguised as a girl to get near her, was discovered and speared to death. Apollo had his eye on her during this time. He materialised in front of Daphne who ran away. He gave chase but Daphne sent up a prayer to her mother Gaia and her father, the river god Ladon, to help. They transformed her into a laurel tree. Apollo was chastened, and the laurel would become sacred to him. Victors at the Pythian Games would be awarded a laurel wreath, and the winner of a great prize is still called a laureate to this day.

target.name: Apollo
target.god_of: God of Mathematics, reason, logic, poetry, medicine, knowledge, prophecy, archery & music
target.notes: He kills a Python sent by Hera to eat him and his sister. The Python came from the landing site of the magnetite stone that Kronos ate thinking it was the infant Zeus. As the Python was born of Gaia and under divine protection he had to be punished by Zeus. He was exiled for eight years to the snake's birthplace beneath Mount Parnassus to replace the snake as guardian of the Omphalos (the spiritual centre of Greece, whose name he would change to Delphi and establish an oracle where anyone could come to ask the god or his appointed priestess, known as a Sibyl or Pythia, questions about the future) and to atone for his crime. Here he would go on to organise The Pythian Games every four years. Apollo was gifted music by Hermes (a tortoise shell with cow guts as strings, the first lyre) as a show of repentence after he stole Apollo's cattle.

source.name: Pygmalion
source.notes: Pygmalion of Cyprus became so disgusted with the lack of modesty and chastity on the island that he vowed never to fall under its spell. This angered Aphrodite. One day whilst sculpting what he thought was a male body, he took a step back and noticed that he had in fact carved the most beautiful woman he had ever seen. He named her Galatea. Aphrodite then cursed him to fall in love with the statue. She eventually agreed to Pygmalion's prayers that Galatea should be transformed into an actual human. They lived happily ever after.

target.name: Echidna
target.notes: A monstrous she-dragon with the head and breast of a woman and the tail of a serpent. She represents the corruptions of the earth, rot, slime, fetid water, illness and disease.

target.name: Heracles
target.notes: Born Alcides, son of Zeus and Alcmene. Zeus had wanted a child in the blood line of Perseus as Hera had prophecised that a child of Perseus would save the Olympians. Hera was so incensed at yet another affair of Zeus that she swore eternal enmity against Alcides. Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

source.name: Daphnis
source.notes: Lover of both Hermes and Pan, Pan taught him to play the pipes. He became so proficient that he was credited with being the founder of pastoral poetry.

source.name: Hero
source.notes: Lover of Leander, they lived on each side of the Dardanelles, or Hellespont as it was called back then. Hero would light a lamp in her window which would guide Leander to her as he swam across the strait. One day the winds blew out the lamp, Leander couldn't find his way and drowned. Hero awoke to see him dead on the rocks below and she dashed herself on the same rocks in despair.

source.name: Arion
source.notes: Son of Poseidon and the nymph Oncaea, he devoted his life to music becoming the greatest musician in the land. His patron, Periander, King of Corinth, sent him to Italy for a music competition which he won easily. He was sailing back with his prize money when the crew of the ship stole his treasure and were just about to kill him when he begged them to play one last song. This final song was an offering to his father Poseidon. He then jumped overboard and was rescued from drowning by a dolphin. Returning to Corinth, Arion ordered that the dolphin be taken care of. Sadly it was left out in the sun too long and died. Periander ordered a high tower to be built to commemorate the dolphin. One day later, the ship that Arion had escaped from was blown into Corinth by a storm. Periander asked them where the treasure was. The crew lied saying that it was lost overboard along with their dear friend Arion. As soon as they told this lie Arion emerged from the dolphin's tower and Periander ordered them all to be executed. After his death Apollo, to whom dolphins were sacred, set Arion and his rescue dolphin amongst the stars between Sagittarius and Aquarius, the Dolphin constellation which aided navigators for years later.
