source.name: Periander
source.notes: King of Corinth, he was also patron of the greatest musician in the land, Arion.

target.name: Arion
target.notes: Son of Poseidon and the nymph Oncaea, he devoted his life to music becoming the greatest musician in the land. His patron, Periander, King of Corinth, sent him to Italy for a music competition which he won easily. He was sailing back with his prize money when the crew of the ship stole his treasure and were just about to kill him when he begged them to play one last song. This final song was an offering to his father Poseidon. He then jumped overboard and was rescued from drowning by a dolphin. Returning to Corinth, Arion ordered that the dolphin be taken care of. Sadly it was left out in the sun too long and died. Periander ordered a high tower to be built to commemorate the dolphin. One day later, the ship that Arion had escaped from was blown into Corinth by a storm. Periander asked them where the treasure was. The crew lied saying that it was lost overboard along with their dear friend Arion. As soon as they told this lie Arion emerged from the dolphin's tower and Periander ordered them all to be executed. After his death Apollo, to whom dolphins were sacred, set Arion and his rescue dolphin amongst the stars between Sagittarius and Aquarius, the Dolphin constellation which aided navigators for years later.

source.name: Philemon
source.notes: He and his wife Baucis passed Hermes' and Zeus' test of hospitality. The only set of people in their village to do so. Zeus ordered them to the top of the hill overlooking the town where he transformed them into oak and linden trees to spend the rest of eternity together. The rest of the town perished in a great flood.

source.name: Midas
source.notes: Son of Gordias, he took over his father's throne as King of Phrygia upon his death. One day he encountered Silenus, Dionysus's sidekick, in a drunken revelry. He showed him much hospitality which was rewarded by Dionysus with any wish he wanted. Having a rush of blood to the head perhaps, and because his kingdom was struggling for money, he wished for anything that he touched be turned to gold. His wish was granted but he quickly realised this was indeed, a curse. Even his wife and daughter were transformed, he couldn't touch anything. Pleading with Dionysus, who told him he was lucky that Silenus was so fond of him, made it so that anything he washed in the nearby river would be transformed back again. A relieved Midas quickly restored his wife and daughter back to human form. He then devoted his life to a more bucolic existence becoming a follower of Pan, the god of nature. One day when Pan and Apollo were playing music, Midas had the temerity to say that Pan's playing was better than Apollo's. Luckily he caught Apollo in a good mood and his only punishment was to have his ear's transformed into those of an ass, becuase only the ears of an ass could not appreciate such music. From then on he wore a turban to keep his ears a secret, only his barber knew the truth. His barber, unable to keep it a secret any longer, buried the words, "Midas has the ears of an ass" in the ground. This would grow into a flower which released the words into the wild. When Midas heard them and was scorned by his subjects he drank poison and killed himself.

target.name: Gordias
target.notes: A poor man from Macedonia, Gordias luck turned when the nearby city of Phrygia, whose king had recently deceased, were trying to appoint a successor. An oracle told them that the next person to enter the city in a cart should be crowned King. This was Gordias. He rebuilt the city and named it Gordium in his honour. The cart became a holy relic. It was secured by the most intricate knot known to man, so determined was Gordias that it not be stolen. This is the famous Gordian Knot that lay undone for a thousand years until a young Macedonian entered the city and sliced the knot open with his sword. The young man's name, Alexander, who would earn the sobriquet "The Great" for his actions.

target.name: Silenus
target.notes: Fathered by Hermes and an unknown nymph, Silenus was a snub-nosed, donkey-tailed lecher who would grow up to become a bearded, pot-bellied old drunk. A popular subject in paintings and sculptures.

source.name: Enceladus
source.notes: One of the giants who fought the Olympians during the Gigantomachy. Enceladus was the most powerful of all the giants. He was killed by Athena and buried under Mount Etna where he grumbles to this day (Enceladus means 'the noisy one').

source.name: Enceladus
source.notes: One of the giants who fought the Olympians during the Gigantomachy. Enceladus was the most powerful of all the giants. He was killed by Athena and buried under Mount Etna where he grumbles to this day (Enceladus means 'the noisy one').

target.name: Athena
target.notes: Zeus would court Metis, transforming into various creatures to chase her. She hid in a deep cave but Zeus would transform into a snake and coil around her where she would become pregnant. Later she goaded him by transforming into a fly to escape, he transformed into a lizard and ate her (in a shocking Kronos eating his children repeat). Metis then worked inside his head crafting armour and weapons giving Zeus an almighty headache. Hephaestus and Prometheus conjured a plan to fix the pain. They forged an axe that split Zeus' head in two from which Athena emerged. (Zeus' head then healed itself). Athens is named after her after she gifted the city the world's first olive tree. Her signature appearance is with an owl on her shoulder, symbol of watchful wisdom, and the serpent coiled around her feet, symbol of guile, as shown by her father winning over her mother. Like Demeter, she would remain untouched by man. The Greek word for virgin, Parthenos, is often attached to her name, hence the Parthenon, her temple on the Acropolis.

source.name: Enceladus
source.notes: One of the giants who fought the Olympians during the Gigantomachy. Enceladus was the most powerful of all the giants. He was killed by Athena and buried under Mount Etna where he grumbles to this day (Enceladus means 'the noisy one').

target.name: Heracles
target.notes: Born Alcides, son of Zeus and Alcmene. Zeus had wanted a child in the blood line of Perseus as Hera had prophecised that a child of Perseus would save the Olympians. Hera was so incensed at yet another affair of Zeus that she swore eternal enmity against Alcides. Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

source.name: Polybotes
source.notes: One of the giants who fought the Olympians during the Gigantomachy. He was crushed under a section of the island of Kos that Poseidon broke off and thrust on top of him.

target.name: Heracles
target.notes: Born Alcides, son of Zeus and Alcmene. Zeus had wanted a child in the blood line of Perseus as Hera had prophecised that a child of Perseus would save the Olympians. Hera was so incensed at yet another affair of Zeus that she swore eternal enmity against Alcides. Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

target.name: Dionysus
target.notes: Produced the world's first vintage from his lover and friend Ampelos (vine in Greek). Replaced Hestia in the quorum of twelve Olympians after she retired. The Gods were happy to have Dionysus for his wine and debauchery, all except Hera, as Dionysus was the result of Zeus's affair with Semele. Hera swore never to drink from Dionysus's cup and would later curse his son Priapus with ugliness and impotence.

Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

target.name: Eos
target.notes: Goddess of dawn, she opened the gates to let the sun chariot out each morning. Had a disastrous affair with Ares, the god of war. Aphrodite, Ares' jealous lover, found out and cursed Eos never to find love.

source.name: Ismenian Dragon
source.notes: A giant serpent that guarded the sacred spring of Ares near Thebes. Cadmus killed it and to placate Ares, on instructions from Athena, sowed the dragon's teeth, which produced a crop of fully-grown, armed warriors called the Spartoi who would go on to become the ancestral lords of Thebes. Ares would have his revenge later, transforming Cadmus and his wife into serpents.

target.name: Ares
target.notes: He and Aphrodite would form a couple (Venus and Mars, love and war).

source.name: Nike
source.notes: Winged goddess of victory - victory in war and peaceful competition. Stood at Zeus' throne with her three siblings Kratos, Bia and Zelos after they came to Zeus' aide in the Titan war.

source.name: Perseus
source.notes: Son of Danaë and Zeus, and grandson of King Acrisius of Argos who was warned by the Delphic oracle that his grandson would kill him. Acrisius locked Danaë and the infant Perseus in a wooden chest and hurled into the sea to prevent the proclomation coming true. Was tricked by Polydectes into bringing him the head of Medusa so he could move in on his mother, Danaë. He would then go on a quest and become the prototypical Greek hero. With weapons provided by Athena and Hermes he defeated Medusa. He would go on to rescue Andromeda, and they would become lovers. He then took revenge on Polydectes by turning him to stone with Medusa's head. Later, whilst travelling mainland Greece with Andromeda, he took part in an athletics event. He threw the discus so far it struck someone in the crowd, when he went to comfort him he caught the man's dying breath, "I defeated the Oracle, it said I would be killed by my grandson". But the man was indeed Perseus' grandfather, the same man who had bundled Danae and Perseus into the sea in a wooden chest to prevent the prophecy becoming true. After appeasing the Gods for this accidental killing, Perseus and Andromeda would live happily ever after, they were brought up to the heavens as constellations.

target.name: Athena
target.notes: Zeus would court Metis, transforming into various creatures to chase her. She hid in a deep cave but Zeus would transform into a snake and coil around her where she would become pregnant. Later she goaded him by transforming into a fly to escape, he transformed into a lizard and ate her (in a shocking Kronos eating his children repeat). Metis then worked inside his head crafting armour and weapons giving Zeus an almighty headache. Hephaestus and Prometheus conjured a plan to fix the pain. They forged an axe that split Zeus' head in two from which Athena emerged. (Zeus' head then healed itself). Athens is named after her after she gifted the city the world's first olive tree. Her signature appearance is with an owl on her shoulder, symbol of watchful wisdom, and the serpent coiled around her feet, symbol of guile, as shown by her father winning over her mother. Like Demeter, she would remain untouched by man. The Greek word for virgin, Parthenos, is often attached to her name, hence the Parthenon, her temple on the Acropolis.

source.name: Polydectes
source.notes: King of Seriphos and brother of Dictys who adopted Perseus. Tricked Perseus into bringing him the head of Medusa just so he could move in on his mother, Danaë. When Danaë rebuffed his advances he had her along with Dictys executed, but Perseus returned just in time to save them, deploying his new favourite weapon of Medusa's head to turn him into stone.

target.name: Oenomaus

source.name: Pegasus
source.notes: Child of Poseidon and Medusa, was held in Medusa's womb when she was punished by Athena until Perseus beheaded her and Pegasus emerged as a shimmering white, winged horse. He first went to Mount Helicon where he struck his hoof on the ground and water bubbled up to become the famous Hippocrene, horse fountain. Ended up at Corinth where he was tamed by Bellerophon. He was always at Bellerophons' side during his many heroic feats until the day hubris got the better of Bellerophon and he flew up to Olympus believing he'd be welcomed due to his divine parentage. Instead Zeus punished his arrogance by striking him down onto the rocks below, and keeping Pegasus on Olympus to carry his thunderbolts.

source.notes: Chained to a rock by Poseidon because her mother, Cassiopeia had incurred his wrath by claiming that she was more beautiful than all of the Nereids and Oceanids in the world. Was saved by Perseus and they fell in love. Would be taken up to the heavens as a constellation as a reward for living a good life by Zeus.

target.name: Cepheus
target.notes: King of Ethiopia, father of Andromeda.

source.name: Andromeda
source.notes: Chained to a rock by Poseidon because her mother, Cassiopeia had incurred his wrath by claiming that she was more beautiful than all of the Nereids and Oceanids in the world. Was saved by Perseus and they fell in love. Would be taken up to the heavens as a constellation as a reward for living a good life by Zeus.

target.name: Cassiopeia
target.notes: Queen of Ethiopia, mother of Andromeda. She angered the sea god Poseidon by claiming Andromeda was more beautiful than all of the Nereids and Oceanids in the world.

source.name: Andromeda
source.notes: Chained to a rock by Poseidon because her mother, Cassiopeia had incurred his wrath by claiming that she was more beautiful than all of the Nereids and Oceanids in the world. Was saved by Perseus and they fell in love. Would be taken up to the heavens as a constellation as a reward for living a good life by Zeus.

target.name: Perseus
target.notes: Son of Danaë and Zeus, and grandson of King Acrisius of Argos who was warned by the Delphic oracle that his grandson would kill him. Acrisius locked Danaë and the infant Perseus in a wooden chest and hurled into the sea to prevent the proclomation coming true. Was tricked by Polydectes into bringing him the head of Medusa so he could move in on his mother, Danaë. He would then go on a quest and become the prototypical Greek hero. With weapons provided by Athena and Hermes he defeated Medusa. He would go on to rescue Andromeda, and they would become lovers. He then took revenge on Polydectes by turning him to stone with Medusa's head. Later, whilst travelling mainland Greece with Andromeda, he took part in an athletics event. He threw the discus so far it struck someone in the crowd, when he went to comfort him he caught the man's dying breath, "I defeated the Oracle, it said I would be killed by my grandson". But the man was indeed Perseus' grandfather, the same man who had bundled Danae and Perseus into the sea in a wooden chest to prevent the prophecy becoming true. After appeasing the Gods for this accidental killing, Perseus and Andromeda would live happily ever after, they were brought up to the heavens as constellations.

source.name: Cetus
source.notes: A sea dragon that was sent by Poseidon to ravage the shoreline of the kingdom of Cepheus and Cassiopeia for their blasphemous claims that their daughter Andromeda was more beautiful than all of the Nereids and Oceanids in the world. Perseus would kill the dragon and save Andromeda's life.

source.name: Phineus

target.name: Aegyptus
target.notes: Great-grandson of Epaphus, he would go on to rule Egypt for generations.

source.name: Nicippe
source.notes: Zeus had chosen Alcmene instead of Nicippe to bear his child to fulfill Hera's prophecy that someone from the line of Perseus would save the Olympians. Just before Alcmene was to give birth he exhorted that "the next child born of the house of Perseus will rule all Argolis". But unbeknownst to him, Hera had crafted a plan to get Nicippe to give birth first as revenge on Zeus' affair, Eurystheus was the result.

target.name: Pelops
target.notes: King of Pisa in the Peloponnese. Murdered by his father and offered to the gods during a feast. The gods were so angered they dispatched Tantalus to Tartarus for eternity and brought Pelops back to life, endowing him with a new shoulder made of ivory to replace the one that was mistakenly eaten. He took in Laius as a baby who was smuggled out of Thebes when his father, Labdacus was overthrown. Laius took Pelops' son, Chrysippus with him when he finally returned to Thebes to reclaim his throne. This wasn't a consensual relationship so Chrysippus took his own life. Pelops swore a curse on Laius and his line for ever.

target.name: Sthenelus
target.notes: nan

source.name: Alcmene
source.notes: Impregnated by Zeus as he wanted to guard against Hera's prophecy that someone from the line of Perseus would save the Olympians. He decided that who would be better than a descendant of Perseus and a son of his own? He disguised himself as Electryon, Alcmene's husband. Hera, angered at yet another dalliance, ordered her daughter Eileithyia, the goddess of childbirth to prevent the offspring being born. Alcemene got help from Galanthis and Historis who tricked Eileithyia into thinking the baby had been born. She was then able to give birth to twins, Alcides (later to become Heracles) and Iphicles, Alcides by Zeus, and Iphicles by Electryon.

target.notes: Swallowed by Kronos when born due to Ouranos' curse on him that "Your own children will overthrow you as you overthrew me". Married to Zeus.

source.name: Eileithyia

target.name: Zeus
target.god_of: King of the Gods, god of sky, weather & fate
target.notes: Rhea tricked Kronos into eating a piece of magnetite and escaped to Crete to have Zeus. She vowed that he'd take revenge on Kronos. He gives Kronos poison where he regurgitates all 5 children that he ate

source.name: Eurystheus
source.notes: Zeus had chosen Alcmene instead of Nicippe to bear his child to fulfill Hera's prophecy that someone from the line of Perseus would save the Olympians. Just before Alcmene was to give birth he exhorted that "the next child born of the house of Perseus will rule all Argolis". But unbeknownst to him, Hera had crafted a plan to get Nicippe to give birth first as revenge on Zeus' affair, Eurystheus was the result. He would take the throne as Zeus had inadvertenly promised, and in Hera's cruel twist of fate Heracles would be ordered to serve Eurystheus after he mistakenly killed his family. Eurystheus would send Heracles on his labours to atone for his sins.

target.name: Heracles
target.notes: Born Alcides, son of Zeus and Alcmene. Zeus had wanted a child in the blood line of Perseus as Hera had prophecised that a child of Perseus would save the Olympians. Hera was so incensed at yet another affair of Zeus that she swore eternal enmity against Alcides. Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

source.name: Galanthis
source.notes: Friend of Alcmene, came to her aid when Hera had cursed her not to give birth as it was Zeus' child. Tricked Eileithyia into releasing her lock on Alcmene's legs enabling her to finally give birth. Hera turned her into a weasel as punishment.

target.name: Alcmene
target.notes: Impregnated by Zeus as he wanted to guard against Hera's prophecy that someone from the line of Perseus would save the Olympians. He decided that who would be better than a descendant of Perseus and a son of his own? He disguised himself as Electryon, Alcmene's husband. Hera, angered at yet another dalliance, ordered her daughter Eileithyia, the goddess of childbirth to prevent the offspring being born. Alcemene got help from Galanthis and Historis who tricked Eileithyia into thinking the baby had been born. She was then able to give birth to twins, Alcides (later to become Heracles) and Iphicles, Alcides by Zeus, and Iphicles by Electryon.

source.name: Historis
source.notes: Friend of Alcmene, came to her aid when Hera had cursed her not to give birth as it was Zeus' child. Tricked Eileithyia into releasing her lock on Alcmene's legs enabling her to finally give birth.

target.name: Tiresias
target.notes: Born male, he was turned into a female by Hera as a punishment for striking two mating snakes with a stick. She was then brought up to Olympus to arbitrate a wager between Zeus and Hera as to who enjoyed sex the most, males or females. Having experience of both she was best placed to answer this question. She answered that it was females who enjoyed sex more. This enraged Hera who wanted to prove it was men who enjoyed it more, probably due to Zeus's unconquerable libido. For this heinous crime Hera struck Tiresias blind. Having sympathy, Zeus awarded him the gift of second sight, prophecy.

source.name: Historis
source.notes: Friend of Alcmene, came to her aid when Hera had cursed her not to give birth as it was Zeus' child. Tricked Eileithyia into releasing her lock on Alcmene's legs enabling her to finally give birth.

source.name: Linus
source.notes: Brother of Orpheus, he was also a fine musician and taught Heracles how to play the lyre. The arts were not Heracle's strength however and when Linus tried to discipline him, Heracles saw the red mist and threw Linus against the far side of the room killing him instantly.

target.name: Oeagrus
target.notes: Thracian King. Father or step-father of Orpheus.

source.name: Eumolpus
source.notes: Son of Autolycus, rascally son of Hermes, he took up Heracle's music tuition after Heracles killed his previous teacher, Linus, in a fit of rage.

target.name: Autolycus
target.notes: Neighbour of Sisyphus. He got caught stealing Sisyphus's cattle.

source.name: Kastor
source.notes: Twin of Polydeuces, he trained Heracles in the use of weaponry. Was also one of Jason's Argonauts.

target.name: Leda
target.notes: Zeus transformed into a swan to couple with her.

source.name: Kastor
source.notes: Twin of Polydeuces, he trained Heracles in the use of weaponry. Was also one of Jason's Argonauts.

target.name: Tyndareus
target.notes: Heracles ousted his brother Hippocoön and put Tyndareus, the rightful ruler of Sparta, on the throne. This would have devestating consequences as it would lead to the Trojan war.

source.name: Kastor
source.notes: Twin of Polydeuces, he trained Heracles in the use of weaponry. Was also one of Jason's Argonauts.

target.name: Jason
target.notes: Smuggled out of Iolcos when he was a baby due to Pelias and Neleus laying siege to the city believeing they were the rightful heirs to the throne and not his father, Aeson. He was brought up by his mother's (Alcimede) friend, the great centaur, Chiron. Met Bellerophon, who was seeking help from Chiron for Pegasus burned skin at the hands of Chimera. He filled his head with heroic feats which influenced Jason in his formative years. When his tutelage with Chiron was finished he ventured back to Iolcos. On the journey he lost a sandal helping an old lady (Hera in disguise) across a river. It was prophecised to Pelias to beware of a man arriving from the country with one sandal so when he arrived in Iolcos, Pelias knew immediately who he was. Pelias agreed to let him take the throne but lied to him, telling him the land was cursed and that the only way to lift the curse was to retrieve the Golden Fleece. He arranged a mighty ship, the Argo, and a great crew, the Argonauts, to sail to Colchis and retrieve the fleece. When the Argonauts arrived at Colchis, King Aeëtes demanded three tests of Jason before he could take it. To tame the fire breathing bulls, the Khalkotauroi, to sow some dragon's teeth from Cadmus and defeat the army that sprouts from the ground, and to kill the dragon that guards the fleece. He managed these feats thanks to his new lover, Medea, whom Hera had had Eros strike her with his cupid's arrow. They escaped with the fleece back to Pelias where they realised he was never going to give up the throne so Medea tricked his nine daughters into killing him, believing they were being taught a magic trick and would be brought back to life. They had to flee Iolcos after this blood killing and sought refuge in Corinth. Here Jason fell for the King's daughter, Creusa. Medea, so enraged at this betrayal after everything she had done for him killed Creusa and her father, King Creon. In a terrible denouement she even killed her children. A broken Jason lived on Corinth until his old friend Peleus persuaded him to return to Iolcos and overthrow Acastus, the King. They managed this and he was finally on the throne of Iolcos. This didn't last long however as one day, asleep under the Argo, a rotten beam fell on him and killed him. It was an ironic twist as he was warned years before during the voyage to repair the damage caused during the crossing of the Bosporus, but who knew this would be the deadly outcome.

source.name: Polydeuces
source.notes: Twin of Castor. He was one of Jason's Argonauts.

source.notes: King of Thespiae. Heracles killed the dreaded Mount Cithaeron lion that was terrorising Thespis' kingdom. He rewarded him with the hand of his daughter, Megara.

target.name: Heracles
target.notes: Born Alcides, son of Zeus and Alcmene. Zeus had wanted a child in the blood line of Perseus as Hera had prophecised that a child of Perseus would save the Olympians. Hera was so incensed at yet another affair of Zeus that she swore eternal enmity against Alcides. Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

source.name: Erginos
source.notes: King of Orchomenos, he attacked Thebes but was defeated by Heracles. The people of Thebes would go on to venerate Heracles, the greatest Theban since their founder Cadmus.

source.name: Megara
source.notes: Wife of Heracles, they had a son and daughter together. One fateful day when Heracles returned home he was confronted by a demon and two dragons at his front door, Heracles being Heracles he quickly dispatched them but when he looked at the corpses he saw it was in fact his wife and children. This was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions she had stripped Heracles of everything that mattered to him, his family and his standing in the community.

source.name: Chimera
source.notes: A two-headed monster with a lion's body and head, a goat's head rising from its back, the udders of a goat, and a serpent's tail. Killed by the hero Bellerophon.

target.name: Typhon
target.notes: A monstrous storm giant who laid siege to the heavens in the clash of the Titans but was defeated by Zeus.

source.name: Chimera
source.notes: A two-headed monster with a lion's body and head, a goat's head rising from its back, the udders of a goat, and a serpent's tail. Killed by the hero Bellerophon.

target.name: Echidna
target.notes: A monstrous she-dragon with the head and breast of a woman and the tail of a serpent. She represents the corruptions of the earth, rot, slime, fetid water, illness and disease.

source.name: Nemean Lion
source.notes: A fierce lion with an impenetrable hide. Heracles was ordered to kill it as one of his labours. He managed to wrestle it into submission after a fierce fight and killed it. He would wear its hide over his shoulders and a necklace of its claws around his neck.

target.name: Orthrus
target.notes: A ferocious two-headed dog, brother of Cerberus, the hound of hell. He guarded Geryon's cattle. Killed by Heracles when he was tasked with retrieving the cattle as one of his labours.

source.name: Iolaus
source.notes: Son of Iphicles and nephew of Heracles, he helped Heracles defeat the Lernaean Hydra.

target.name: Iphicles
target.notes: Step-brother of Heracles.

source.name: Ceryneian Hind
source.notes: A golden-horned, brass-footed doe, sacred to Artemis. Eurystheus ordered Heracles to bring her to him as one of his labours, knowing full well that she wasn't a threat to anyone but it would result in his certain death at the hands of Artemis. He managed to capture her but was confronted by Artemis who was just about to kill him when Apollo emerged and told her the entire story. It amused Artemis to aid an enemy of Hera (Hera wasn't fond of any child of Zeus that wasn't hers, and the feelings were mutual) so she ordered him to release the hind as soon as he showed her to Eurystheus.

target.name: Artemis
target.god_of: God of Hunting, wild animals, children, & childbirth
target.notes: Goddess of chastity and hunting.

source.name: Erymanthian Boar
source.notes: A giant boar that ravaged the area around Mount Erymanthus in Arcadia. Heracles was ordered to kill it as one of his labours. Heracles captured the boar and took it back alive. A terrified Eurystheus leapt into a giant stone jar to hide from it which would become an amusing and favourite scene for Greek pot painters.

source.name: Pholus
source.notes: Heracles sought Pholus' advice on where to find the Erymanthian Boar. Whilst staying with him he mistakenly drank some centaur wine and an argument broke out. The row became a fight and Heracles set loose a volley of arrows, whose tips were poisoned with the venemous blood of Hydra. Pholus was killed in the fight.

target.name: Silenus
target.notes: Fathered by Hermes and an unknown nymph, Silenus was a snub-nosed, donkey-tailed lecher who would grow up to become a bearded, pot-bellied old drunk. A popular subject in paintings and sculptures.

source.name: Nessus
source.notes: A centaur who survived the fight with Heracles (see Pholus for the details). Years later he would meet Heracles and his wife Deianira trying to cross the River Euinos. Heracles didn't recognise him, but he certainly recognised Heracles. Whilst transporting Deianira across the river he tried to molest her. Heracles fired his Hydra poisoned arrows at him, as he lay dying he tricked Deianira into taking his blood stained shirt telling her that it was charmed and that it will ignite a failing marriage, all she has to do is make him wear it. A few years later Deianira did indeed give Heracles the shirt, the Hydra poison worked its way through his mighty body causing him the most agonising death.

target.name: Nephele
target.notes: Zeus, angered by Ixion who tried to seduce Hera, sent Nephele to Ixion with the appearance of Hera as a trap. He coupled with her incurring Zeus's wrath in the process who bound him to a burning wheel in the depths of Tartarus for eternity. The result of this coupling was a son, Centauros.

source.name: Nessus
source.notes: A centaur who survived the fight with Heracles (see Pholus for the details). Years later he would meet Heracles and his wife Deianira trying to cross the River Euinos. Heracles didn't recognise him, but he certainly recognised Heracles. Whilst transporting Deianira across the river he tried to molest her. A few years later Deianira did indeed give Heracles the shirt, the Hydra poison worked its way through his mighty body causing him the most agonising death.

target.name: Ixion
target.notes: Ixion, already angering the gods to breaking point by refusing one of their most strongly held beliefs, the spirit of hospitality, or xenia, and by killing his father-in-law, Deioneus, King of Phocis and committing the first blood murder, would go on to anger them even further. Invited to a banquet by Zeus he tried it on with his wife, Hera. An angry Zeus then tested him the day after by animating a cloud shaped Hera look-a-like and presenting it to Ixion. He duly impregnated her. This was the final straw and Zeus bound him to a wheel of fire and sent him down to the depths of Tartarus where he revolves, spread-eagled and roasting in agony to this day. "Thou art a soul in bliss,but I am bound Upon a wheel of fire, that mine own tears Do scald like molten lead." King Lear.

source.name: Augeas
source.notes: King of Elis, he possessed a sacred herd of three thousand cattle. Heracles was ordered to clean out the stables, which hadn't been cleaned in over thirty years, in a single day. He managed to do this by diverting two local rivers, the Peneus and the Alpheus to sluice out the stables. The manure rich torrents swept onto the plains of Elis and fertilised the lands for miles around, pleasing the entire population. Heracles, who had been promised a reward by Augeas, returned to claim his prize of three-hundred of the cattle. Augeas reneged on the deal and Heracles swore revenge. He returned in later years to kill Augeas and placed his exiled son, Phyleus, who supported Heracles in the original dispute on the throne. Heracles established athletic competitions here, every four years, which he named in honour of his father's home, the Olympic games. Before his death he was also one of Jason's Argonauts.

target.name: Helios
target.notes: Would become the sun's sole charioteer after Apollo gave up the job when his son Phaeton died trying to drive it. He mocked Phaeton for trying to drive the sun chariot, letting out a high-pitched hysterical squeak when he heard the ridiculous nature of his plan. The same high-pitched squeak that you get when you breathe in the gas named after him, helium.

He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

source.name: Augeas
source.notes: King of Elis, he possessed a sacred herd of three thousand cattle. Heracles was ordered to clean out the stables, which hadn't been cleaned in over thirty years, in a single day. He managed to do this by diverting two local rivers, the Peneus and the Alpheus to sluice out the stables. The manure rich torrents swept onto the plains of Elis and fertilised the lands for miles around, pleasing the entire population. Heracles, who had been promised a reward by Augeas, returned to claim his prize of three-hundred of the cattle. Augeas reneged on the deal and Heracles swore revenge. He returned in later years to kill Augeas and placed his exiled son, Phyleus, who supported Heracles in the original dispute on the throne. Heracles established athletic competitions here, every four years, which he named in honour of his father's home, the Olympic games. Before his death he was also one of Jason's Argonauts.

target.name: Jason
target.notes: Smuggled out of Iolcos when he was a baby due to Pelias and Neleus laying siege to the city believeing they were the rightful heirs to the throne and not his father, Aeson. He was brought up by his mother's (Alcimede) friend, the great centaur, Chiron. Met Bellerophon, who was seeking help from Chiron for Pegasus burned skin at the hands of Chimera. He filled his head with heroic feats which influenced Jason in his formative years. When his tutelage with Chiron was finished he ventured back to Iolcos. On the journey he lost a sandal helping an old lady (Hera in disguise) across a river. It was prophecised to Pelias to beware of a man arriving from the country with one sandal so when he arrived in Iolcos, Pelias knew immediately who he was. Pelias agreed to let him take the throne but lied to him, telling him the land was cursed and that the only way to lift the curse was to retrieve the Golden Fleece. He arranged a mighty ship, the Argo, and a great crew, the Argonauts, to sail to Colchis and retrieve the fleece. When the Argonauts arrived at Colchis, King Aeëtes demanded three tests of Jason before he could take it. To tame the fire breathing bulls, the Khalkotauroi, to sow some dragon's teeth from Cadmus and defeat the army that sprouts from the ground, and to kill the dragon that guards the fleece. He managed these feats thanks to his new lover, Medea, whom Hera had had Eros strike her with his cupid's arrow. They escaped with the fleece back to Pelias where they realised he was never going to give up the throne so Medea tricked his nine daughters into killing him, believing they were being taught a magic trick and would be brought back to life. They had to flee Iolcos after this blood killing and sought refuge in Corinth. Here Jason fell for the King's daughter, Creusa. Medea, so enraged at this betrayal after everything she had done for him killed Creusa and her father, King Creon. In a terrible denouement she even killed her children. A broken Jason lived on Corinth until his old friend Peleus persuaded him to return to Iolcos and overthrow Acastus, the King. They managed this and he was finally on the throne of Iolcos. This didn't last long however as one day, asleep under the Argo, a rotten beam fell on him and killed him. It was an ironic twist as he was warned years before during the voyage to repair the damage caused during the crossing of the Bosporus, but who knew this would be the deadly outcome.

source.name: Phyleus
source.notes: Son of Augeas, he stuck up for Heracles when Augeas reneged on the deal to clean out the Augean stables for three-hundred of his cattle. He was exiled to Dulichium, an island in the Ionian Sea as punishment. Later when Heracles took revenge on Augeas, he was placed on the throne in his place.

target.name: Heracles
target.notes: Born Alcides, son of Zeus and Alcmene. Zeus had wanted a child in the blood line of Perseus as Hera had prophecised that a child of Perseus would save the Olympians. Hera was so incensed at yet another affair of Zeus that she swore eternal enmity against Alcides. Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

source.name: Stymphalian Birds
source.notes: Fearsome man-eating birds the size of cranes with beaks of iron, talons of brass and toxic droppings. Sacred to Ares, the god of war. Heracles was ordered to rid them from Lake Stymphalia. He couldn't get near to them as the ground near them was swampland. Athena came to his aid by providing him a great bronze rattle, manufactured by Hephaestus, to flush the birds out from the swamp where he was then able to  shoot them down and scare the rest away.

target.name: Ares
target.notes: He and Aphrodite would form a couple (Venus and Mars, love and war).

source.name: Cretan Bull
source.notes: Sent from the sea by Posedion in answer to the prayers of Minos, the King of Crete who wanted a sign that his reign was blessed. Heracles was sent to subdue it as one of his labours. When Heracles released the bull it fled to Marathon, where it became known as the Marathonian Bull and terrorised the inhabitants there until Theseus came along and subdued the bull. He then sacrificed it to Apollo.

source.name: Minos II
source.notes: King of Crete. He demanded a yearly tribute from Athens for the death of his son, Androgeus, who died trying to subdue the Marathonian Bull on the King of Athens' orders (King Aegeus). Theseus, Aegeus' son, went to Crete as part of the tribute and killed Asterion the minotaur, the one for whom the tribute was for. Minos blamed Daedalus, the inventor of the labyrinth which imprisoned Asterion. Daedalus escaped but Minos eventually tracked him down to Sicily where he demanded King Cocalus hand him over. Cocalus' daughters, very fond of Daedalus, scalded him to death in the bath before he had chance to take him.

target.name: Asterion
target.notes: King of Crete and son of Minos, one of the judges of the underworld.

source.name: Pasiphae
source.notes: Queen of Crete, she mated with the Cretan Bull and bore the minotaur Asterion.

target.name: Helios
target.notes: Would become the sun's sole charioteer after Apollo gave up the job when his son Phaeton died trying to drive it. He mocked Phaeton for trying to drive the sun chariot, letting out a high-pitched hysterical squeak when he heard the ridiculous nature of his plan. The same high-pitched squeak that you get when you breathe in the gas named after him, helium.

source.name: Pasiphae
source.notes: Queen of Crete, she mated with the Cretan Bull and bore the minotaur Asterion.

source.name: Asterion
source.notes: Son of the Cretan Bull and Pasiphae, Queen of Crete. This half man, half bull, known as a Minotaur, lived in the labyrinth designed by King Minos of Crete's architect, Daedalus.

target.name: Cretan Bull
target.notes: Sent from the sea by Posedion in answer to the prayers of Minos, the King of Crete who wanted a sign that his reign was blessed. Heracles was sent to subdue it as one of his labours. source.name: Asterion

target.name: Pasiphae
target.notes: Queen of Crete, she mated with the Cretan Bull and bore the minotaur Asterion.

source.name: Daedalus
source.notes: The most gifted architect, inventor, designer in all of ancient Greece. Born in Athens but was expelled when he threw his nephew and apprentice Perdix off the Acropolis in a jealous rage as Perdix had become even more gifted than Daedalus himself. He went to Crete where he would work for King Minos.  He designed the labyrinth that imprisoned the minotaur Asterion for King Minos of Crete. When Theseus killed Asterion Minos blamed Daedalus. Only the inventor of the labyrinth could have helped him on his way through. He imprisoned Daedalus and his son, Icarus, at the top of the palace tower. Daedalus made wings from feathers and candle wax for them both to escape. Icarus flew too high and his wings melted. He crashed into the sea and died. Daedalus eventually ended up working for King Cocalus in Sicily. One day he was presented with a puzzle, passing a thread through a shell's complex helical chambers. Daedalus did this with ease and showed the man how he did it. The man was pleased, only Daedalus the inventor could have solved this puzzle. The man was Minos. He had finally tracked Daedalus down and wanted revenge. Cocalus reluctantly agreed to hand him over the next day but whilst Minos was bathing in the palace, Cocalus' daughters, so very fond of Daedalus, heated the water to boiling point and scalded Minos to death.

target.name: Cecrops I
target.notes: The first king of Attica and ancestor of all Athenians. He judged in favour of Athena when she and Poseidon vied for control of the new town that he built. Hence the name Athens. His son is Daedalus, the inventor.

source.name: Diomedes
source.notes: King of Thrace. Heracles was sent to get his four mares as one of his labours. The horses killed Heracles' lover, Abderus during the quest. Heracles unleashed the full force of his wrath on Diomedes as a result and he fed him to his own horses. The unpleasant taste of their former master caused the mares to lose the taste for human flesh and Heracles was able to ride them back to Eurystheus.

target.name: Ares
target.notes: He and Aphrodite would form a couple (Venus and Mars, love and war).

source.name: Alcestis
source.notes: Queen of Pherae alongside King Admetus. She agreed to die for Admetus who was promised immortality by Apollo and the Moirai if he could find someone to take his place. Admetus was so distraught that Heracles rescued her from Thanatos as he was taking her soul to the underworld.

target.name: Pelias
target.notes: He had nine daughters, the most beautiful, Alcestis, was promised only to the man who was able to harness a boar and a lion to a chariot. source.name: Alcestis

target.name: Admetus
target.notes: Thessalian King, he had won the approval of Zeus for his exceptionally warm hospitality. When Apollo was punished for killing the cyclopes that helped kill his son Asclepius, he was sent to Admetus to serve under him for one whole year. The two became great friends, again due to his warm hospitality. Apollo made a deal with the Moirai to make him immortal, he just had to find someone to die in his place. His loving wife Alcestis agreed to die for him. Filled with remorse, he tried to stop her, but the will of the Moirai could not be overturned. It was at her funeral that Heracles arrived to stay with Admetus. Finding out about the tragic events, he promised to rescue Alcestis from the underworld. He found Thanatos, the god of death at her tomb and wrestled him to the ground, rescuing Alcestis and taking her back to Admetus.

Pelias, terrified, tricked agreed to let him have the throne but told him that the land was cursed and the only way to lift the curse was to retrieve the Golden Fleece.

target.name: Tyro
target.notes: Wife of Sisyphus and daughter of his brother Salmoneus (yes, he married his niece). Sisyphus only married her because the Delphic Oracle told Sisyphus that "Sons of Sisyphus and Tyro rise to slay Salmoneus". Salmoneus was his brother whom he despised more than anything. One day Tyro found out the real reason for their marriage. Feeling a stronger attachment to her father rather than her husband, she drowned their children in the river before fleeing back to her father.

source.name: Pelias
source.notes: He had nine daughters, the most beautiful, Alcestis, was promised only to the man who was able to harness a boar and a lion to a chariot. Admetus, with help from his friend and lover Apollo, was the only one who managed this feat, and the two were wed. Believed he was the rightful heir to the throne of Iolcos when King Cretheus died (Cretheus' wife, Tyro, was his mother by the sea god Poseidon). He besieged Iolcos alongside his brother Neleus which caused the rightful heir, Aeson, to smuggle out his firstborn child, Jason, of Golden Fleece fame. He slaughtered everyone connected to Cretheus and imprisoned Aeson and his wife Alcimede. He also killed Sidero, Cretheus' second wife, who mistreated his mother, but he mistakenly did this in a temple dedicated to Hera, the Queen of Heaven. She swore revenge, of all the gods she was the most dangerous an enemy, just ask Heracles. Pelias, troubled by this, seeks advice from an oracle who informs him that "One of your own blood will end your life, beware the man who comes from the country wearing but one sandal". The prophecy came true one fateful day when Jason wandered into the city. He had lost a sandal on the journey helping an old woman (Hera in disguise) across a river. Pelias, terrified, tricked agreed to let him have the throne but told him that the land was cursed and the only way to lift the curse was to retrieve the Golden Fleece.

target.name: Jason
target.notes: Smuggled out of Iolcos when he was a baby due to Pelias and Neleus laying siege to the city believeing they were the rightful heirs to the throne and not his father, Aeson. He was brought up by his mother's (Alcimede) friend, the great centaur, Chiron. Met Bellerophon, who was seeking help from Chiron for Pegasus burned skin at the hands of Chimera. He filled his head with heroic feats which influenced Jason in his formative years. When his tutelage with Chiron was finished he ventured back to Iolcos. On the journey he lost a sandal helping an old lady (Hera in disguise) across a river. It was prophecised to Pelias to beware of a man arriving from the country with one sandal so when he arrived in Iolcos, Pelias knew immediately who he was. Pelias agreed to let him take the throne but lied to him, telling him the land was cursed and that the only way to lift the curse was to retrieve the Golden Fleece. He arranged a mighty ship, the Argo, and a great crew, the Argonauts, to sail to Colchis and retrieve the fleece. When the Argonauts arrived at Colchis, King Aeëtes demanded three tests of Jason before he could take it. To tame the fire breathing bulls, the Khalkotauroi, to sow some dragon's teeth from Cadmus and defeat the army that sprouts from the ground, and to kill the dragon that guards the fleece. He managed these feats thanks to his new lover, Medea, whom Hera had had Eros strike her with his cupid's arrow. They escaped with the fleece back to Pelias where they realised he was never going to give up the throne so Medea tricked his nine daughters into killing him, believing they were being taught a magic trick and would be brought back to life. They had to flee Iolcos after this blood killing and sought refuge in Corinth. Here Jason fell for the King's daughter, Creusa. Medea, so enraged at this betrayal after everything she had done for him killed Creusa and her father, King Creon. In a terrible denouement she even killed her children. A broken Jason lived on Corinth until his old friend Peleus persuaded him to return to Iolcos and overthrow Acastus, the King. They managed this and he was finally on the throne of Iolcos. This didn't last long however as one day, asleep under the Argo, a rotten beam fell on him and killed him. It was an ironic twist as he was warned years before during the voyage to repair the damage caused during the crossing of the Bosporus, but who knew this would be the deadly outcome.

source.name: Podargos
source.notes: One of Diomede's mares, the 'flashing-footed'. Diomedes fed them human flesh and they became quite mad and dangerous. Heracles was commanded to retrieve the horses as one of his labours. When his friend and lover, Abderus, was killed during the quest, he fed Diomedes to the horses in revenge. The horses lost their appetite for human flesh as a result and Heracles was able to ride them back to Eurystheus.

target.name: Heracles
target.notes: Born Alcides, son of Zeus and Alcmene. Zeus had wanted a child in the blood line of Perseus as Hera had prophecised that a child of Perseus would save the Olympians. Hera was so incensed at yet another affair of Zeus that she swore eternal enmity against Alcides. Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

source.name: Podargos
source.notes: One of Diomede's mares, the 'flashing-footed'. Diomedes fed them human flesh and they became quite mad and dangerous. The horses lost their appetite for human flesh as a result and Heracles was able to ride them back to Eurystheus.

target.name: Diomedes
target.notes: King of Thrace. Heracles was sent to get his four mares as one of his labours. The horses killed Heracles' lover, Abderus during the quest. Heracles unleashed the full force of his wrath on Diomedes as a result and he fed him to his own horses. The unpleasant taste of their former master caused the mares to lose the taste for human flesh and Heracles was able to ride them back to Eurystheus.

source.name: Abderus

target.name: Hermes
target.god_of: God of Messengers, thievery, medicine, herds & trade
target.notes: This infant prodigy gives his name to anything "mercurial". Would become "chief conductor of souls" for the most important human spirits.

source.name: Admete
source.notes: Daughter of Eurystheus, who commanded Heracles on his labours to atone for the killing of his family. She was given a labour of Heracles by her father as a present. She ordered Heracles to bring her the girdle of Hippolyta, the Queen of the Amazons, a fierce band of strong, independent women.

target.name: Eurystheus
target.notes: Zeus had chosen Alcmene instead of Nicippe to bear his child to fulfill Hera's prophecy that someone from the line of Perseus would save the Olympians. Just before Alcmene was to give birth he exhorted that "the next child born of the house of Perseus will rule all Argolis". But unbeknownst to him, Hera had crafted a plan to get Nicippe to give birth first as revenge on Zeus' affair, Eurystheus was the result. He would take the throne as Zeus had inadvertenly promised, and in Hera's cruel twist of fate Heracles would be ordered to serve Eurystheus after he mistakenly killed his family. Eurystheus would send Heracles on his labours to atone for his sins.

source.name: Admete
source.notes: Daughter of Eurystheus, who commanded Heracles on his labours to atone for the killing of his family. She was given a labour of Heracles by her father as a present. source.name: Hippolyta
source.notes: Queen of the Amazons, a fierce band of strong, independent female warriors, the daughters of Ares, the god of war, and Harmonia. They were the first warriors to ride on horseback and when they conquered a territory they would choose the best men for mating and kill them, raising only girls to join their group. Heracles was ordered to steal her jewelled girdle as one of his labours. When Heracles reached the Amazons news of his labours had spread far and wide and he was welcomed as a hero and equal. Hippolyta gifted her girdle to Heracles as a gesture of goodwill. Hera, incensed at the ease of how he achieved this labour, snuck amongst the Amazons and tricked them into attacking Heracles. Heracles killed Hippolyta thinking it was a trap sprung by her.

target.name: Ares
target.notes: He and Aphrodite would form a couple (Venus and Mars, love and war).

target.name: Harmonia
target.notes: Wife of Cadmus, Prince of Tyre and King of Thebes. When he was finally worn down by Ares for killing the Ismenian Dragon and turned into a snake, Athena turned her into a snake also so they could live out their days together.

source.name: Hesione
source.notes: Daughter of Laomedon, King of Troy. He had to appease Apollo and Poseidon, who had helped build Troy, because he had refused them the necessary sacrifices. The penance was that he had to chain his daughter, Hesione, to a rock for Poseidon's sea monster to feast upon. Heracles promised to free her in return for the horses that Zeus had gifted to Tros (the founder of Troy) in return for his son Ganymede. Heracles kep his side of the bargain but Laomedon reneged, he vowed one day to take revenge.

target.name: Laomedon
target.notes: Nephew of Zeus's beloved cupbearer Ganymede and King of Troy. He angered Heracles when he refused payment for one of his labours. Heracles sought revenge and killed him, sacking the city in the process.

source.name: Hesione
source.notes: Daughter of Laomedon, King of Troy. He had to appease Apollo and Poseidon, who had helped build Troy, because he had refused them the necessary sacrifices. The penance was that he had to chain his daughter, Hesione, to a rock for Poseidon's sea monster to feast upon. Heracles promised to free her in return for the horses that Zeus had gifted to Tros (the founder of Troy) in return for his son Ganymede. Heracles kep his side of the bargain but Laomedon reneged, he vowed one day to take revenge.

target.name: Heracles
target.notes: Born Alcides, son of Zeus and Alcmene. Zeus had wanted a child in the blood line of Perseus as Hera had prophecised that a child of Perseus would save the Olympians. Hera was so incensed at yet another affair of Zeus that she swore eternal enmity against Alcides. Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

source.name: Geryon
source.notes: A three-headed monster who fiercely protected an enormous herd of red cattle in Erytheia. Killed by Heracles when he was ordered to retrieve the cattle as one of his labours.

target.name: Chrysaor
target.notes: Child of Poseidon and Medusa, was held in Medusa's womb when she was punished by Athena until Perseus beheaded her and Chrysaor could emerge bearing a weapon of shining gold. His name means 'golden sword'.

source.name: Antaeus
source.notes: A half-giant, he would challenge passers by to wrestling matches, the loser of which must die. Heracles challenged him to match but struggled to defeat him as every time Antaeus hit the ground, he would get stronger. Heracles realised that as a child of Gaia, mother earth, he had to keep him off the ground to defeat him. He got him in a bear hug off the ground and managed to defeat him.

source.name: Cercyon
source.notes: A giant of a man, he challenged travellers to wrestling matches. Theseus encountered him on his heroic travels where he used wit and skill to Cercyon's brute strength. Cercyon tired and Theseus managed to best him by tripping him over some cliffs. To the Greeks this would be the birth of modern wrestling.

target.name: Hephaestus
target.god_of: God of  Fire, Blacksmiths, Artisans, Sculptors & Metalworkers
target.notes: To Hera's dismay, wanting to give birth to the greatest of the gods, saw the child was so ugly that she hurled him down Mount Olympus in disgust. He would forge a golden throne that would bind Hera and come and unlock it to get back to Olympus. He would wed Aphrodite as a reward.

target.name: Theseus
target.notes: Theseus discovered his father was Aegeus, King of Athens. He wanted to enter Athens a hero to finally meet his father, so he set out along the dangerous coastal route from Troezen. During his travels he cleared the route of all evil, slaying monsters and murderes alike to enter Athens held aloft by an adoring public grateful to have the road made safe once more. Aegeus' wife, Jason's widow, Medea, was adamant that her own son, Medus, and not Theseus would be the heir to throne of Athens so she persuaded Aegeus, who didn't know it was his long lost son at this point, to order him to kill the Marathonian Bull. Theseus accomplished this heroic feat, inventing ancient bull fighting in the process. Medea then contrived to have him poisoned. Aegeus agreed, believing Theseus' fame was a threat to his rule. Just as Theseus was about to drink the poison, Aegeus noticed his sword. It was the exact same sword that he'd buried back in Troezen for his son to find one day. He managed to stop him drinking the poison just in time and father and son were united. Medea fled Athens never to return. Theseus then went to Crete to lift the tributes that Athens had to pay. This was due to Aegeus sending Minos' (King of Crete) son Androgeus to kill the Marathonian Bull and getting killed. Minos threatened to raze Athens to the ground unless a tribute of seven maidens and seven youths were sent from Athens every year to feed the minotaur Asterion. Theseus sent himself as one of the sacrifical lambs where he fell in love with Minos' daughter, Ariadne. She gave him a ball of cotton which he used to find his way through the labyrinth to kill Asterion. He fled Crete with Ariadne to the island of Naxos. It was here that Theseus had a dream in which Dionysus warned him to leave Ariadne on the island as she was betrothed to him. He took the tough decision to leave her to save the Athenians he'd managed to save from being sacrificed to Asterion. He later took Antiope, an Amazon warrior as his queen kickstarting the Attic War, or Amazonomachy. They managed to defeat the Amazons but Antiope was killed in the process. He then had a sort of mid-life crisis, getting into all sorts of scrapes with his best friend Pirithous. They had the terrible idea one day of trying to kidnap Persephone, Queen of the underworld to be Pirithous' wife. Hades had them cast into stone chairs, their buttocks stuck to the seats. Heracles managed to free them during his twelfth labour to retrieve Cerberus. He married Phaedra, the younger sister of Ariadne. When visiting his son Hippolytus, Phaedra, Hippolytus' step-mother, was struck by a curse sent from Aphrodite in revenge for Hippolytus' neglect in all matters of love. Phaedra declared her love to Hippolytus but it wasn't reciprocated. Phaedra cried rape to Theseus who prayed to his father Poseidon for justice. Hippolytus was trampled to death in a chariot "accident". Upon hearing this Phaedra killed herself. Theseus was exiled from Athens for this unwitting role in the deaths of his son and wife. The end of his life was marked by shame and bitterness. He ended up as the guest of King Lycomedes of Skyros where one day he fell to his death over a cliff, pushed by Lycomedes but the reason is lost to us. His legacy wasn't tarnished however, Theseus goes down as one of the great heroes of Greek myth, and the greatest in all of Athens. His statue stands proudly in the centre of Athens today in Syntagma Square.

source.name: Busiris
source.notes: Son of Aegyptus in Egypt, the Greeks had a distaste for the human sacrifices performed by the priests of Osiris, from whom Busiris got his name. Heracles offered himself to as the next sacrifice but just before he was to be killed, he burst open from his chains and killed Busiris. He renamed the town of Busiris, Thebes, in honour of the city of his birth. Hence the need to distinguish between Thebes in Greece, and Thebes in Egypt, which is contained within the cities of Luxor and Karnak.

target.name: Aegyptus
target.notes: Great-grandson of Epaphus, he would go on to rule Egypt for generations.

source.name: Pirithous
source.notes: King of the Lapiths and one of Jason's Argonauts. He heard of the exploits of Theseus and wanted to test them out. He raided his cattle and Theseus tracked him down, but instead of fighting it out they quickly realised they very much liked each other and so began one of the great friendships in Greek mythology. They had the crazy idea of kidnapping Persephone, Queen of the Underworld to be his wife. Hades had them cast into stone chairs, their buttocks glued to the seats. It wasn't until Heracles descended into the underworld during his twelfth labour to retrieve Cerberus, that they managed to be freed.

target.god_of: King of the Gods, god of sky, weather & fate
