He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

source.name: Pirithous
source.notes: King of the Lapiths and one of Jason's Argonauts. He heard of the exploits of Theseus and wanted to test them out. He raided his cattle and Theseus tracked him down, but instead of fighting it out they quickly realised they very much liked each other and so began one of the great friendships in Greek mythology. They had the crazy idea of kidnapping Persephone, Queen of the Underworld to be his wife. Hades had them cast into stone chairs, their buttocks glued to the seats. It wasn't until Heracles descended into the underworld during his twelfth labour to retrieve Cerberus, that they managed to be freed.

target.name: Jason
target.notes: Smuggled out of Iolcos when he was a baby due to Pelias and Neleus laying siege to the city believeing they were the rightful heirs to the throne and not his father, Aeson. He was brought up by his mother's (Alcimede) friend, the great centaur, Chiron. Met Bellerophon, who was seeking help from Chiron for Pegasus burned skin at the hands of Chimera. He filled his head with heroic feats which influenced Jason in his formative years. When his tutelage with Chiron was finished he ventured back to Iolcos. On the journey he lost a sandal helping an old lady (Hera in disguise) across a river. It was prophecised to Pelias to beware of a man arriving from the country with one sandal so when he arrived in Iolcos, Pelias knew immediately who he was. Pelias agreed to let him take the throne but lied to him, telling him the land was cursed and that the only way to lift the curse was to retrieve the Golden Fleece. He arranged a mighty ship, the Argo, and a great crew, the Argonauts, to sail to Colchis and retrieve the fleece. When the Argonauts arrived at Colchis, King Aeëtes demanded three tests of Jason before he could take it. To tame the fire breathing bulls, the Khalkotauroi, to sow some dragon's teeth from Cadmus and defeat the army that sprouts from the ground, and to kill the dragon that guards the fleece. He managed these feats thanks to his new lover, Medea, whom Hera had had Eros strike her with his cupid's arrow. They escaped with the fleece back to Pelias where they realised he was never going to give up the throne so Medea tricked his nine daughters into killing him, believing they were being taught a magic trick and would be brought back to life. They had to flee Iolcos after this blood killing and sought refuge in Corinth. Here Jason fell for the King's daughter, Creusa. Medea, so enraged at this betrayal after everything she had done for him killed Creusa and her father, King Creon. In a terrible denouement she even killed her children. A broken Jason lived on Corinth until his old friend Peleus persuaded him to return to Iolcos and overthrow Acastus, the King. They managed this and he was finally on the throne of Iolcos. This didn't last long however as one day, asleep under the Argo, a rotten beam fell on him and killed him. It was an ironic twist as he was warned years before during the voyage to repair the damage caused during the crossing of the Bosporus, but who knew this would be the deadly outcome.

source.name: Meleager
source.notes: One of Jason's Argonauts. He was son of either Oeneus, King of Calydon, or Ares, the god of war. His mother, Althaea, fell into a deep sleep after giving birth where she dreamed that the Moirai, or Fates, had decided that his life would be noble, potentially being the son of Ares and all, but his life would only last as long as the central log in the fireplace by which his mother slept remained unburned. "Meleager's life will end in a flash, when his log of fate is turned to ash" they chanted. He was a member of the hunt for the Calydonian Boar that terrorised his father's kingdom. He fell instantly in love with Atalanta who joined the hunt. This wasn't reciprocated however because as a subject of the god of chastity, Artemis, she had turned her back on men and love. When the hunt was over he credited Atalanta with the honour of the kill, to the indignation of his uncles, the Thestiades. They believed the honour should be bestowed on their family only as Atalanta was an outsider. So enraged through his love for Atalanta, Meleager killed his uncles in cold blood. When his mother discovered this she retrieved the fateful log and burned it on the spit the boar was being roasted on. Meleager died an agonising death. Overcome by extreme guilt, Althaea ran into the forest and hung herself.

target.name: Ares
target.notes: He and Aphrodite would form a couple (Venus and Mars, love and war).

target.name: Calydonian Boar
target.notes: Killed Ancaeus in his vineyard when he returned from the quest for the Golden Fleece.

target.name: Atalanta
target.notes: Abandoned by her father Schoeneues because he wanted a boy and heir. She was left on Mount Parthenion to die, but she was discovered by a she-bear who had just lost her cubs, so instead of eating her, she raised her. She was taken in by a group of hunters later who named her Atalanta, meaning "equal in weight", i.e. she was man's equal. She quickly learned and surpassed her teachers in the skills of hunting and dedicated herself to the Olympian Artemis, goddess of chastity and hunting. She joined the hunt for the Calydonian Boar to prove herself the greatest hero of the age. After she had killed the boar she was taken back in her father, certainly not the last time a  parent was to reclaim a famous and successful child. He wanted her to marry to keep the kingdom in the family but being a disciple of Artemis she refused. "I will only marry a man who can best me in a foot race" she said. Being the fastest in the land she knew this was an impossible task. Hippomenes was the one who finally beat her in a race, thanks to Aphrodite's help. They were married soon after but Hippomenes had failed to thank Aphrodite for her help and she cursed the couple into making love in a temple sacred to the goddess Cybele. So outraged was Cybele she transformed them into lions who the Greeks believed couldn't mate with each other. They lived out their lives drawing Cybele's chariot, closely coupled but denied the pleasure of sex for eternity.

source.name: Deianira
source.notes: Sister of Meleager who wanted Heracles to join his bloodline, so he persuaded him to marry her. She lived a happy life married to Heracles but was tricked by Nessus, the centaur who survived the fight with Heracles into giving him his blood stained shirt. The blood was that of Hydra, and was deadly posionous. After giving him the shirt he died the most agonising death and she killed herself as a result.

target.name: Oeneus
target.notes: Father-in-law to Heracles, during a feast Heracles killed his cupbearer for spilling wine on him. He was the King of Calydon, it was his excessive worship of the god Dionysus that so enraged Artemis which caused her to send the Calydonian Boar to terrorise his kingdom. He sent out a call for someone to kill the beast who would go down as 'the greatest hero of the age'. That hero was Atalanta.

target.name: Heracles
target.notes: Born Alcides, son of Zeus and Alcmene. Zeus had wanted a child in the blood line of Perseus as Hera had prophecised that a child of Perseus would save the Olympians. Hera was so incensed at yet another affair of Zeus that she swore eternal enmity against Alcides. Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

source.name: Iole
source.notes: Daughter of King Eurytus, he arranged an archery competition (he was Greece's finest bowman) to find a suitable man to claim his daughter's hand in marriage. Heracles, Eurytus' former pupil, tried to enter the competition but Eurytus refused saying that a man that killed his wife and children could not take his daughter's hand. Heracles stormed off promising revenge.

target.name: Eurytus
target.notes: King of Oechalia, the most famed bowman in Greece, he taught Heracles his archery skills.

source.name: Iphitus
source.notes: Son of King Eurytus, he pleaded with him to let Heracles marry his sister. He visited Heracles after but became victim of one of Heracles' infamous fits of rage and was thrown from the city walls to his death.

source.name: Neleus
source.notes: King of Pylos. Heracles sought a penance from him after he killed Iphitus in a fit of rage. But Neleus was an old friend of Eurytus, Iphitus' father, and so refused him atonement. Heracles vowed revenge. He helped his brother, Pelias, set siege to Iolcos believing him to be the rightful heir to the throne. This led to Jason, of Golden Fleece fame, to be smuggled out of the city and set off a famous chain of events.

target.name: Poseidon

target.notes: Swallowed by Kronos when born due to Ouranos' curse on him that "Your own children will overthrow you as you overthrew me". Giften the weapon of a Trident by the Cyclopes.

target.name: Tyro
target.notes: Wife of Sisyphus and daughter of his brother Salmoneus (yes, he married his niece). Sisyphus only married her because the Delphic Oracle told Sisyphus that "Sons of Sisyphus and Tyro rise to slay Salmoneus". Salmoneus was his brother whom he despised more than anything. One day Tyro found out the real reason for their marriage. Feeling a stronger attachment to her father rather than her husband, she drowned their children in the river before fleeing back to her father.

source.notes: One of the Delphic oracles. She was the one who ordered Heracles to atone for his killing of Iphitus. He was ordered to become a slave to Queen Omphale of Lydia for three years, after which he would give all of his earnings to Eurytus in compensation.

target.name: Heracles
target.notes: Born Alcides, son of Zeus and Alcmene. Zeus had wanted a child in the blood line of Perseus as Hera had prophecised that a child of Perseus would save the Olympians. Hera was so incensed at yet another affair of Zeus that she swore eternal enmity against Alcides. Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

source.name: Telamon
source.notes: Friend of Heracles, he helped him take revenge on Laomedon, King of Troy for refusing payment for one of his labours. He took Laomedon's daughter, Hesione, as his wife. Was also one of Jason's Argonauts and brought Heracles along with him.

target.name: Jason
target.notes: Smuggled out of Iolcos when he was a baby due to Pelias and Neleus laying siege to the city believeing they were the rightful heirs to the throne and not his father, Aeson. He was brought up by his mother's (Alcimede) friend, the great centaur, Chiron. Met Bellerophon, who was seeking help from Chiron for Pegasus burned skin at the hands of Chimera. He filled his head with heroic feats which influenced Jason in his formative years. When his tutelage with Chiron was finished he ventured back to Iolcos. On the journey he lost a sandal helping an old lady (Hera in disguise) across a river. It was prophecised to Pelias to beware of a man arriving from the country with one sandal so when he arrived in Iolcos, Pelias knew immediately who he was. Pelias agreed to let him take the throne but lied to him, telling him the land was cursed and that the only way to lift the curse was to retrieve the Golden Fleece. He arranged a mighty ship, the Argo, and a great crew, the Argonauts, to sail to Colchis and retrieve the fleece. When the Argonauts arrived at Colchis, King Aeëtes demanded three tests of Jason before he could take it. To tame the fire breathing bulls, the Khalkotauroi, to sow some dragon's teeth from Cadmus and defeat the army that sprouts from the ground, and to kill the dragon that guards the fleece. He managed these feats thanks to his new lover, Medea, whom Hera had had Eros strike her with his cupid's arrow. They escaped with the fleece back to Pelias where they realised he was never going to give up the throne so Medea tricked his nine daughters into killing him, believing they were being taught a magic trick and would be brought back to life. They had to flee Iolcos after this blood killing and sought refuge in Corinth. Here Jason fell for the King's daughter, Creusa. Medea, so enraged at this betrayal after everything she had done for him killed Creusa and her father, King Creon. In a terrible denouement she even killed her children. A broken Jason lived on Corinth until his old friend Peleus persuaded him to return to Iolcos and overthrow Acastus, the King. They managed this and he was finally on the throne of Iolcos. This didn't last long however as one day, asleep under the Argo, a rotten beam fell on him and killed him. It was an ironic twist as he was warned years before during the voyage to repair the damage caused during the crossing of the Bosporus, but who knew this would be the deadly outcome.

source.name: Cteatus
source.notes: Conjoined twin brother of Eurytus. They were hired by Augeas to battle Heracles who sought revenge because he refused payment for one of his labours. They killed Heracles' own brother Iphicles, which roused Heracles into such a fury that he split them apart with a single swing of his sword.

target.name: Iphicles
target.notes: Step-brother of Heracles.

source.name: Actor
source.notes: nan

target.name: Molione
target.notes: nan

source.name: Actor
source.notes: nan

target.name: Augeas
target.notes: King of Elis, he possessed a sacred herd of three thousand cattle. Heracles was ordered to clean out the stables, which hadn't been cleaned in over thirty years, in a single day. He managed to do this by diverting two local rivers, the Peneus and the Alpheus to sluice out the stables. The manure rich torrents swept onto the plains of Elis and fertilised the lands for miles around, pleasing the entire population. Heracles, who had been promised a reward by Augeas, returned to claim his prize of three-hundred of the cattle. Augeas reneged on the deal and Heracles swore revenge. He returned in later years to kill Augeas and placed his exiled son, Phyleus, who supported Heracles in the original dispute on the throne. Heracles established athletic competitions here, every four years, which he named in honour of his father's home, the Olympic games. Before his death he was also one of Jason's Argonauts.

source.name: Nestor
source.notes: Took over his father's (Neleus) throne after Heracles took revenge on him for not atoneing him of the killing of Iphitus. He would become one of the wisest kings in the history of the Greek world, famed for his sound judgement and his distinguished service in the quest for the golden fleece and as a brave ally of Agamemnon in the Trojan war. He also took part in the hunr for the Calydonian Boar. Atalanta saved his life when she fired an arrow at the boar just as he was about to charge Nestor.

target.name: Neleus
target.notes: King of Pylos. Heracles sought a penance from him after he killed Iphitus in a fit of rage. But Neleus was an old friend of Eurytus, Iphitus' father, and so refused him atonement. Heracles vowed revenge. He helped his brother, Pelias, set siege to Iolcos believing him to be the rightful heir to the throne. This led to Jason, of Golden Fleece fame, to be smuggled out of the city and set off a famous chain of events.

target.name: Jason
target.notes: Smuggled out of Iolcos when he was a baby due to Pelias and Neleus laying siege to the city believeing they were the rightful heirs to the throne and not his father, Aeson. He was brought up by his mother's (Alcimede) friend, the great centaur, Chiron. Met Bellerophon, who was seeking help from Chiron for Pegasus burned skin at the hands of Chimera. He filled his head with heroic feats which influenced Jason in his formative years. When his tutelage with Chiron was finished he ventured back to Iolcos. On the journey he lost a sandal helping an old lady (Hera in disguise) across a river. It was prophecised to Pelias to beware of a man arriving from the country with one sandal so when he arrived in Iolcos, Pelias knew immediately who he was. Pelias agreed to let him take the throne but lied to him, telling him the land was cursed and that the only way to lift the curse was to retrieve the Golden Fleece. He arranged a mighty ship, the Argo, and a great crew, the Argonauts, to sail to Colchis and retrieve the fleece. When the Argonauts arrived at Colchis, King Aeëtes demanded three tests of Jason before he could take it. To tame the fire breathing bulls, the Khalkotauroi, to sow some dragon's teeth from Cadmus and defeat the army that sprouts from the ground, and to kill the dragon that guards the fleece. He managed these feats thanks to his new lover, Medea, whom Hera had had Eros strike her with his cupid's arrow. They escaped with the fleece back to Pelias where they realised he was never going to give up the throne so Medea tricked his nine daughters into killing him, believing they were being taught a magic trick and would be brought back to life. They had to flee Iolcos after this blood killing and sought refuge in Corinth. Here Jason fell for the King's daughter, Creusa. Medea, so enraged at this betrayal after everything she had done for him killed Creusa and her father, King Creon. In a terrible denouement she even killed her children. A broken Jason lived on Corinth until his old friend Peleus persuaded him to return to Iolcos and overthrow Acastus, the King. They managed this and he was finally on the throne of Iolcos. This didn't last long however as one day, asleep under the Argo, a rotten beam fell on him and killed him. It was an ironic twist as he was warned years before during the voyage to repair the damage caused during the crossing of the Bosporus, but who knew this would be the deadly outcome.

target.name: Calydonian Boar
target.notes: Killed Ancaeus in his vineyard when he returned from the quest for the Golden Fleece.

target.name: Atalanta
target.notes: Abandoned by her father Schoeneues because he wanted a boy and heir. She was left on Mount Parthenion to die, but she was discovered by a she-bear who had just lost her cubs, so instead of eating her, she raised her. She was taken in by a group of hunters later who named her Atalanta, meaning "equal in weight", i.e. she was man's equal. She quickly learned and surpassed her teachers in the skills of hunting and dedicated herself to the Olympian Artemis, goddess of chastity and hunting. She joined the hunt for the Calydonian Boar to prove herself the greatest hero of the age. After she had killed the boar she was taken back in her father, certainly not the last time a  parent was to reclaim a famous and successful child. He wanted her to marry to keep the kingdom in the family but being a disciple of Artemis she refused. "I will only marry a man who can best me in a foot race" she said. Being the fastest in the land she knew this was an impossible task. Hippomenes was the one who finally beat her in a race, thanks to Aphrodite's help. They were married soon after but Hippomenes had failed to thank Aphrodite for her help and she cursed the couple into making love in a temple sacred to the goddess Cybele. So outraged was Cybele she transformed them into lions who the Greeks believed couldn't mate with each other. They lived out their lives drawing Cybele's chariot, closely coupled but denied the pleasure of sex for eternity.

source.name: Hippocoön
source.notes: King of Sparta, he aided his friend Neleus during his battle with Heracles. Heracles took revenge by killing him and his sons and installing his older brother Tyndareus, the rightful King of Sparta who Hippocoön had ousted, on the throne. This would cause devestating consequences in the upcoming Trojan war.

source.name: Alcyoneus
source.notes: Stole Helios' cattle which kickstarted the Gigantomachy - the war of the Giants. He scaled Olympus and tried to rape Hera but Heracles arrived just in time to stop him. He buried him under Vesuvius where he grumbles to this day.

target.name: Gaia
target.notes: Mother Earth. Progenitor of the first generation of Titans.

source.name: Achelous
source.notes: River god who tried to woo Deianira. Heracles had promised her brother Meleager that he would be the one to marry her so he wrestled him into submission breaking one of his horns in the process. To get it back, Achelous offered in exchange the fabled Horn of Plenty, or Cornucopia.

target.name: Oceanus
target.notes: God of the earth-encircling River Oceanus, the source of all of the earth's fresh water.

target.name: Tethys

target.name: Deianira
target.notes: Sister of Meleager who wanted Heracles to join his bloodline, so he persuaded him to marry her. She lived a happy life married to Heracles but was tricked by Nessus, the centaur who survived the fight with Heracles into giving him his blood stained shirt. The blood was that of Hydra, and was deadly posionous. After giving him the shirt he died the most agonising death and she killed herself as a result.

source.name: Oeneus
source.notes: Father-in-law to Heracles, during a feast Heracles killed his cupbearer for spilling wine on him. He was the King of Calydon, it was his excessive worship of the god Dionysus that so enraged Artemis which caused her to send the Calydonian Boar to terrorise his kingdom. He sent out a call for someone to kill the beast who would go down as 'the greatest hero of the age'. That hero was Atalanta.

target.name: Calydonian Boar
target.notes: Killed Ancaeus in his vineyard when he returned from the quest for the Golden Fleece.

target.name: Jason
target.notes: Smuggled out of Iolcos when he was a baby due to Pelias and Neleus laying siege to the city believeing they were the rightful heirs to the throne and not his father, Aeson. He was brought up by his mother's (Alcimede) friend, the great centaur, Chiron. Met Bellerophon, who was seeking help from Chiron for Pegasus burned skin at the hands of Chimera. He filled his head with heroic feats which influenced Jason in his formative years. When his tutelage with Chiron was finished he ventured back to Iolcos. On the journey he lost a sandal helping an old lady (Hera in disguise) across a river. It was prophecised to Pelias to beware of a man arriving from the country with one sandal so when he arrived in Iolcos, Pelias knew immediately who he was. Pelias agreed to let him take the throne but lied to him, telling him the land was cursed and that the only way to lift the curse was to retrieve the Golden Fleece. He arranged a mighty ship, the Argo, and a great crew, the Argonauts, to sail to Colchis and retrieve the fleece. When the Argonauts arrived at Colchis, King Aeëtes demanded three tests of Jason before he could take it. To tame the fire breathing bulls, the Khalkotauroi, to sow some dragon's teeth from Cadmus and defeat the army that sprouts from the ground, and to kill the dragon that guards the fleece. He managed these feats thanks to his new lover, Medea, whom Hera had had Eros strike her with his cupid's arrow. They escaped with the fleece back to Pelias where they realised he was never going to give up the throne so Medea tricked his nine daughters into killing him, believing they were being taught a magic trick and would be brought back to life. They had to flee Iolcos after this blood killing and sought refuge in Corinth. Here Jason fell for the King's daughter, Creusa. Medea, so enraged at this betrayal after everything she had done for him killed Creusa and her father, King Creon. In a terrible denouement she even killed her children. A broken Jason lived on Corinth until his old friend Peleus persuaded him to return to Iolcos and overthrow Acastus, the King. They managed this and he was finally on the throne of Iolcos. This didn't last long however as one day, asleep under the Argo, a rotten beam fell on him and killed him. It was an ironic twist as he was warned years before during the voyage to repair the damage caused during the crossing of the Bosporus, but who knew this would be the deadly outcome.

source.name: Hebe
source.notes: Hera's cupbearer she bestowed her hand to Heracles upon his death to be his eternal wife.

target.name: Hera
target.god_of: Queen of the Gods, god of Marriage, Women, the Sky & Stars of Heaven
target.notes: Swallowed by Kronos when born due to Ouranos' curse on him that "Your own children will overthrow you as you overthrew me". Married to Zeus.

source.name: Atreus
source.notes: The Heraclides, children of Heracles, installed Atreus on the deposed Eurystheus' throne.

target.name: Pelops
target.notes: King of Pisa in the Peloponnese. Murdered by his father and offered to the gods during a feast. The gods were so angered they dispatched Tantalus to Tartarus for eternity and brought Pelops back to life, endowing him with a new shoulder made of ivory to replace the one that was mistakenly eaten. He took in Laius as a baby who was smuggled out of Thebes when his father, Labdacus was overthrown. Laius took Pelops' son, Chrysippus with him when he finally returned to Thebes to reclaim his throne. This wasn't a consensual relationship so Chrysippus took his own life. Pelops swore a curse on Laius and his line for ever.

source.name: Bellerophon
source.notes: Tamed the winged horse Pegasus, from which point on they would never be separated. Accidentally killed his brother, Deliades, during a hunting trip. He sought penance with King Proetus of Mycenae whose wife, Stheneboea, forced herself on Bellerophon but he refused her charms and insulted her in the process. He was sent to Iobates with a sealed letter detailing the false allegations. Iobates decided to get rid of Bellerophon by getting him to kill Chimera. He managed to defeat Chimera with an arrow of lead which melted inside Chimera's body after she breathed fire. He was sent on more and more dangerous missions until he realised that Iobates had meant him harm all along. He was confronted by the citizens of Iobates' kingdom and without Pegasus, he was unable to defend himself. He prayed to his father Poseidon who flooded the local river Xanthus to show them that he was protected by the gods. When Iobates saw this he realised the letter must be false. He cleared up the whole mess and even married his daughter, Philonoë. When Stheneboea heard about the marriage she realised her deceit had been uncovered and she hung herself. Bellerophon grew into quite an arrogant and vain man. One day he flew with Pegasus to Olympus believing that he'd be welcomed due to his divine parentage. Zeus punished his hubris by striking Pegasus with a gadfly. Bellerophon landed on the rocks below and crushed his hip, Pegasus was kept on Olympus by Zeus to carry his thunderbolts. Bellerophon lived out his final days as a crippled, bitter and lonely man.

target.name: Poseidon
target.god_of: God of Seas, Earthquakes, Floods, Droughts & Horses
target.notes: Swallowed by Kronos when born due to Ouranos' curse on him that "Your own children will overthrow you as you overthrew me". Giften the weapon of a Trident by the Cyclopes.

target.name: Pegasus
target.notes: Child of Poseidon and Medusa, was held in Medusa's womb when she was punished by Athena until Perseus beheaded her and Pegasus emerged as a shimmering white, winged horse. He first went to Mount Helicon where he struck his hoof on the ground and water bubbled up to become the famous Hippocrene, horse fountain. Ended up at Corinth where he was tamed by Bellerophon. He was always at Bellerophons' side during his many heroic feats until the day hubris got the better of Bellerophon and he flew up to Olympus believing he'd be welcomed due to his divine parentage. Instead Zeus punished his arrogance by striking him down onto the rocks below, and keeping Pegasus on Olympus to carry his thunderbolts.

target.name: Chimera
target.notes: A two-headed monster with a lion's body and head, a goat's head rising from its back, the udders of a goat, and a serpent's tail. Killed by the hero Bellerophon.

source.name: Deliades
source.notes: Brother or step-brother of Bellerophon. He was accidentally killed by Bellerophon during a hunting trip.

target.name: Eurynome
target.notes: nan

source.name: Deliades
source.notes: Brother or step-brother of Bellerophon. He was accidentally killed by Bellerophon during a hunting trip.

target.name: Glaucus
target.notes: King of Corinth, father, or step-father (Posedion being the father, we don't know for sure), of Bellerophon.

source.name: Polyidus
source.notes: Priest and seer who told Bellerophon to ask Athena's help to tame Pegasus.

target.name: Bellerophon
target.notes: Tamed the winged horse Pegasus, from which point on they would never be separated. Accidentally killed his brother, Deliades, during a hunting trip. He sought penance with King Proetus of Mycenae whose wife, Stheneboea, forced herself on Bellerophon but he refused her charms and insulted her in the process. He was sent to Iobates with a sealed letter detailing the false allegations. Iobates decided to get rid of Bellerophon by getting him to kill Chimera. He managed to defeat Chimera with an arrow of lead which melted inside Chimera's body after she breathed fire. He was sent on more and more dangerous missions until he realised that Iobates had meant him harm all along. He was confronted by the citizens of Iobates' kingdom and without Pegasus, he was unable to defend himself. He prayed to his father Poseidon who flooded the local river Xanthus to show them that he was protected by the gods. When Iobates saw this he realised the letter must be false. He cleared up the whole mess and even married his daughter, Philonoë. When Stheneboea heard about the marriage she realised her deceit had been uncovered and she hung herself. Bellerophon grew into quite an arrogant and vain man. One day he flew with Pegasus to Olympus believing that he'd be welcomed due to his divine parentage. Zeus punished his hubris by striking Pegasus with a gadfly. Bellerophon landed on the rocks below and crushed his hip, Pegasus was kept on Olympus by Zeus to carry his thunderbolts. Bellerophon lived out his final days as a crippled, bitter and lonely man.

source.name: Aethra
source.notes: Was engaged to the hero Bellerophon until he accidentally killed his brother, Deliades, during a hunting trip.

target.name: Pittheus
target.notes: King of Troezen, a small city state in the Peloponnese. His daughter was engaged to the hero Bellerophon until he accidentally killed his brother Deliades during a hunting trip.

source.name: Proetus
source.notes: King of Mycenae. Bellerophon sought penance at his palace for the accidental blood killing of his brother, Deliades, during a hunting trip. His wife, Stheneboea, had forced herself on Bellerophon but he had turned her down and insulted her in the process. She then tricked Proetus into thinking it was Bellerophon who had forced himself on her. He was in a quandry because refusing Bellerophon xenia, or hospitality, was also an affront to the gods. So he came up with the cunning plan of sending him to Lycia to see his brother-in-law, Iobates, with a sealed letter detailing the alleged crime.

Bellerophon lived out his final days as a crippled, bitter and lonely man.

source.name: Stheneboea
source.notes: Queen of Mycenae. She forced herself on Bellerophon whilst he was staying at their palace. Bellerophon refused her charms and insulted her in the process, claiming she wasn't attractive enough. She took revenge by claiming it was Bellerophon who had forced himself on her. Years later when she heard that her deceit had been uncovered, she hung herself.

target.name: Iobates
target.notes: King of Lycia. Bellerophon was sent to him with a sealed letter which detailed the false allegation by Stheneboea that Bellerophon had forced himself on her. After opening the letter he decided to get rid of Bellerophon by getting him to kill Chimera, the two-headed monster. When he managed the heroic feat he sent him on more and more dangerous missions which culminated in him ordering his own citizens to take up arms against him. When Bellerophon realised that Iobates had meant him harm all along he prayed to his father Poseidon to help him. Poseidon flooded the local river Xanthus to prove that Bellerophon was protected by the gods. Iobates realised the letter must be false and the whole mess was cleared up.

Years later when she heard that her deceit had been uncovered, she hung herself.

source.name: Oeagrus
source.notes: Thracian King. Father or step-father of Orpheus.

target.name: Calliope
target.notes: The Muses were the gods of music, song and dance and the source of inspiration to poets. Each muse was assigned a specific artistic influence.

source.name: Eurydice
source.notes: Wife of Orpheus. She was a reward for Orpheus' bravery and loyalty during the quest for the Golden Fleece. She was pursued by Aristaeus but she escaped and fell into a ditch where she was bitten and killed by an adder.

target.name: Orpheus
target.notes: The greatest musician of the ancient world. He was rewarded for his bravery in the quest for the Golden Fleece with a wife, Eurydice. One day she was pursued by Aristaeus and she fell into a ditch trying to escape and was bitten by an adder and died. The grief caused Orpheus to stop playing his beautiful music, even the Gods wept. Finally his father Apollo told him to retrieve Eurydice from the underworld with a lyre strung with hairs from his own head. His mellifluous playing won over the hound of hell, Cerberus, and Charon, the ferryman of the dead, which enabled him to enter the palace of Hades itself. Queen of the underworld, Persephone, convinced her husband to let Orpheus play one song and if it moves them they shall release Eurydice. He played the most amazing song that transformed the underworld into a place of light and love. Hades agreed to let Eurydice go but on one condition, that she must follow ten paces behind and if he turns around to look at her, she will be kept in the underworld. He kept the correct pace right until the edge of the underworld, but unbeknownst to him, his last few steps had accelerated into a run, Eurydice, too far behind was still not over the threshold of the underworld when Orpheus looked back in triumph and she was pulled back into the darkness. Orpheus lived out the rest of his life shunning any advances from women eventually sparking the ire of the Ciconians, followers of Dionysus who found his music an affront to their dark dances. They tore him apart in a Bacchic frenzy. His head ended up on the island of Lesbos where it was taken to a cave where people would come from all around to seek guidance and to hear his music once more. Apollo, jealous that the shrine was becoming more popular than his own Delphic oracle, finally silenced him. Finally at peace, his spirit descended to the underworld where he could be with Eurydice at last.

source.name: Eurydice
source.notes: Wife of Orpheus. She was a reward for Orpheus' bravery and loyalty during the quest for the Golden Fleece. She was pursued by Aristaeus but she escaped and fell into a ditch where she was bitten and killed by an adder.

target.name: Aristaeus
target.god_of: God of Cheesemaking, Beekeeping, Hunting & Olive-growing
target.notes: Minor deity of bee-keeping, agriculture and other country crafts. He pursued Orpheus' wife, Eurydice. She ran away and fell into a ditch where she was bitten by an adder and killed. Thus began the hero Orpheus' quest to retrieve her from the underworld.

source.name: Hymen
source.notes: Minor deity of song, he gave us the word hymn. He was one of the Erotes, responsible for weddings and the marriage bed. He failed to bless the marriage of Eurydice and Orpheus.

target.name: Urania
target.notes: The Muses were the gods of music, song and dance and the source of inspiration to poets. Each muse was assigned a specific artistic influence.

source.name: Hymen
source.notes: Minor deity of song, he gave us the word hymn. He was one of the Erotes, responsible for weddings and the marriage bed. He failed to bless the marriage of Eurydice and Orpheus.

target.name: Apollo
target.god_of: God of Mathematics, reason, logic, poetry, medicine, knowledge, prophecy, archery & music
target.notes: He kills a Python sent by Hera to eat him and his sister. The Python came from the landing site of the magnetite stone that Kronos ate thinking it was the infant Zeus. As the Python was born of Gaia and under divine protection he had to be punished by Zeus. He was exiled for eight years to the snake's birthplace beneath Mount Parnassus to replace the snake as guardian of the Omphalos (the spiritual centre of Greece, whose name he would change to Delphi and establish an oracle where anyone could come to ask the god or his appointed priestess, known as a Sibyl or Pythia, questions about the future) and to atone for his crime. Here he would go on to organise The Pythian Games every four years. Apollo was gifted music by Hermes (a tortoise shell with cow guts as strings, the first lyre) as a show of repentence after he stole Apollo's cattle.

source.name: Jason
source.notes: Smuggled out of Iolcos when he was a baby due to Pelias and Neleus laying siege to the city believeing they were the rightful heirs to the throne and not his father, Aeson. He was brought up by his mother's (Alcimede) friend, the great centaur, Chiron. Met Bellerophon, who was seeking help from Chiron for Pegasus burned skin at the hands of Chimera. He filled his head with heroic feats which influenced Jason in his formative years. When his tutelage with Chiron was finished he ventured back to Iolcos. On the journey he lost a sandal helping an old lady (Hera in disguise) across a river. It was prophecised to Pelias to beware of a man arriving from the country with one sandal so when he arrived in Iolcos, Pelias knew immediately who he was. Pelias agreed to let him take the throne but lied to him, telling him the land was cursed and that the only way to lift the curse was to retrieve the Golden Fleece. He arranged a mighty ship, the Argo, and a great crew, the Argonauts, to sail to Colchis and retrieve the fleece. When the Argonauts arrived at Colchis, King Aeëtes demanded three tests of Jason before he could take it. To tame the fire breathing bulls, the Khalkotauroi, to sow some dragon's teeth from Cadmus and defeat the army that sprouts from the ground, and to kill the dragon that guards the fleece. He managed these feats thanks to his new lover, Medea, whom Hera had had Eros strike her with his cupid's arrow. They escaped with the fleece back to Pelias where they realised he was never going to give up the throne so Medea tricked his nine daughters into killing him, believing they were being taught a magic trick and would be brought back to life. They had to flee Iolcos after this blood killing and sought refuge in Corinth. Here Jason fell for the King's daughter, Creusa. Medea, so enraged at this betrayal after everything she had done for him killed Creusa and her father, King Creon. In a terrible denouement she even killed her children. A broken Jason lived on Corinth until his old friend Peleus persuaded him to return to Iolcos and overthrow Acastus, the King. They managed this and he was finally on the throne of Iolcos. This didn't last long however as one day, asleep under the Argo, a rotten beam fell on him and killed him. It was an ironic twist as he was warned years before during the voyage to repair the damage caused during the crossing of the Bosporus, but who knew this would be the deadly outcome.

target.name: Aeson
target.notes: Rightful heir to the throne of Iolcos but when his father, Cretheus, died, his half-brothers Pelias and Neleus laid siege to the city. Fearing the city was lost he smuggled out his first-born child, Jason. He was imprisoned by Pelias when the siege was lost. He died whilst Jason was retrieving the Golden Fleece, possibly at the hands of Pelias, but we cannot be sure.

A broken Jason lived on Corinth until his old friend Peleus persuaded him to return to Iolcos and overthrow Acastus, the King. They managed this and he was finally on the throne of Iolcos. This didn't last long however as one day, asleep under the Argo, a rotten beam fell on him and killed him. It was an ironic twist as he was warned years before during the voyage to repair the damage caused during the crossing of the Bosporus, but who knew this would be the deadly outcome.

target.notes: Possibly taught Dionysus how to make wine from grapes.

It was an ironic twist as he was warned years before during the voyage to repair the damage caused during the crossing of the Bosporus, but who knew this would be the deadly outcome.

target.name: Heracles
target.notes: Born Alcides, son of Zeus and Alcmene. Zeus had wanted a child in the blood line of Perseus as Hera had prophecised that a child of Perseus would save the Olympians. Hera was so incensed at yet another affair of Zeus that she swore eternal enmity against Alcides. Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

target.name: Pelias
target.notes: He had nine daughters, the most beautiful, Alcestis, was promised only to the man who was able to harness a boar and a lion to a chariot. Admetus, with help from his friend and lover Apollo, was the only one who managed this feat, and the two were wed. Believed he was the rightful heir to the throne of Iolcos when King Cretheus died (Cretheus' wife, Tyro, was his mother by the sea god Poseidon). He besieged Iolcos alongside his brother Neleus which caused the rightful heir, Aeson, to smuggle out his firstborn child, Jason, of Golden Fleece fame. He slaughtered everyone connected to Cretheus and imprisoned Aeson and his wife Alcimede. He also killed Sidero, Cretheus' second wife, who mistreated his mother, but he mistakenly did this in a temple dedicated to Hera, the Queen of Heaven. She swore revenge, of all the gods she was the most dangerous an enemy, just ask Heracles. Pelias, troubled by this, seeks advice from an oracle who informs him that "One of your own blood will end your life, beware the man who comes from the country wearing but one sandal". The prophecy came true one fateful day when Jason wandered into the city. He had lost a sandal on the journey helping an old woman (Hera in disguise) across a river. Pelias, terrified, tricked agreed to let him have the throne but told him that the land was cursed and the only way to lift the curse was to retrieve the Golden Fleece.

source.name: Jason
source.notes: Smuggled out of Iolcos when he was a baby due to Pelias and Neleus laying siege to the city believeing they were the rightful heirs to the throne and not his father, Aeson. It was an ironic twist as he was warned years before during the voyage to repair the damage caused during the crossing of the Bosporus, but who knew this would be the deadly outcome.

target.name: Bellerophon
target.notes: Tamed the winged horse Pegasus, from which point on they would never be separated. Accidentally killed his brother, Deliades, during a hunting trip. He sought penance with King Proetus of Mycenae whose wife, Stheneboea, forced herself on Bellerophon but he refused her charms and insulted her in the process. He was sent to Iobates with a sealed letter detailing the false allegations. Iobates decided to get rid of Bellerophon by getting him to kill Chimera. He managed to defeat Chimera with an arrow of lead which melted inside Chimera's body after she breathed fire. He was sent on more and more dangerous missions until he realised that Iobates had meant him harm all along. He was confronted by the citizens of Iobates' kingdom and without Pegasus, he was unable to defend himself. He prayed to his father Poseidon who flooded the local river Xanthus to show them that he was protected by the gods. When Iobates saw this he realised the letter must be false. He cleared up the whole mess and even married his daughter, Philonoë. When Stheneboea heard about the marriage she realised her deceit had been uncovered and she hung herself. Bellerophon grew into quite an arrogant and vain man. One day he flew with Pegasus to Olympus believing that he'd be welcomed due to his divine parentage. Zeus punished his hubris by striking Pegasus with a gadfly. Bellerophon landed on the rocks below and crushed his hip, Pegasus was kept on Olympus by Zeus to carry his thunderbolts. Bellerophon lived out his final days as a crippled, bitter and lonely man.

source.name: Bisaltes
source.notes: Founder hero of the Bisaltae peoples of Thrace.

target.name: Gaia
target.notes: Mother Earth. Progenitor of the first generation of Titans.

source.name: Bisaltes
source.notes: Founder hero of the Bisaltae peoples of Thrace.

target.name: Helios
target.notes: Would become the sun's sole charioteer after Apollo gave up the job when his son Phaeton died trying to drive it. He mocked Phaeton for trying to drive the sun chariot, letting out a high-pitched hysterical squeak when he heard the ridiculous nature of his plan. The same high-pitched squeak that you get when you breathe in the gas named after him, helium.

source.name: Theophane
source.notes: She caught the eye of Poseidon who took her to the island of Crinissa where he turned himself into a ram and Theophane into a ewe. She gave birth to a golden ram.

target.name: Bisaltes

source.name: Theophane

target.name: Poseidon
target.god_of: God of Seas, Earthquakes, Floods, Droughts & Horses
target.notes: Swallowed by Kronos when born due to Ouranos' curse on him that "Your own children will overthrow you as you overthrew me". Giften the weapon of a Trident by the Cyclopes.

source.name: Learchus
source.notes: Son of Athamas and Ino. Ino wanted them to take the throne of Boetia and not her step-children Phrixus and Helle so she contrived a famine and told Athamas that he must sacrifice Phrixus to end it. Athamas eventually found out and killed Learchus in the ensuing frenzy.

target.name: Ino
target.notes: She suckled her sister Semele's child by Zeus (the infant Dionysus). Married King Athamas of Boetia. She wanted her own children and not her step-children Phrixus and Helle to take the throne of Boetia so she contrived a famine and claimed that only the sacrifice of Phrixus would end it (Helle wouldn't be parted and agreed to die with him). When their mother Nephele heard about this she sent a golden ram to rescue them from the sacrifical altar. Athamas eventually discovered her wicked plot and killed her son Learchus in the ensuing frenzy. He cornered Ino and her other child, Melicertes and they threw themselves over the cliffs in despair. Dionysus, ever grateful to his step-mother, transformed her into the immortal Leucothea, the 'white-goddess' of the sea.

source.name: Learchus
source.notes: Son of Athamas and Ino. Ino wanted them to take the throne of Boetia and not her step-children Phrixus and Helle so she contrived a famine and told Athamas that he must sacrifice Phrixus to end it. Athamas eventually found out and killed Learchus in the ensuing frenzy.

target.name: Athamas

Athamas eventually found out and killed his brother Learchus in the ensuing frenzy. Ino and Melicertes were cornered and threw themselves over the cliffs in despair. Dionysus, ever grateful to his foster-mother Ino, transformed Melicertes into Palaemon, a dolphin-riding deity and guardian of ships.

target.name: Dionysus
target.notes: Produced the world's first vintage from his lover and friend Ampelos (vine in Greek). Replaced Hestia in the quorum of twelve Olympians after she retired. The Gods were happy to have Dionysus for his wine and debauchery, all except Hera, as Dionysus was the result of Zeus's affair with Semele. Hera swore never to drink from Dionysus's cup and would later curse his son Priapus with ugliness and impotence.

source.name: Golden Ram
source.notes: Nephele sent the Golden Ram to rescue her children Phrixus and Helle from being sacrificed. Helle was killed when she fell from the ram but Phrixus survived and sacrificed the ram to Zeus and presented Aeëtes, King of Colchis, where Phrixus sought refuge, with its golden fleece. Zeus, pleased with the offering, raised the noble creature to the firmament as Aries, the Ram.

source.name: Aeson
source.notes: Rightful heir to the throne of Iolcos but when his father, Cretheus, died, his half-brothers Pelias and Neleus laid siege to the city. Fearing the city was lost he smuggled out his first-born child, Jason. He was imprisoned by Pelias when the siege was lost. He died whilst Jason was retrieving the Golden Fleece, possibly at the hands of Pelias, but we cannot be sure.

target.name: Cretheus
target.notes: Ruler of Iolcos, a city in the north west Greek mainland. His death caused a power struggle because his son Aeson was the rightful heir, but Aeson's half-brothers, Pelias and Neleus, believed the throne should be theirs.

source.name: Aeson
source.notes: Rightful heir to the throne of Iolcos but when his father, Cretheus, died, his half-brothers Pelias and Neleus laid siege to the city. Fearing the city was lost he smuggled out his first-born child, Jason. He was imprisoned by Pelias when the siege was lost. He died whilst Jason was retrieving the Golden Fleece, possibly at the hands of Pelias, but we cannot be sure.

target.name: Tyro
target.notes: Wife of Sisyphus and daughter of his brother Salmoneus (yes, he married his niece). Sisyphus only married her because the Delphic Oracle told Sisyphus that "Sons of Sisyphus and Tyro rise to slay Salmoneus". Salmoneus was his brother whom he despised more than anything. One day Tyro found out the real reason for their marriage. Feeling a stronger attachment to her father rather than her husband, she drowned their children in the river before fleeing back to her father.

source.name: Aeson
source.notes: Rightful heir to the throne of Iolcos but when his father, Cretheus, died, his half-brothers Pelias and Neleus laid siege to the city. He slaughtered everyone connected to Cretheus and imprisoned Aeson and his wife Alcimede. He also killed Sidero, Cretheus' second wife, who mistreated his mother, but he mistakenly did this in a temple dedicated to Hera, the Queen of Heaven. She swore revenge, of all the gods she was the most dangerous an enemy, just ask Heracles. Pelias, troubled by this, seeks advice from an oracle who informs him that "One of your own blood will end your life, beware the man who comes from the country wearing but one sandal". The prophecy came true one fateful day when Jason wandered into the city. He had lost a sandal on the journey helping an old woman (Hera in disguise) across a river. Pelias, terrified, tricked agreed to let him have the throne but told him that the land was cursed and the only way to lift the curse was to retrieve the Golden Fleece.

source.name: Promachus

He died whilst Jason was retrieving the Golden Fleece, possibly at the hands of Pelias, but we cannot be sure.

source.name: Sidero
source.notes: Second wife of Cretheus, King of Iolcos. She mistreated Cretheus' first wife, Tyro. When Cretheus died, Pelias, son of Tyro, laid siege to the city believing the throne should be his. He killed Sidero in revenge in a temple dedicated to Hera, thus incurring the wrath of the most vengeful of gods.

target.name: Cretheus
target.notes: Ruler of Iolcos, a city in the north west Greek mainland. His death caused a power struggle because his son Aeson was the rightful heir, but Aeson's half-brothers, Pelias and Neleus, believed the throne should be theirs.

source.name: Sidero
source.notes: Second wife of Cretheus, King of Iolcos. She mistreated Cretheus' first wife, Tyro. When Cretheus died, Pelias, son of Tyro, laid siege to the city believing the throne should be his. He killed Sidero in revenge in a temple dedicated to Hera, thus incurring the wrath of the most vengeful of gods.

target.name: Pelias
target.notes: He had nine daughters, the most beautiful, Alcestis, was promised only to the man who was able to harness a boar and a lion to a chariot. source.name: Argus
source.notes: Shipwright. Was commisioned by Jason to craft a vessel to help him the retrieve the Golden Fleece. The ship was named after its creator, the Argo.

target.name: Darnaus
target.notes: King of Argos.

source.name: Argus
source.notes: Shipwright. Was commisioned by Jason to craft a vessel to help him the retrieve the Golden Fleece. The ship was named after its creator, the Argo.

target.name: Jason
target.notes: Smuggled out of Iolcos when he was a baby due to Pelias and Neleus laying siege to the city believeing they were the rightful heirs to the throne and not his father, Aeson. He was brought up by his mother's (Alcimede) friend, the great centaur, Chiron. Met Bellerophon, who was seeking help from Chiron for Pegasus burned skin at the hands of Chimera. He filled his head with heroic feats which influenced Jason in his formative years. When his tutelage with Chiron was finished he ventured back to Iolcos. On the journey he lost a sandal helping an old lady (Hera in disguise) across a river. It was prophecised to Pelias to beware of a man arriving from the country with one sandal so when he arrived in Iolcos, Pelias knew immediately who he was. Pelias agreed to let him take the throne but lied to him, telling him the land was cursed and that the only way to lift the curse was to retrieve the Golden Fleece. He arranged a mighty ship, the Argo, and a great crew, the Argonauts, to sail to Colchis and retrieve the fleece. When the Argonauts arrived at Colchis, King Aeëtes demanded three tests of Jason before he could take it. To tame the fire breathing bulls, the Khalkotauroi, to sow some dragon's teeth from Cadmus and defeat the army that sprouts from the ground, and to kill the dragon that guards the fleece. He managed these feats thanks to his new lover, Medea, whom Hera had had Eros strike her with his cupid's arrow. They escaped with the fleece back to Pelias where they realised he was never going to give up the throne so Medea tricked his nine daughters into killing him, believing they were being taught a magic trick and would be brought back to life. They had to flee Iolcos after this blood killing and sought refuge in Corinth. Here Jason fell for the King's daughter, Creusa. Medea, so enraged at this betrayal after everything she had done for him killed Creusa and her father, King Creon. In a terrible denouement she even killed her children. A broken Jason lived on Corinth until his old friend Peleus persuaded him to return to Iolcos and overthrow Acastus, the King. They managed this and he was finally on the throne of Iolcos. This didn't last long however as one day, asleep under the Argo, a rotten beam fell on him and killed him. It was an ironic twist as he was warned years before during the voyage to repair the damage caused during the crossing of the Bosporus, but who knew this would be the deadly outcome.

source.name: Idmon
source.notes: A mortal seer and son of Apollo. He agreed to be one of Jason's Argonauts on the quest for the Golden Fleece. He foresaw fame but also an early death in the venture. He was gored to death by a boar in Mariandynia where the Argo had docked.

target.name: Apollo
target.god_of: God of Mathematics, reason, logic, poetry, medicine, knowledge, prophecy, archery & music
target.notes: He kills a Python sent by Hera to eat him and his sister. The Python came from the landing site of the magnetite stone that Kronos ate thinking it was the infant Zeus. As the Python was born of Gaia and under divine protection he had to be punished by Zeus. He was exiled for eight years to the snake's birthplace beneath Mount Parnassus to replace the snake as guardian of the Omphalos (the spiritual centre of Greece, whose name he would change to Delphi and establish an oracle where anyone could come to ask the god or his appointed priestess, known as a Sibyl or Pythia, questions about the future) and to atone for his crime. Here he would go on to organise The Pythian Games every four years. Apollo was gifted music by Hermes (a tortoise shell with cow guts as strings, the first lyre) as a show of repentence after he stole Apollo's cattle.

source.name: Tiphys
source.notes: Helmsman of the Argo and one of Jason's Argonauts. He succumbed to fever on the voyage.

source.name: Ancaeus
source.notes: King of Samos. Helsman of the Argo and one of Jason's Argonauts. He planted a vine before leaving for the voyage and prayed that it would harvest a beautiful vintage. The island's seer told him that he would return but he would never taste the vineyard's wine. Upon his return from the quest the vineyard had fluorished, Samos is now famous for its wine. He raised a cup of wine in a mocking fashion to the seer but was warned that "there's many a slip 'twixt cup and lip". Soon after he heard a commotion in the vineyard, a wild boar was destorying his grapes. He tried to subdue the boar but was gored to death in the process.

source.name: Hylas
source.notes: Beloved young page of Heracles. He joined him onboard the Argo on the quest for the Golden Fleece. He was taken by some water nymphs when the Argo was docked. A distraught Heracles abandoned the quest for the Golden Fleece and resumed his labours.

target.name: Heracles
target.notes: Born Alcides, son of Zeus and Alcmene. Zeus had wanted a child in the blood line of Perseus as Hera had prophecised that a child of Perseus would save the Olympians. Hera was so incensed at yet another affair of Zeus that she swore eternal enmity against Alcides. Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

Heracles friend Telamon never forgot this and told Heracles years later. Heracles took his revenge by killing them. He constructed two pillars to mark their graves on the island of Tenos which were said to sway whenever the North Wind blew.

He constructed two pillars to mark their graves on the island of Tenos which were said to sway whenever the North Wind blew.

target.name: Heracles
target.notes: Born Alcides, son of Zeus and Alcmene. Zeus had wanted a child in the blood line of Perseus as Hera had prophecised that a child of Perseus would save the Olympians. Hera was so incensed at yet another affair of Zeus that she swore eternal enmity against Alcides. Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

source.name: Calais
source.notes: Son of Boreas, the North Wind. Endowed with the ability to fly. Was one of Jason's Argonauts. He refused to go back and pick up Heracles, Polyphemus and Hylas when they inadvertently left them ashore (Hylas was lost, and Heracles and Polyphemus were searching for him). Heracles friend Telamon never forgot this and told Heracles years later. Heracles took his revenge by killing them. He constructed two pillars to mark their graves on the island of Tenos which were said to sway whenever the North Wind blew.

target.name: Jason
target.notes: Smuggled out of Iolcos when he was a baby due to Pelias and Neleus laying siege to the city believeing they were the rightful heirs to the throne and not his father, Aeson. He was brought up by his mother's (Alcimede) friend, the great centaur, Chiron. Met Bellerophon, who was seeking help from Chiron for Pegasus burned skin at the hands of Chimera. He filled his head with heroic feats which influenced Jason in his formative years. When his tutelage with Chiron was finished he ventured back to Iolcos. On the journey he lost a sandal helping an old lady (Hera in disguise) across a river. It was prophecised to Pelias to beware of a man arriving from the country with one sandal so when he arrived in Iolcos, Pelias knew immediately who he was. Pelias agreed to let him take the throne but lied to him, telling him the land was cursed and that the only way to lift the curse was to retrieve the Golden Fleece. He arranged a mighty ship, the Argo, and a great crew, the Argonauts, to sail to Colchis and retrieve the fleece. When the Argonauts arrived at Colchis, King Aeëtes demanded three tests of Jason before he could take it. To tame the fire breathing bulls, the Khalkotauroi, to sow some dragon's teeth from Cadmus and defeat the army that sprouts from the ground, and to kill the dragon that guards the fleece. He managed these feats thanks to his new lover, Medea, whom Hera had had Eros strike her with his cupid's arrow. They escaped with the fleece back to Pelias where they realised he was never going to give up the throne so Medea tricked his nine daughters into killing him, believing they were being taught a magic trick and would be brought back to life. They had to flee Iolcos after this blood killing and sought refuge in Corinth. Here Jason fell for the King's daughter, Creusa. Medea, so enraged at this betrayal after everything she had done for him killed Creusa and her father, King Creon. In a terrible denouement she even killed her children. A broken Jason lived on Corinth until his old friend Peleus persuaded him to return to Iolcos and overthrow Acastus, the King. They managed this and he was finally on the throne of Iolcos. This didn't last long however as one day, asleep under the Argo, a rotten beam fell on him and killed him. It was an ironic twist as he was warned years before during the voyage to repair the damage caused during the crossing of the Bosporus, but who knew this would be the deadly outcome.

source.name: Euphemus
source.notes: Son of Poseidon, he could walk on water. He was one of Jason's Argonauts.

target.name: Poseidon
target.god_of: God of Seas, Earthquakes, Floods, Droughts & Horses
target.notes: Swallowed by Kronos when born due to Ouranos' curse on him that "Your own children will overthrow you as you overthrew me". Giften the weapon of a Trident by the Cyclopes.

source.name: Aeolus
source.notes: Divine keeper of the winds. He kept the violent storm winds locked safely in his floating island of Aeolia, releasing them only at the command of the gods. Helped the Argo on its way on the quest for the Golden Fleece.

source.name: Hypsipyle
source.notes: Queen of Lemnos. Her people neglected the god Aphrodite so she made all the women smell so foul that the men wouldn't touch them and only married women from other islands. The women murdered all of the men on the island in revenge. The Argo anchored here on the quest for the Golden Fleece. The curse by that time was lifted and Hypsipyle and Jason got together and had twin sons, Euneus and Thoas. When Jason left to continue his quest, word had gotten out that Hysipyle had spared her father, Thoas, from the massacre of the menfolk. She escaped with her sons where they were captured by pirates and sold as slaves to King Lycurgus of Nemea.

target.name: Thoas
target.notes: Father of Queen Hypsipyle. She spared him when the women killed all of the menfolk on the island of Lemnos due to a curse put on them by Aphrodite. He found his way to Tauris on the Crimean peninsula where he was to play a part in the Trojan war.

source.notes: Queen of Doliones, on the coast of the Sea of Marmara. The Argo berthed here on the quest for the Golden Fleece. After enjoying friendly hospitality they set sail but a storm blew them back to port. Being dark, the two peoples didn't recognise each other and fierce fighting broke out. The Argonauts killed the Dolionians including King Cyzicus. When Queen Clite saw her dead husband she ran back into the palace and hanged herself.

target.name: Cyzicus

The Argonauts killed the Dolionians including King Cyzicus.

source.name: Clite
source.notes: Queen of Doliones, on the coast of the Sea of Marmara. The Argo berthed here on the quest for the Golden Fleece. After enjoying friendly hospitality they set sail but a storm blew them back to port. Being dark, the two peoples didn't recognise each other and fierce fighting broke out. The Argonauts killed the Dolionians including King Cyzicus. When Queen Clite saw her dead husband she ran back into the palace and hanged herself.

target.name: Jason
target.notes: Smuggled out of Iolcos when he was a baby due to Pelias and Neleus laying siege to the city believeing they were the rightful heirs to the throne and not his father, Aeson. He was brought up by his mother's (Alcimede) friend, the great centaur, Chiron. Met Bellerophon, who was seeking help from Chiron for Pegasus burned skin at the hands of Chimera. He filled his head with heroic feats which influenced Jason in his formative years. When his tutelage with Chiron was finished he ventured back to Iolcos. On the journey he lost a sandal helping an old lady (Hera in disguise) across a river. It was prophecised to Pelias to beware of a man arriving from the country with one sandal so when he arrived in Iolcos, Pelias knew immediately who he was. Pelias agreed to let him take the throne but lied to him, telling him the land was cursed and that the only way to lift the curse was to retrieve the Golden Fleece. He arranged a mighty ship, the Argo, and a great crew, the Argonauts, to sail to Colchis and retrieve the fleece. When the Argonauts arrived at Colchis, King Aeëtes demanded three tests of Jason before he could take it. To tame the fire breathing bulls, the Khalkotauroi, to sow some dragon's teeth from Cadmus and defeat the army that sprouts from the ground, and to kill the dragon that guards the fleece. He managed these feats thanks to his new lover, Medea, whom Hera had had Eros strike her with his cupid's arrow. They escaped with the fleece back to Pelias where they realised he was never going to give up the throne so Medea tricked his nine daughters into killing him, believing they were being taught a magic trick and would be brought back to life. They had to flee Iolcos after this blood killing and sought refuge in Corinth. Here Jason fell for the King's daughter, Creusa. Medea, so enraged at this betrayal after everything she had done for him killed Creusa and her father, King Creon. In a terrible denouement she even killed her children. A broken Jason lived on Corinth until his old friend Peleus persuaded him to return to Iolcos and overthrow Acastus, the King. They managed this and he was finally on the throne of Iolcos. This didn't last long however as one day, asleep under the Argo, a rotten beam fell on him and killed him. It was an ironic twist as he was warned years before during the voyage to repair the damage caused during the crossing of the Bosporus, but who knew this would be the deadly outcome.

source.name: Thrax
source.notes: A son of Ares, the god of war. His descendents were the fierce people of Thrace, modern day Bulgaria.

target.name: Ares
target.notes: He and Aphrodite would form a couple (Venus and Mars, love and war).

source.name: Glaucus
source.notes: Born a mortal fisherman in Boetia, but achieved divine status when he nibbled at a herb that he had observed to have the power to bring dead fish back to life. This gave him immortaility but caused him to grow fins and a fish's tail. From then on he was to be the patron god of fisherman, acting as guide to stricken sailors. He ordered the Argo to continue on its quest without Heracles, who they had inadventently left behind whilst he was looking for his lover, Hylas.

target.name: Poseidon
target.god_of: God of Seas, Earthquakes, Floods, Droughts & Horses
target.notes: Swallowed by Kronos when born due to Ouranos' curse on him that "Your own children will overthrow you as you overthrew me". Giften the weapon of a Trident by the Cyclopes.

source.name: Amycus
source.notes: King of Bebryces where the Argo docked on its quest for the Golden Fleece. He was defeated in a boxing match by one of the Argonauts, Polydeuces.

target.name: Polydeuces
target.notes: Twin of Castor. He was one of Jason's Argonauts.

source.name: Aello
source.notes: Aello, or 'storm' was one of the Harpies, meaning snatcher, flying women with human faces and wings and talons of birds.

target.name: Electra
target.notes: Oceanid mother of Iris, the rainbow goddess, and the Harpies.

target.name: Thaumas

source.name: Aello
source.notes: Aello, or 'storm' was one of the Harpies, meaning snatcher, flying women with human faces and wings and talons of birds.

target.name: Calais
target.notes: Son of Boreas, the North Wind. Endowed with the ability to fly. Was one of Jason's Argonauts. He refused to go back and pick up Heracles, Polyphemus and Hylas when they inadvertently left them ashore (Hylas was lost, and Heracles and Polyphemus were searching for him). Heracles friend Telamon never forgot this and told Heracles years later. Heracles took his revenge by killing them. He constructed two pillars to mark their graves on the island of Tenos which were said to sway whenever the North Wind blew.

source.name: Aello

target.name: Phineus
target.notes: King of Salmydessus. He was cursed by the Harpies who would steal his food. He was gifted with prophecy, but he would give his gift away too easily, the Oracles were supposed to be a cryptic people, hence the curse. When the Argo docked in his kingdom he told them it was prophecised that Calais and Zetus, two of the Argonauts and sons of Boreas, the North Wind would save him from them. They duly obliged and a close run fight ensued until it was broken up by Iris, the rainbow goddess. She told the Harpies to leave Phineus alone and the curse was lifted. As a reward Phineus told the Argonauts how to navigate the dangerous straits of the Bosporus.
