source.name: Argos
source.notes: Son of Phrixus and Chalciope. They were expelled by their grandfather, Aeëtes, for alledgedly plotting against him. They met the Argonauts during their escape. This was a fateful meeting because it was Phrixus who had gifted the Golden Fleece to Aeëtes. He decided to join the Argonauts and retrieve the fleece.

target.name: Phrixus
target.notes: His cruel step-mother Ino, wanted her own children to inherit the throne of Boetia so she contrived a famine and informed her husband King Athamas that the only way to end it was to sacrifice Phrixus (his sister Helle wouldn't be parted and agreed to be sacrificed alongside). When their mother Nephele heard about this she sent the Golden Ram to rescue them from the sacrifical altar.

target.name: Phrixus
target.notes: His cruel step-mother Ino, wanted her own children to inherit the throne of Boetia so she contrived a famine and informed her husband King Athamas that the only way to end it was to sacrifice Phrixus (his sister Helle wouldn't be parted and agreed to be sacrificed alongside). When their mother Nephele heard about this she sent the Golden Ram to rescue them from the sacrifical altar.

source.name: Circe
source.notes: A sorceress from Aeaea. She was asked to perform the cleansing ritual of the Argonauts after Medea had killed her own brother to get away from her father Aeëtes after retrieving the Golden Fleece. But when she found out the true horror of the crime she refused.

target.name: Helios
target.notes: Would become the sun's sole charioteer after Apollo gave up the job when his son Phaeton died trying to drive it. He mocked Phaeton for trying to drive the sun chariot, letting out a high-pitched hysterical squeak when he heard the ridiculous nature of his plan. The same high-pitched squeak that you get when you breathe in the gas named after him, helium.

target.name: Oceanus
target.notes: God of the earth-encircling River Oceanus, the source of all of the earth's fresh water.

source.name: Idyia
source.notes: Queen of Colchis, wife of Aeëtes.

target.name: Tethys
target.notes: Goddess of the sea.

source.name: Idyia
source.notes: Queen of Colchis, wife of Aeëtes.

target.name: Aeëtes
target.notes: King of Colchis. It was here that Phrixus landed after being rescued by the Golden Ram. Phrixus presented Aeëtes with the ram's golden fleece. When the Argonauts arrived at Colchis to claim the fleece, Aeëtes demanded three tests of Jason before he could take it. To tame the fire breathing bulls, the Khalkotauroi, to sow some dragon's teeth from Cadmus and defeat the army that sprouts from the ground, and to kill the dragon that guards the fleece.

source.name: Medea
source.notes: Follower of the goddess of magic, Hecate. Hera had her struck by Eros' arrow of love so she would fall in love with Jason and help him in his three tests to win the Golden Fleece. She made a lotion which made him fireproof and able to defeat the Khalkotauroi. She told him how to defeat the Spartoi, and she made a potion that put the dragon guarding the Golden Fleece to sleep. During the escape from Colchis she murdered her brother, Absyrtus, to prevent Aeëtes, their father, from catching them. When they returned the fleece to Pelias and realised he was not going to hand over his reign, she tricked his nine daughters, the Peliades, into killing him up thinking they were going to bring him back to life with special herbs. She and Jason had to flee afterward, it was after all, a blood killing. Took refuge with Jason in Corinth where Jason fell for the King's daughter, Creusa. Medea killed her and the King in and even killed her own children in an extreme act of revenge. After she escaped to Athens and married the king, Aegeus. When the hero Theseus turned up in Athens, Medea conspired to have him killed by poisoning him, wanting her own son Medus to be heir to the throne. When Aegeus found out that Theseus was his son, he managed to stop him from drinking the poison just in time. Medea fled Athens never to return.

target.name: Idyia

source.name: The Khalkotauroi
source.notes: A pair of bulls with mouths and hoofs of bronze. They were the fire-breathing creation of Hephaestus, a gift to King Aeëtus of Colchis. Aeëtes demanded that Jason tame the bulls as one of his tests to win the Golden Fleece. He managed to do so with the help of his lover Medea and some magic lotion that made him impervious to their fiery breath.

target.name: Hephaestus
target.god_of: God of  Fire, Blacksmiths, Artisans, Sculptors & Metalworkers
target.notes: To Hera's dismay, wanting to give birth to the greatest of the gods, saw the child was so ugly that she hurled him down Mount Olympus in disgust. He would forge a golden throne that would bind Hera and come and unlock it to get back to Olympus. He would wed Aphrodite as a reward.

source.name: Butes
source.notes: One of the Argonauts. He was a Sicilian King, recruited for his bee-keeping skills which helped the crew's rations taste better. He fell to the Sirens charm on the return voyage. The Sirens sang to entice sailors onto their rocky cliff home where they would feast on them. He was rescued from their grasp by Aphrodite who whisked him away to Marsala in his home kingdom of Sicily, a place now famous for its honey-sweet wine. They became lovers and they had a child, Eryx.

target.name: Aphrodite
target.god_of: God of Love, Beauty, Pleasure & Procreation
target.notes: Child of Ouranos' genitals as they "impregnated" the sea when discarded by Kronos. Hence the image of Aphrodite emerging from the sea on a scallop (Botticelli). Kept safe by Zeus in the Titan War.

target.name: Heracles
target.notes: Born Alcides, son of Zeus and Alcmene. Zeus had wanted a child in the blood line of Perseus as Hera had prophecised that a child of Perseus would save the Olympians. Hera was so incensed at yet another affair of Zeus that she swore eternal enmity against Alcides. Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

source.name: Alcinous
source.notes: King of Scheria, modern day Corfu. Helped the Argonauts on their way when the docked there but a fleet from Colchis, who were chasing them, demanded they be returned along with the Golden Fleece.

target.name: Jason
target.notes: Smuggled out of Iolcos when he was a baby due to Pelias and Neleus laying siege to the city believeing they were the rightful heirs to the throne and not his father, Aeson. He was brought up by his mother's (Alcimede) friend, the great centaur, Chiron. Met Bellerophon, who was seeking help from Chiron for Pegasus burned skin at the hands of Chimera. He filled his head with heroic feats which influenced Jason in his formative years. When his tutelage with Chiron was finished he ventured back to Iolcos. On the journey he lost a sandal helping an old lady (Hera in disguise) across a river. It was prophecised to Pelias to beware of a man arriving from the country with one sandal so when he arrived in Iolcos, Pelias knew immediately who he was. Pelias agreed to let him take the throne but lied to him, telling him the land was cursed and that the only way to lift the curse was to retrieve the Golden Fleece. He arranged a mighty ship, the Argo, and a great crew, the Argonauts, to sail to Colchis and retrieve the fleece. When the Argonauts arrived at Colchis, King Aeëtes demanded three tests of Jason before he could take it. To tame the fire breathing bulls, the Khalkotauroi, to sow some dragon's teeth from Cadmus and defeat the army that sprouts from the ground, and to kill the dragon that guards the fleece. He managed these feats thanks to his new lover, Medea, whom Hera had had Eros strike her with his cupid's arrow. They escaped with the fleece back to Pelias where they realised he was never going to give up the throne so Medea tricked his nine daughters into killing him, believing they were being taught a magic trick and would be brought back to life. They had to flee Iolcos after this blood killing and sought refuge in Corinth. Here Jason fell for the King's daughter, Creusa. Medea, so enraged at this betrayal after everything she had done for him killed Creusa and her father, King Creon. In a terrible denouement she even killed her children. A broken Jason lived on Corinth until his old friend Peleus persuaded him to return to Iolcos and overthrow Acastus, the King. They managed this and he was finally on the throne of Iolcos. This didn't last long however as one day, asleep under the Argo, a rotten beam fell on him and killed him. It was an ironic twist as he was warned years before during the voyage to repair the damage caused during the crossing of the Bosporus, but who knew this would be the deadly outcome.

source.name: Arete
source.notes: Queen of Scheria, modern day Corfu. Helped the Argonauts on their way when the docked there but a fleet from Colchis, who were chasing them, demanded they be returned along with the Golden Fleece.

source.name: Talos
source.notes: Protector of Crete, he was a huge bronze man who flung waves at pirates to protect the island. He attacked the Argo on its return with the Golden Fleece but Pirithous pulled out his nail that held in his ichor, the blood that runs in the veins of the gods.

target.name: Hephaestus
target.god_of: God of  Fire, Blacksmiths, Artisans, Sculptors & Metalworkers
target.notes: To Hera's dismay, wanting to give birth to the greatest of the gods, saw the child was so ugly that she hurled him down Mount Olympus in disgust. He would forge a golden throne that would bind Hera and come and unlock it to get back to Olympus. He would wed Aphrodite as a reward.

source.name: Talos
source.notes: Protector of Crete, he was a huge bronze man who flung waves at pirates to protect the island. He attacked the Argo on its return with the Golden Fleece but Pirithous pulled out his nail that held in his ichor, the blood that runs in the veins of the gods.

target.name: Pirithous
target.notes: King of the Lapiths and one of Jason's Argonauts. He heard of the exploits of Theseus and wanted to test them out. He raided his cattle and Theseus tracked him down, but instead of fighting it out they quickly realised they very much liked each other and so began one of the great friendships in Greek mythology. They had the crazy idea of kidnapping Persephone, Queen of the Underworld to be his wife. Hades had them cast into stone chairs, their buttocks glued to the seats. It wasn't until Heracles descended into the underworld during his twelfth labour to retrieve Cerberus, that they managed to be freed.

source.name: Alcimede
source.notes: nan

target.name: Pelias
target.notes: He had nine daughters, the most beautiful, Alcestis, was promised only to the man who was able to harness a boar and a lion to a chariot. Admetus, with help from his friend and lover Apollo, was the only one who managed this feat, and the two were wed. Believed he was the rightful heir to the throne of Iolcos when King Cretheus died (Cretheus' wife, Tyro, was his mother by the sea god Poseidon). He besieged Iolcos alongside his brother Neleus which caused the rightful heir, Aeson, to smuggle out his firstborn child, Jason, of Golden Fleece fame. He slaughtered everyone connected to Cretheus and imprisoned Aeson and his wife Alcimede. He also killed Sidero, Cretheus' second wife, who mistreated his mother, but he mistakenly did this in a temple dedicated to Hera, the Queen of Heaven. She swore revenge, of all the gods she was the most dangerous an enemy, just ask Heracles. Pelias, troubled by this, seeks advice from an oracle who informs him that "One of your own blood will end your life, beware the man who comes from the country wearing but one sandal". The prophecy came true one fateful day when Jason wandered into the city. He had lost a sandal on the journey helping an old woman (Hera in disguise) across a river. Pelias, terrified, tricked agreed to let him have the throne but told him that the land was cursed and the only way to lift the curse was to retrieve the Golden Fleece.

source.name: Acastus
source.notes: Son of Pelias who sent Jason to retrieve the Golden Fleece. He was possibly one of the Argonauts, sent by his father as a mole to ensure either that the quest would fail, or the fleece would be returned to him. Took over the rule of Iolcos and not Jason after Medea had tricked Pelias' daughters into killing him.

source.name: Calydonian Boar
source.notes: Killed Ancaeus in his vineyard when he returned from the quest for the Golden Fleece.

target.name: Crommyonian Sow
target.notes: Either a large, aggressive wild pig, or a malicious and murderous old woman called Phaea who transformed into a pig. Killed by the hero Theseus.

source.name: Calydonian Boar
source.notes: Killed Ancaeus in his vineyard when he returned from the quest for the Golden Fleece.

target.name: Ancaeus
target.notes: King of Samos. Helsman of the Argo and one of Jason's Argonauts. He planted a vine before leaving for the voyage and prayed that it would harvest a beautiful vintage. The island's seer told him that he would return but he would never taste the vineyard's wine. Upon his return from the quest the vineyard had fluorished, Samos is now famous for its wine. He raised a cup of wine in a mocking fashion to the seer but was warned that "there's many a slip 'twixt cup and lip". Soon after he heard a commotion in the vineyard, a wild boar was destorying his grapes. He tried to subdue the boar but was gored to death in the process.

source.name: Creon
source.notes: King of Corinth, he offered refuge to Jason and Medea who were fleeing Iolcos after the killing of King Pelias. When Jason fell for his daughter, Creusa, Medea posioned her and Creon died too when he tried to save her.

target.name: Jason
target.notes: Smuggled out of Iolcos when he was a baby due to Pelias and Neleus laying siege to the city believeing they were the rightful heirs to the throne and not his father, Aeson. He was brought up by his mother's (Alcimede) friend, the great centaur, Chiron. Met Bellerophon, who was seeking help from Chiron for Pegasus burned skin at the hands of Chimera. He filled his head with heroic feats which influenced Jason in his formative years. When his tutelage with Chiron was finished he ventured back to Iolcos. On the journey he lost a sandal helping an old lady (Hera in disguise) across a river. It was prophecised to Pelias to beware of a man arriving from the country with one sandal so when he arrived in Iolcos, Pelias knew immediately who he was. Pelias agreed to let him take the throne but lied to him, telling him the land was cursed and that the only way to lift the curse was to retrieve the Golden Fleece. He arranged a mighty ship, the Argo, and a great crew, the Argonauts, to sail to Colchis and retrieve the fleece. When the Argonauts arrived at Colchis, King Aeëtes demanded three tests of Jason before he could take it. To tame the fire breathing bulls, the Khalkotauroi, to sow some dragon's teeth from Cadmus and defeat the army that sprouts from the ground, and to kill the dragon that guards the fleece. He managed these feats thanks to his new lover, Medea, whom Hera had had Eros strike her with his cupid's arrow. They escaped with the fleece back to Pelias where they realised he was never going to give up the throne so Medea tricked his nine daughters into killing him, believing they were being taught a magic trick and would be brought back to life. They had to flee Iolcos after this blood killing and sought refuge in Corinth. Here Jason fell for the King's daughter, Creusa. Medea, so enraged at this betrayal after everything she had done for him killed Creusa and her father, King Creon. In a terrible denouement she even killed her children. A broken Jason lived on Corinth until his old friend Peleus persuaded him to return to Iolcos and overthrow Acastus, the King. They managed this and he was finally on the throne of Iolcos. This didn't last long however as one day, asleep under the Argo, a rotten beam fell on him and killed him. It was an ironic twist as he was warned years before during the voyage to repair the damage caused during the crossing of the Bosporus, but who knew this would be the deadly outcome.

source.name: Creon
source.notes: King of Corinth, he offered refuge to Jason and Medea who were fleeing Iolcos after the killing of King Pelias. When Jason fell for his daughter, Creusa, Medea posioned her and Creon died too when he tried to save her.

target.name: Medea
target.notes: Follower of the goddess of magic, Hecate. Hera had her struck by Eros' arrow of love so she would fall in love with Jason and help him in his three tests to win the Golden Fleece. She made a lotion which made him fireproof and able to defeat the Khalkotauroi. She told him how to defeat the Spartoi, and she made a potion that put the dragon guarding the Golden Fleece to sleep. During the escape from Colchis she murdered her brother, Absyrtus, to prevent Aeëtes, their father, from catching them. When they returned the fleece to Pelias and realised he was not going to hand over his reign, she tricked his nine daughters, the Peliades, into killing him up thinking they were going to bring him back to life with special herbs. She and Jason had to flee afterward, it was after all, a blood killing. Took refuge with Jason in Corinth where Jason fell for the King's daughter, Creusa. Medea killed her and the King in and even killed her own children in an extreme act of revenge. After she escaped to Athens and married the king, Aegeus. When the hero Theseus turned up in Athens, Medea conspired to have him killed by poisoning him, wanting her own son Medus to be heir to the throne. When Aegeus found out that Theseus was his son, he managed to stop him from drinking the poison just in time. Medea fled Athens never to return.

source.name: Thessalus
source.notes: Son of Jason and Medea. When Jason fell for Creusa, Medea would kill her children in revenge, but Thessalus was way being tutored by Chiron and survived. He would return to rule over Iolcos and Greater Aeolia, which we now call Thessaly in his honour.

source.name: Atalanta
source.notes: Abandoned by her father Schoeneues because he wanted a boy and heir. She was left on Mount Parthenion to die, but she was discovered by a she-bear who had just lost her cubs, so instead of eating her, she raised her. She was taken in by a group of hunters later who named her Atalanta, meaning "equal in weight", i.e. she was man's equal. She quickly learned and surpassed her teachers in the skills of hunting and dedicated herself to the Olympian Artemis, goddess of chastity and hunting. She joined the hunt for the Calydonian Boar to prove herself the greatest hero of the age. After she had killed the boar she was taken back in her father, certainly not the last time a  parent was to reclaim a famous and successful child. He wanted her to marry to keep the kingdom in the family but being a disciple of Artemis she refused. "I will only marry a man who can best me in a foot race" she said. Being the fastest in the land she knew this was an impossible task. Hippomenes was the one who finally beat her in a race, thanks to Aphrodite's help. They were married soon after but Hippomenes had failed to thank Aphrodite for her help and she cursed the couple into making love in a temple sacred to the goddess Cybele. So outraged was Cybele she transformed them into lions who the Greeks believed couldn't mate with each other. They lived out their lives drawing Cybele's chariot, closely coupled but denied the pleasure of sex for eternity.

target.name: Schoeneus
target.notes: Father of Atalanta, whom he abandoned when he saw his first born was a girl. He left her on a mountainside to perish.

target.name: Calydonian Boar
target.notes: Killed Ancaeus in his vineyard when he returned from the quest for the Golden Fleece.

source.name: Althaea
source.notes: Queen of Calydonia, she fell into a deep sleep after giving birth to her son, Meleager, who was probably the son of the god of war, Ares. She dreamed that the Moirai, or Fates, had decided that his life would be noble, potentially being the son of Ares and all, but his life would only last as long as the central log in the fireplace by which his mother slept remained unburned. "Meleager's life will end in a flash, when his log of fate is turned to ash" they chanted. When she awoke she buried the log deep in the palace just to be safe. During the hunt for the Calydonian Boar, Meleager credited Atalanta with the kill. This enraged his uncles, the Thestiades (brothers of Althaea) who believed the honour should be bestowed upon their family only because Atalanta was an outsider. Meleager, deeply in love with Atalanta, couldn't bear this so he murdered all of them. When Althaea found out she rushed to the palace and retrieved the fateful log which she burned on the spit the boar was being roasted on. Meleager died in agony. Distraught at her actions she ran into the forest and hung herself.

target.name: Oeneus
target.notes: Father-in-law to Heracles, during a feast Heracles killed his cupbearer for spilling wine on him. He was the King of Calydon, it was his excessive worship of the god Dionysus that so enraged Artemis which caused her to send the Calydonian Boar to terrorise his kingdom. He sent out a call for someone to kill the beast who would go down as 'the greatest hero of the age'. That hero was Atalanta.

target.name: Atalanta
target.notes: Abandoned by her father Schoeneues because he wanted a boy and heir. She was left on Mount Parthenion to die, but she was discovered by a she-bear who had just lost her cubs, so instead of eating her, she raised her. She was taken in by a group of hunters later who named her Atalanta, meaning "equal in weight", i.e. she was man's equal. She quickly learned and surpassed her teachers in the skills of hunting and dedicated herself to the Olympian Artemis, goddess of chastity and hunting. She joined the hunt for the Calydonian Boar to prove herself the greatest hero of the age. After she had killed the boar she was taken back in her father, certainly not the last time a  parent was to reclaim a famous and successful child. He wanted her to marry to keep the kingdom in the family but being a disciple of Artemis she refused. "I will only marry a man who can best me in a foot race" she said. Being the fastest in the land she knew this was an impossible task. Hippomenes was the one who finally beat her in a race, thanks to Aphrodite's help. They were married soon after but Hippomenes had failed to thank Aphrodite for her help and she cursed the couple into making love in a temple sacred to the goddess Cybele. So outraged was Cybele she transformed them into lions who the Greeks believed couldn't mate with each other. They lived out their lives drawing Cybele's chariot, closely coupled but denied the pleasure of sex for eternity.

Meleager, who was deeply in love with Atalanta, killed him.

target.name: Meleager
target.notes: One of Jason's Argonauts. He was son of either Oeneus, King of Calydon, or Ares, the god of war. His mother, Althaea, fell into a deep sleep after giving birth where she dreamed that the Moirai, or Fates, had decided that his life would be noble, potentially being the son of Ares and all, but his life would only last as long as the central log in the fireplace by which his mother slept remained unburned. "Meleager's life will end in a flash, when his log of fate is turned to ash" they chanted. He was a member of the hunt for the Calydonian Boar that terrorised his father's kingdom. He fell instantly in love with Atalanta who joined the hunt. This wasn't reciprocated however because as a subject of the god of chastity, Artemis, she had turned her back on men and love. When the hunt was over he credited Atalanta with the honour of the kill, to the indignation of his uncles, the Thestiades. They believed the honour should be bestowed on their family only as Atalanta was an outsider. So enraged through his love for Atalanta, Meleager killed his uncles in cold blood. When his mother discovered this she retrieved the fateful log and burned it on the spit the boar was being roasted on. Meleager died an agonising death. Overcome by extreme guilt, Althaea ran into the forest and hung herself.

target.name: Hippocoön
target.notes: King of Sparta, he aided his friend Neleus during his battle with Heracles. Heracles took revenge by killing him and his sons and installing his older brother Tyndareus, the rightful King of Sparta who Hippocoön had ousted, on the throne. This would cause devestating consequences in the upcoming Trojan war.

source.name: Hippomenes
source.notes: Atalanta, forced to find a suitor by her father, had arranged a foot race where the winner would win her hand in marriage. Being a devoted disciple of Artemis, goddess of chastity she didn't want to marry, so a foot race, where she was the fastest person in the land, seemed the best compromise to her father. Hippomenes had fell in love with Atalanta whilst watching one of her races. He prayed to the goddess of love, Aphrodite, to be able to win Atalanta's heart. She bestowed upon him three golden apples which he used during the race to distract Atalanta and win the race. They were married but Hippomenes had failed to thank Aphrodite for her help and she cursed the couple into making love in a temple sacred to the goddess Cybele. So outraged was Cybele she transformed them into lions who the Greeks believed couldn't mate with each other. They lived out their lives drawing Cybele's chariot, closely coupled but denied the pleasure of sex for eternity.

target.name: Aphrodite
target.god_of: God of Love, Beauty, Pleasure & Procreation
target.notes: Child of Ouranos' genitals as they "impregnated" the sea when discarded by Kronos. Hence the image of Aphrodite emerging from the sea on a scallop (Botticelli). Kept safe by Zeus in the Titan War.

source.name: Labdacus
source.notes: Overthrown as ruler of Thebes by the twins Amphion and Zethus.

target.name: Amphion
target.notes: One of the co-founders of Thebes with Cadmus and Zethus. His wife Niobe would anger the mother of the gods Leto which brought Artemis and Apollo to hunt down and kill their fourteen children. When he heard news of the slaughter he took his own life by falling on his sword.

source.name: Labdacus
source.notes: Overthrown as ruler of Thebes by the twins Amphion and Zethus.

target.name: Zethus
target.notes: One of the co-founders of Thebes with Cadmus and Amphion.

source.name: Laius
source.notes: Smuggled out of Thebes as an infant when his father, Labdacus, was overthrown by Amphion and Zethus. He reclaimed the throne later in life. He married Jocasta but found he was unable to father a child. He visited the Delphic oracle for advice who warned him that, "The son of Laius and Jocasta shall kill his father". He decided it best to abstain from the marriage bed until one day he got drunk and Jocasta became pregnant. He had the child imprisoned on the top of Mount Cithaeron.

target.name: Labdacus
target.notes: Overthrown as ruler of Thebes by the twins Amphion and Zethus.

source.name: Laius
source.notes: Smuggled out of Thebes as an infant when his father, Labdacus, was overthrown by Amphion and Zethus. He reclaimed the throne later in life. He married Jocasta but found he was unable to father a child. He visited the Delphic oracle for advice who warned him that, "The son of Laius and Jocasta shall kill his father". He decided it best to abstain from the marriage bed until one day he got drunk and Jocasta became pregnant. He had the child imprisoned on the top of Mount Cithaeron.

target.name: Pelops
target.notes: King of Pisa in the Peloponnese. Murdered by his father and offered to the gods during a feast. The gods were so angered they dispatched Tantalus to Tartarus for eternity and brought Pelops back to life, endowing him with a new shoulder made of ivory to replace the one that was mistakenly eaten. He took in Laius as a baby who was smuggled out of Thebes when his father, Labdacus was overthrown. Laius took Pelops' son, Chrysippus with him when he finally returned to Thebes to reclaim his throne. This wasn't a consensual relationship so Chrysippus took his own life. Pelops swore a curse on Laius and his line for ever.

source.name: Chrysippus
source.notes: Son of Pelops who was looking after Laius, the deposed infant heir to the throne of Thebes. Laius fell in love with Chrysippus and took him back with him to Thebes to reclaim the throne. This wasn't a consensual relationship and Chrysippus committed suicide in shame.

target.name: Pelops
target.notes: King of Pisa in the Peloponnese. Murdered by his father and offered to the gods during a feast. target.name: Laius
target.notes: Smuggled out of Thebes as an infant when his father, Labdacus, was overthrown by Amphion and Zethus. He reclaimed the throne later in life. He married Jocasta but found he was unable to father a child. He visited the Delphic oracle for advice who warned him that, "The son of Laius and Jocasta shall kill his father". He decided it best to abstain from the marriage bed until one day he got drunk and Jocasta became pregnant. He had the child imprisoned on the top of Mount Cithaeron.

source.name: Jocasta
source.notes: Queen of Thebes. Her husband, King Laius had discarded their child, Oedipus, to avoid a prophecy which stated that his son would end up killing him. Oedipus was raised in Corinth but fate would have it that he would return to Thebes and he ended up marrying Jocasta after Laius had been killed. All of this was unbeknownst to the both of them. When a plague hit Thebes Oedipus sought the advice of the Delphic oracle where he was told that the plague would be lifted when the killer of Laius was named. Oedipus was the killer. He had gotten into a fight on the road years before and Laius was killed in the scuffle. Antimedes, Laius' servant and the only survivor of the fight was called by Oedipus to help find the killer. As soon as he saw Oedipus the truth came out about his real parents, his being abandoned by Jocasta and Laius and the fact that the prophecies had all come true, he had killed his father and slept with his mother. Jocasta ran away in anguish and hanged herself.

target.name: Oedipus
target.notes: His father, Laius, had received a prophecy that his son would kill him, so he had him imprisoned on the top of Mount Cithaeron as a baby. He was rescued and taken to Corinth where he was raised by the King and Queen, Polybus and Merope. They named him Oedipus which means 'swollen foot' after the scars on his once shackled ankles. During his life he heard rumours that he was adopted so he consulted with the Delphic oracle. Instead of being told who his real parents were, in typical oracular cryptic fashion he was told, "Oedipus will kill his father and mate with his mother". He decided to leave Corinth to avoid the possibility of the prophecy coming true. Whilst on the road he got into a fight with a man in a chariot who had hurled abuse at him to get out of the way, Oedipus killed him and his entourage during the ensuing fight. He ended up making his way toward Thebes, he answered one of the Sphinx's riddles on the way to reopen the road and lift the curse. He was welcomed into the city as a hero and welcomed by Queen Jocasta, unbeknownst to Oedipus, this was his real mother. She told him that her husband had been killed on the road by a gang of robbers, this was the very same fight that Oedipus had gotten into, part of the prophecy had come true. In time he fell in love with Jocasta. He became King and they married and had four children, thus completing the prophecy. Later in his reign he again sought the advice of the Delphic oracle about a vicious plague that had swept through the kingdom. The Pythia answered, "Thebes will be relieved when the murderer of King Laius is named and found." Oedipus sent for Laius' servant, Antimedes, who was the sole survivor of the fight that fateful day. As soon as Antimedes set eyes on Oedipus the whole horrendous truth came out. Oedipus discovered his true parents, his being abandoned by his mother and now wife, Jocasta, and the fact that the horrible prophecies had all come true. Jocasta ran away and hanged herself in the bedroom. Oedipus found her and thrust her gold brooch dress pins into his eyes in anguish.

He decided it best to abstain from the marriage bed until one day he got drunk and Jocasta became pregnant. He had the child imprisoned on the top of Mount Cithaeron.

source.name: Antimedes
source.notes: Servant of Laius, King of Thebes. Antimedes imprisoned his son, Oedipus on top of Mount Cithaeron on Laius' orders, who was trying to avoid a prophecy that his son would kill him. He was part of Laius' entourage the day he encountered Oedipus on the road where a fight broke out and Oedipus had killed Laius, unbeknownst to him at the time was his father. Antimedes was the only one to escape unharmed. In later years Oedipus sent for Antimedes to try and find the killer of Laius which would lift the plague terrorising Thebes. When Antimedes set eyes on Oedipus he knew straight away he was the killer. He related the whole terrible story to him about the prophecies, being abandoned as a child, and the fact that he was the cause of the plague.

target.name: Oedipus
target.notes: His father, Laius, had received a prophecy that his son would kill him, so he had him imprisoned on the top of Mount Cithaeron as a baby. He was rescued and taken to Corinth where he was raised by the King and Queen, Polybus and Merope. They named him Oedipus which means 'swollen foot' after the scars on his once shackled ankles. During his life he heard rumours that he was adopted so he consulted with the Delphic oracle. Instead of being told who his real parents were, in typical oracular cryptic fashion he was told, "Oedipus will kill his father and mate with his mother". He decided to leave Corinth to avoid the possibility of the prophecy coming true. Whilst on the road he got into a fight with a man in a chariot who had hurled abuse at him to get out of the way, Oedipus killed him and his entourage during the ensuing fight. He ended up making his way toward Thebes, he answered one of the Sphinx's riddles on the way to reopen the road and lift the curse. He was welcomed into the city as a hero and welcomed by Queen Jocasta, unbeknownst to Oedipus, this was his real mother. She told him that her husband had been killed on the road by a gang of robbers, this was the very same fight that Oedipus had gotten into, part of the prophecy had come true. In time he fell in love with Jocasta. He became King and they married and had four children, thus completing the prophecy. Later in his reign he again sought the advice of the Delphic oracle about a vicious plague that had swept through the kingdom. The Pythia answered, "Thebes will be relieved when the murderer of King Laius is named and found." Oedipus sent for Laius' servant, Antimedes, who was the sole survivor of the fight that fateful day. As soon as Antimedes set eyes on Oedipus the whole horrendous truth came out. Oedipus discovered his true parents, his being abandoned by his mother and now wife, Jocasta, and the fact that the horrible prophecies had all come true. Jocasta ran away and hanged herself in the bedroom. Oedipus found her and thrust her gold brooch dress pins into his eyes in anguish.

source.name: Straton
source.notes: Friend of Phorbas who rescued Oedipus. Straton took the baby to Corinth wher he was raised by the King and Queen, Polybus and Merope.

target.name: Phorbas
target.notes: Rescued the baby Oedipus from Mount Cithaeron after he'd been imprisoned at the top by his father, Laius, who was trying to avoid a prophecy that his son would kill him.

source.name: Polybus

source.name: Sphinx
source.notes: Head of a mortal woman, body of a lion and the wings of a bird. This fierce creature was sent by Hera as a curse on Thebes for King Laius for abducting Chrysippus. She stopped every traveller on the road to Thebes and forced them to answer a riddle. If they got it wrong they were thrown to their deaths on the rocks below. Oedipus was the hero to finally solve one of her riddles. "What walks on four feet in the morning, two at noon and three in the evening?". "Man" answered Oedipus. "He crawls on all fours at birth, upright on two legs during his prime, and uses a stick in old age". This sent the Sphinx crashing into the rocks below and the road was open again once again.

target.name: Hera
target.god_of: Queen of the Gods, god of Marriage, Women, the Sky & Stars of Heaven
target.notes: Swallowed by Kronos when born due to Ouranos' curse on him that "Your own children will overthrow you as you overthrew me". Married to Zeus.

target.name: Laius
target.notes: Smuggled out of Thebes as an infant when his father, Labdacus, was overthrown by Amphion and Zethus. He reclaimed the throne later in life. He married Jocasta but found he was unable to father a child. He visited the Delphic oracle for advice who warned him that, "The son of Laius and Jocasta shall kill his father". He decided it best to abstain from the marriage bed until one day he got drunk and Jocasta became pregnant. He had the child imprisoned on the top of Mount Cithaeron.

source.name: Eteocles
source.notes: Child of Jocasta and Oedipus, Jocasta's son and husband. Takes the throne of Thebes after Oedipus' demise. Initially agreeing to power share with his brother, Polynices, but refusing to give up the throne when it's his turn. Polynices raises an army to fight him (the so called Seven against Thebes) but they are both killed in the battle.

target.name: Creon
target.notes: King of Thebes, ruling after King Laius was murdered by Oedipus, unbeknownst to him at the time, Laius was Oedipus' father. He abdicated the throne for Oedipus when he married Queen Jocasta, his mother. At the time of his reign, Thebes was being hounded by a viscious fox that couldn't be caught, the Cadmean Vixen. Creon begged Cephalus to let him use his hunting dog Lailaps to hunt the fox down.

source.name: Haemon
source.notes: nan

target.name: Eurydice
target.notes: nan

source.name: Haemon
source.notes: nan

target.name: Antigone
target.notes: Daughter of Oedipus and Jocasta, Oedipus' mother and wife. After Oedipus' demise her brothers, Eteocles and Polynices, agree to power share the throne of Thebes. But Eteocles reneged on the deal and Polynices raises an army (the so called Seven against Thebes) where both are killed in the ensuing battle. Polynices is denied proper burial as he was considered the agressor. Antigone, distraught at the idea of this attempts to cover the corpse but is caught and sentenced to death. Her sentence is commuted at the last minute but she hanged herself before she could get the news.

source.name: Eurydice
source.notes: nan

source.name: Theseus
source.notes: Theseus discovered his father was Aegeus, King of Athens. He wanted to enter Athens a hero to finally meet his father, so he set out along the dangerous coastal route from Troezen. During his travels he cleared the route of all evil, slaying monsters and murderes alike to enter Athens held aloft by an adoring public grateful to have the road made safe once more. Aegeus' wife, Jason's widow, Medea, was adamant that her own son, Medus, and not Theseus would be the heir to throne of Athens so she persuaded Aegeus, who didn't know it was his long lost son at this point, to order him to kill the Marathonian Bull. Theseus accomplished this heroic feat, inventing ancient bull fighting in the process. Medea then contrived to have him poisoned. Aegeus agreed, believing Theseus' fame was a threat to his rule. Just as Theseus was about to drink the poison, Aegeus noticed his sword. It was the exact same sword that he'd buried back in Troezen for his son to find one day. He managed to stop him drinking the poison just in time and father and son were united. Medea fled Athens never to return. Theseus then went to Crete to lift the tributes that Athens had to pay. This was due to Aegeus sending Minos' (King of Crete) son Androgeus to kill the Marathonian Bull and getting killed. Minos threatened to raze Athens to the ground unless a tribute of seven maidens and seven youths were sent from Athens every year to feed the minotaur Asterion. Theseus sent himself as one of the sacrifical lambs where he fell in love with Minos' daughter, Ariadne. She gave him a ball of cotton which he used to find his way through the labyrinth to kill Asterion. He fled Crete with Ariadne to the island of Naxos. It was here that Theseus had a dream in which Dionysus warned him to leave Ariadne on the island as she was betrothed to him. He took the tough decision to leave her to save the Athenians he'd managed to save from being sacrificed to Asterion. He later took Antiope, an Amazon warrior as his queen kickstarting the Attic War, or Amazonomachy. They managed to defeat the Amazons but Antiope was killed in the process. He then had a sort of mid-life crisis, getting into all sorts of scrapes with his best friend Pirithous. They had the terrible idea one day of trying to kidnap Persephone, Queen of the underworld to be Pirithous' wife. Hades had them cast into stone chairs, their buttocks stuck to the seats. Heracles managed to free them during his twelfth labour to retrieve Cerberus. He married Phaedra, the younger sister of Ariadne. When visiting his son Hippolytus, Phaedra, Hippolytus' step-mother, was struck by a curse sent from Aphrodite in revenge for Hippolytus' neglect in all matters of love. Phaedra declared her love to Hippolytus but it wasn't reciprocated. Phaedra cried rape to Theseus who prayed to his father Poseidon for justice. target.name: Poseidon

target.notes: Swallowed by Kronos when born due to Ouranos' curse on him that "Your own children will overthrow you as you overthrew me". Giften the weapon of a Trident by the Cyclopes.

target.name: Heracles
target.notes: Born Alcides, son of Zeus and Alcmene. Zeus had wanted a child in the blood line of Perseus as Hera had prophecised that a child of Perseus would save the Olympians. Hera was so incensed at yet another affair of Zeus that she swore eternal enmity against Alcides. Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

target.name: Cretan Bull
target.notes: Sent from the sea by Posedion in answer to the prayers of Minos, the King of Crete who wanted a sign that his reign was blessed. Heracles was sent to subdue it as one of his labours. When Heracles released the bull it fled to Marathon, where it became known as the Marathonian Bull and terrorised the inhabitants there until Theseus came along and subdued the bull. He then sacrificed it to Apollo.

target.name: Asterion
target.notes: Son of the Cretan Bull and Pasiphae, Queen of Crete. This half man, half bull, known as a Minotaur, lived in the labyrinth designed by King Minos of Crete's architect, Daedalus.

target.name: Pirithous
target.notes: King of the Lapiths and one of Jason's Argonauts. He heard of the exploits of Theseus and wanted to test them out. He raided his cattle and Theseus tracked him down, but instead of fighting it out they quickly realised they very much liked each other and so began one of the great friendships in Greek mythology. They had the crazy idea of kidnapping Persephone, Queen of the Underworld to be his wife. Hades had them cast into stone chairs, their buttocks glued to the seats. It wasn't until Heracles descended into the underworld during his twelfth labour to retrieve Cerberus, that they managed to be freed.

target.name: Medea
target.notes: Follower of the goddess of magic, Hecate. Hera had her struck by Eros' arrow of love so she would fall in love with Jason and help him in his three tests to win the Golden Fleece. She made a lotion which made him fireproof and able to defeat the Khalkotauroi. She told him how to defeat the Spartoi, and she made a potion that put the dragon guarding the Golden Fleece to sleep. During the escape from Colchis she murdered her brother, Absyrtus, to prevent Aeëtes, their father, from catching them. When they returned the fleece to Pelias and realised he was not going to hand over his reign, she tricked his nine daughters, the Peliades, into killing him up thinking they were going to bring him back to life with special herbs. She and Jason had to flee afterward, it was after all, a blood killing. Took refuge with Jason in Corinth where Jason fell for the King's daughter, Creusa. Medea killed her and the King in and even killed her own children in an extreme act of revenge. After she escaped to Athens and married the king, Aegeus. When the hero Theseus turned up in Athens, Medea conspired to have him killed by poisoning him, wanting her own son Medus to be heir to the throne. When Aegeus found out that Theseus was his son, he managed to stop him from drinking the poison just in time. Medea fled Athens never to return.

Aegeus had told Theseus to use white sails on their return journey to indicate success. Theseus forgot and when Aegeus saw the black sails he threw himself to his death in the sea below in despair. The sea where this happened has been named after him ever since, the Aegean.

target.name: Pittheus
target.notes: King of Troezen, a small city state in the Peloponnese. His daughter was engaged to the hero Bellerophon until he accidentally killed his brother Deliades during a hunting trip.

source.name: Periphetes
source.notes: The 'club man'. A cyclops who wielded a big club, robbing travellers on the coastal road to Athens. Killed by the hero Theseus.

target.name: Theseus
target.notes: Theseus discovered his father was Aegeus, King of Athens. He wanted to enter Athens a hero to finally meet his father, so he set out along the dangerous coastal route from Troezen. He managed to stop him drinking the poison just in time and father and son were united. Medea fled Athens never to return. Theseus then went to Crete to lift the tributes that Athens had to pay. This was due to Aegeus sending Minos' (King of Crete) son Androgeus to kill the Marathonian Bull and getting killed. Minos threatened to raze Athens to the ground unless a tribute of seven maidens and seven youths were sent from Athens every year to feed the minotaur Asterion. Theseus sent himself as one of the sacrifical lambs where he fell in love with Minos' daughter, Ariadne. She gave him a ball of cotton which he used to find his way through the labyrinth to kill Asterion. He fled Crete with Ariadne to the island of Naxos. It was here that Theseus had a dream in which Dionysus warned him to leave Ariadne on the island as she was betrothed to him. He took the tough decision to leave her to save the Athenians he'd managed to save from being sacrificed to Asterion. He later took Antiope, an Amazon warrior as his queen kickstarting the Attic War, or Amazonomachy. They managed to defeat the Amazons but Antiope was killed in the process. He then had a sort of mid-life crisis, getting into all sorts of scrapes with his best friend Pirithous. They had the terrible idea one day of trying to kidnap Persephone, Queen of the underworld to be Pirithous' wife. Hades had them cast into stone chairs, their buttocks stuck to the seats. Phaedra declared her love to Hippolytus but it wasn't reciprocated. Phaedra cried rape to Theseus who prayed to his father Poseidon for justice. His statue stands proudly in the centre of Athens today in Syntagma Square.

source.name: Sinis Pityocamptes
source.notes: The 'pine bender'. He would tie travellers between two pine trees that he had bent down. He would then release the trees pulling the poor traveller apart. Killed by the hero Theseus.

source.name: Crommyonian Sow
source.notes: Either a large, aggressive wild pig, or a malicious and murderous old woman called Phaea who transformed into a pig. Killed by the hero Theseus.

target.name: Typhon
target.notes: A monstrous storm giant who laid siege to the heavens in the clash of the Titans but was defeated by Zeus.

source.name: Crommyonian Sow
source.notes: Either a large, aggressive wild pig, or a malicious and murderous old woman called Phaea who transformed into a pig. Killed by the hero Theseus.

target.name: Echidna
target.notes: A monstrous she-dragon with the head and breast of a woman and the tail of a serpent. She represents the corruptions of the earth, rot, slime, fetid water, illness and disease.

source.name: Sciron
source.notes: A notorious outlaw who lurked along a set of cliffs above the Saronic Gulf. He liked to trick travellers into washing his feet on the edge of the cliffs only to kick them over the edge where a giant turtle would eat them at the bottom. Theseus encountered him on his heroic journey to Athens. He flung the bowl of hot water into Sciron's face just as he was about to wash his feet and pushed him over the edge to be eaten by the turtle.

source.name: Procrustes
source.notes: The 'stretcher'. He would take travellers into his guest house on the road to Athens where he would torture them on a bed that he could stretch. Theseus stayed at his house during his heroic travels. He could sense there was something macabre about the man so he played it cool and overheard him discussing with his wife the terrible plan he had in store for him. Theseus wrestled him to his own sick invention and gave him a taste of his own medicine. He then razed the place to the ground.

source.name: Phytalus
source.notes: Phytalus had once shown great kindess to Demeter, the goddess of the harvest. In recompense the goddess granted his descendants the power to expiate those who broke the laws of hospitality.

target.name: Demeter
target.notes: Swallowed by Kronos when born due to Ouranos' curse on him that "Your own children will overthrow you as you overthrew me"

source.name: Pallas
source.notes: Brother of King Aegeus of Athens. As Aegeus was childless he expected one of his fifty sons, the Palliantidae, to take the throne. When Theseus, Aegeus's son, arrived in Athens, he was given the throne. The Palliantidae revolted but were killed by Theseus.

target.name: Aegeus
target.notes: King of Athens and father of the hero Theseus. Married to Jason's widow, Medea. Being a childless couple left a power vaccuum for the throne of Athens. Both Aegeus' brother, Pallas and Medea had designs on their children being the next king. When Theseus turned up he didn't recognise it was his son. Theseus being so popular was seen as a threat to Aegeus' rule so Medea hatched a plan to poison Theseus. Just as he was about to drink the poison he noticed Theseus' sword, it was the same one Aegeus himself had buried back in Troezen for his son to find one day. He managed to stop Theseus drinking the poison just in time and father and son were united. Medea had scarpered never to return. He angrily sent the boastful Androgeus, son of King Minos of Crete, to kill the Marathonian Bull. When Androgeus was killed, Minos demanded tribute or else he'd raze Athens to the ground. The tribute was to be seven maidens and seven youths sent every year from Athens to Crete to feed Asterion, the minotaur. Theseus joined the tribute and killed Asterion to lift the tribute and free Athenians from their terrible burden. Aegeus had told Theseus to use white sails on their return journey to indicate success. Theseus forgot and when Aegeus saw the black sails he threw himself to his death in the sea below in despair. The sea where this happened has been named after him ever since, the Aegean.

source.name: Medus
source.notes: Child of Jason's widow, Medea. She wanted him to assume the throne of Athens and not Theseus, King Aegeus' long lost son.

target.name: Medea
target.notes: Follower of the goddess of magic, Hecate. Hera had her struck by Eros' arrow of love so she would fall in love with Jason and help him in his three tests to win the Golden Fleece. She made a lotion which made him fireproof and able to defeat the Khalkotauroi. She told him how to defeat the Spartoi, and she made a potion that put the dragon guarding the Golden Fleece to sleep. During the escape from Colchis she murdered her brother, Absyrtus, to prevent Aeëtes, their father, from catching them. When they returned the fleece to Pelias and realised he was not going to hand over his reign, she tricked his nine daughters, the Peliades, into killing him up thinking they were going to bring him back to life with special herbs. She and Jason had to flee afterward, it was after all, a blood killing. Took refuge with Jason in Corinth where Jason fell for the King's daughter, Creusa. Medea killed her and the King in and even killed her own children in an extreme act of revenge. After she escaped to Athens and married the king, Aegeus. When the hero Theseus turned up in Athens, Medea conspired to have him killed by poisoning him, wanting her own son Medus to be heir to the throne. When Aegeus found out that Theseus was his son, he managed to stop him from drinking the poison just in time. Medea fled Athens never to return.

source.name: Androgeus
source.notes: Son of King Minos of Crete. King Aegeus of Athens had received Androgeus as a guest and foolishly sent him on a quest to kill the Marathonian Bull. Androgeus died in the attempt and Minos invaded Attica and threatened to burn the city to the ground unless he sent a tribute to Crete every year. The tribute was seven maidens and seven youths to be sent to feed the Minotaur Asterion which was kept in the labyrinth on Crete.

target.name: Minos II
target.notes: King of Crete. He demanded a yearly tribute from Athens for the death of his son, Androgeus, who died trying to subdue the Marathonian Bull on the King of Athens' orders (King Aegeus). Theseus, Aegeus' son, went to Crete as part of the tribute and killed Asterion the minotaur, the one for whom the tribute was for. Minos blamed Daedalus, the inventor of the labyrinth which imprisoned Asterion. Daedalus escaped but Minos eventually tracked him down to Sicily where he demanded King Cocalus hand him over. Cocalus' daughters, very fond of Daedalus, scalded him to death in the bath before he had chance to take him.

source.name: Androgeus
source.notes: Son of King Minos of Crete. King Aegeus of Athens had received Androgeus as a guest and foolishly sent him on a quest to kill the Marathonian Bull. Androgeus died in the attempt and Minos invaded Attica and threatened to burn the city to the ground unless he sent a tribute to Crete every year. The tribute was seven maidens and seven youths to be sent to feed the Minotaur Asterion which was kept in the labyrinth on Crete.

target.name: Pasiphae
target.notes: Queen of Crete, she mated with the Cretan Bull and bore the minotaur Asterion.

source.name: Androgeus
source.notes: Son of King Minos of Crete. King Aegeus of Athens had received Androgeus as a guest and foolishly sent him on a quest to kill the Marathonian Bull. Androgeus died in the attempt and Minos invaded Attica and threatened to burn the city to the ground unless he sent a tribute to Crete every year. The tribute was seven maidens and seven youths to be sent to feed the Minotaur Asterion which was kept in the labyrinth on Crete.

target.name: Cretan Bull
target.notes: Sent from the sea by Posedion in answer to the prayers of Minos, the King of Crete who wanted a sign that his reign was blessed. Heracles was sent to subdue it as one of his labours. When Heracles released the bull it fled to Marathon, where it became known as the Marathonian Bull and terrorised the inhabitants there until Theseus came along and subdued the bull. He then sacrificed it to Apollo.

source.notes: Theseus' spy in the Palliantidae camp. He warned Theseus of their plan to assassinate him and claim the throne of Athens for themselves. Theseus was then able to defeat them.

They had the terrible idea one day of trying to kidnap Persephone, Queen of the underworld to be Pirithous' wife. Hades had them cast into stone chairs, their buttocks stuck to the seats. Heracles managed to free them during his twelfth labour to retrieve Cerberus. He married Phaedra, the younger sister of Ariadne. When visiting his son Hippolytus, Phaedra, Hippolytus' step-mother, was struck by a curse sent from Aphrodite in revenge for Hippolytus' neglect in all matters of love. Phaedra declared her love to Hippolytus but it wasn't reciprocated. Phaedra cried rape to Theseus who prayed to his father Poseidon for justice. Hippolytus was trampled to death in a chariot "accident". Upon hearing this Phaedra killed herself. Theseus was exiled from Athens for this unwitting role in the deaths of his son and wife. The end of his life was marked by shame and bitterness. He ended up as the guest of King Lycomedes of Skyros where one day he fell to his death over a cliff, pushed by Lycomedes but the reason is lost to us. His legacy wasn't tarnished however, Theseus goes down as one of the great heroes of Greek myth, and the greatest in all of Athens. His statue stands proudly in the centre of Athens today in Syntagma Square.

source.name: Leus
source.notes: Theseus' spy in the Palliantidae camp. He warned Theseus of their plan to assassinate him and claim the throne of Athens for themselves. Theseus was then able to defeat them.

target.name: Pallas
target.notes: Brother of King Aegeus of Athens. As Aegeus was childless he expected one of his fifty sons, the Palliantidae, to take the throne. When Theseus, Aegeus's son, arrived in Athens, he was given the throne. The Palliantidae revolted but were killed by Theseus.

source.name: Perdix
source.notes: Nephew of Daedalus, the most gifted inventor in Greece. Perdix eventually outdid his uncle to become the better inventor. Daedalus threw him off the Acropolis in a jealous rage. Athena turned him into a partridge. This is why partridges always fly low and build their nests on the ground, as they never forget that terrifying plunge from the heights of Athens.

target.name: Daedalus
target.notes: The most gifted architect, inventor, designer in all of ancient Greece. Born in Athens but was expelled when he threw his nephew and apprentice Perdix off the Acropolis in a jealous rage as Perdix had become even more gifted than Daedalus himself. He went to Crete where he would work for King Minos.  He designed the labyrinth that imprisoned the minotaur Asterion for King Minos of Crete. When Theseus killed Asterion Minos blamed Daedalus. Only the inventor of the labyrinth could have helped him on his way through. He imprisoned Daedalus and his son, Icarus, at the top of the palace tower. Daedalus made wings from feathers and candle wax for them both to escape. Icarus flew too high and his wings melted. He crashed into the sea and died. Daedalus eventually ended up working for King Cocalus in Sicily. One day he was presented with a puzzle, passing a thread through a shell's complex helical chambers. Daedalus did this with ease and showed the man how he did it. The man was pleased, only Daedalus the inventor could have solved this puzzle. The man was Minos. He had finally tracked Daedalus down and wanted revenge. Cocalus reluctantly agreed to hand him over the next day but whilst Minos was bathing in the palace, Cocalus' daughters, so very fond of Daedalus, heated the water to boiling point and scalded Minos to death.

source.name: Asterion
source.notes: King of Crete and son of Minos, one of the judges of the underworld.

target.name: Minos I
target.notes: Upon their deaths they were appointed Judges of the Underworld, taking over from Hades as arbiters of a soul's final destination. The righteous would end up at Elysian Fields (Isles of the Blessed). The vast majority were placed in the Meadows of Asphodel. The sinners were placed in the Fields of Punishment in the depths of Tartarus to be tortured for eternity.

source.name: Ariadne
source.notes: Daughter of Minos and Pasiphae, king and queen of Crete. She fell in love with Theseus when he turned up at Crete to fight the minotaur Asterion and free Athens from its tribute to Crete (see Androgeus for more). She gave him a ball of thread to find his way through the labyrinth to kill Asterion. She fled with Theseus from Crete to Naxos where Theseus had a dream where he was warned to leave Ariadne on the island as she was betrothed to Dionysus. Theseus took the hard decision to leave her to save the rest of the Athenians who he'd saved from being given up to Asterion.

target.name: Minos II
target.notes: King of Crete. He demanded a yearly tribute from Athens for the death of his son, Androgeus, who died trying to subdue the Marathonian Bull on the King of Athens' orders (King Aegeus). Theseus, Aegeus' son, went to Crete as part of the tribute and killed Asterion the minotaur, the one for whom the tribute was for. Minos blamed Daedalus, the inventor of the labyrinth which imprisoned Asterion. Daedalus escaped but Minos eventually tracked him down to Sicily where he demanded King Cocalus hand him over. Cocalus' daughters, very fond of Daedalus, scalded him to death in the bath before he had chance to take him.

source.name: Ariadne
source.notes: Daughter of Minos and Pasiphae, king and queen of Crete. She fell in love with Theseus when he turned up at Crete to fight the minotaur Asterion and free Athens from its tribute to Crete (see Androgeus for more). She gave him a ball of thread to find his way through the labyrinth to kill Asterion. She fled with Theseus from Crete to Naxos where Theseus had a dream where he was warned to leave Ariadne on the island as she was betrothed to Dionysus. Theseus took the hard decision to leave her to save the rest of the Athenians who he'd saved from being given up to Asterion.

target.name: Pasiphae
target.notes: Queen of Crete, she mated with the Cretan Bull and bore the minotaur Asterion.

source.name: Ariadne
source.notes: Daughter of Minos and Pasiphae, king and queen of Crete. She fell in love with Theseus when he turned up at Crete to fight the minotaur Asterion and free Athens from its tribute to Crete (see Androgeus for more). She gave him a ball of thread to find his way through the labyrinth to kill Asterion. She fled with Theseus from Crete to Naxos where Theseus had a dream where he was warned to leave Ariadne on the island as she was betrothed to Dionysus. Theseus took the hard decision to leave her to save the rest of the Athenians who he'd saved from being given up to Asterion.

target.name: Dionysus
target.notes: Produced the world's first vintage from his lover and friend Ampelos (vine in Greek). Replaced Hestia in the quorum of twelve Olympians after she retired. The Gods were happy to have Dionysus for his wine and debauchery, all except Hera, as Dionysus was the result of Zeus's affair with Semele. Hera swore never to drink from Dionysus's cup and would later curse his son Priapus with ugliness and impotence.

source.name: Ariadne
source.notes: Daughter of Minos and Pasiphae, king and queen of Crete. She fell in love with Theseus when he turned up at Crete to fight the minotaur Asterion and free Athens from its tribute to Crete (see Androgeus for more). She gave him a ball of thread to find his way through the labyrinth to kill Asterion. She fled with Theseus from Crete to Naxos where Theseus had a dream where he was warned to leave Ariadne on the island as she was betrothed to Dionysus. Theseus took the hard decision to leave her to save the rest of the Athenians who he'd saved from being given up to Asterion.

target.name: Theseus
target.notes: Theseus discovered his father was Aegeus, King of Athens. He wanted to enter Athens a hero to finally meet his father, so he set out along the dangerous coastal route from Troezen. During his travels he cleared the route of all evil, slaying monsters and murderes alike to enter Athens held aloft by an adoring public grateful to have the road made safe once more. Aegeus' wife, Jason's widow, Medea, was adamant that her own son, Medus, and not Theseus would be the heir to throne of Athens so she persuaded Aegeus, who didn't know it was his long lost son at this point, to order him to kill the Marathonian Bull. Theseus accomplished this heroic feat, inventing ancient bull fighting in the process. Medea then contrived to have him poisoned. Aegeus agreed, believing Theseus' fame was a threat to his rule. Just as Theseus was about to drink the poison, Aegeus noticed his sword. It was the exact same sword that he'd buried back in Troezen for his son to find one day. He managed to stop him drinking the poison just in time and father and son were united. Medea fled Athens never to return. Theseus then went to Crete to lift the tributes that Athens had to pay. This was due to Aegeus sending Minos' (King of Crete) son Androgeus to kill the Marathonian Bull and getting killed. Minos threatened to raze Athens to the ground unless a tribute of seven maidens and seven youths were sent from Athens every year to feed the minotaur Asterion. Theseus sent himself as one of the sacrifical lambs where he fell in love with Minos' daughter, Ariadne. She gave him a ball of cotton which he used to find his way through the labyrinth to kill Asterion. He fled Crete with Ariadne to the island of Naxos. It was here that Theseus had a dream in which Dionysus warned him to leave Ariadne on the island as she was betrothed to him. He took the tough decision to leave her to save the Athenians he'd managed to save from being sacrificed to Asterion. He later took Antiope, an Amazon warrior as his queen kickstarting the Attic War, or Amazonomachy. They managed to defeat the Amazons but Antiope was killed in the process. He then had a sort of mid-life crisis, getting into all sorts of scrapes with his best friend Pirithous. They had the terrible idea one day of trying to kidnap Persephone, Queen of the underworld to be Pirithous' wife. Hades had them cast into stone chairs, their buttocks stuck to the seats. Heracles managed to free them during his twelfth labour to retrieve Cerberus. He married Phaedra, the younger sister of Ariadne. When visiting his son Hippolytus, Phaedra, Hippolytus' step-mother, was struck by a curse sent from Aphrodite in revenge for Hippolytus' neglect in all matters of love. Phaedra declared her love to Hippolytus but it wasn't reciprocated. Phaedra cried rape to Theseus who prayed to his father Poseidon for justice. Hippolytus was trampled to death in a chariot "accident". Upon hearing this Phaedra killed herself. Theseus was exiled from Athens for this unwitting role in the deaths of his son and wife. The end of his life was marked by shame and bitterness. He ended up as the guest of King Lycomedes of Skyros where one day he fell to his death over a cliff, pushed by Lycomedes but the reason is lost to us. His legacy wasn't tarnished however, Theseus goes down as one of the great heroes of Greek myth, and the greatest in all of Athens. His statue stands proudly in the centre of Athens today in Syntagma Square.

source.name: Icarus
source.notes: Son of Daedalus. He was imprisoned along with his father when Theseus killed the minotaur Asterion. Minos believed it must have been Daedalus that betrayed him. Being the inventor of the labyrinth that housed Asterion, only Daedalus could have helped Theseus through it. Whilst imprisoned in the tower at the top of the palace, Daedalus made wings from feathers and candle wax for them both to escape. Icarus though flew too high up and the wax melted his wings. He crashed into the sea and died. His body washed up on an island that is named after him today, Icaria.

target.name: Daedalus
target.notes: The most gifted architect, inventor, designer in all of ancient Greece. Born in Athens but was expelled when he threw his nephew and apprentice Perdix off the Acropolis in a jealous rage as Perdix had become even more gifted than Daedalus himself. He went to Crete where he would work for King Minos.  He designed the labyrinth that imprisoned the minotaur Asterion for King Minos of Crete. When Theseus killed Asterion Minos blamed Daedalus. Only the inventor of the labyrinth could have helped him on his way through. He imprisoned Daedalus and his son, Icarus, at the top of the palace tower. Daedalus made wings from feathers and candle wax for them both to escape. Icarus flew too high and his wings melted. He crashed into the sea and died. Daedalus eventually ended up working for King Cocalus in Sicily. One day he was presented with a puzzle, passing a thread through a shell's complex helical chambers. Daedalus did this with ease and showed the man how he did it. The man was pleased, only Daedalus the inventor could have solved this puzzle. The man was Minos. He had finally tracked Daedalus down and wanted revenge. Cocalus reluctantly agreed to hand him over the next day but whilst Minos was bathing in the palace, Cocalus' daughters, so very fond of Daedalus, heated the water to boiling point and scalded Minos to death.

source.name: Cocalus
source.notes: King of Camicus in southern Sicily. Daedalus the inventor worked for him after he escaped from Crete. Minos, King of Crete tracked him down eventually and demanded he be returned to him. Cocalus' daughters scalded Minos to death in the bath to prevent him from doing so.

target.name: Minos II
target.notes: King of Crete. He demanded a yearly tribute from Athens for the death of his son, Androgeus, who died trying to subdue the Marathonian Bull on the King of Athens' orders (King Aegeus). Theseus, Aegeus' son, went to Crete as part of the tribute and killed Asterion the minotaur, the one for whom the tribute was for. Minos blamed Daedalus, the inventor of the labyrinth which imprisoned Asterion. Daedalus escaped but Minos eventually tracked him down to Sicily where he demanded King Cocalus hand him over. Cocalus' daughters, very fond of Daedalus, scalded him to death in the bath before he had chance to take him.

He had finally tracked Daedalus down and wanted revenge. Cocalus reluctantly agreed to hand him over the next day but whilst Minos was bathing in the palace, Cocalus' daughters, so very fond of Daedalus, heated the water to boiling point and scalded Minos to death.

source.name: Eurytion
source.notes: One of the centaurs, he tried to rape Hippodamia at her own wedding to Pirithous. Centaurs, unaccustomed to wine, had caused abominable scenes at the wedding, which Pirithous had only invited them to for political expediency. Pirithous and his best friend, the hero Theseus, fought back and the centaurs galloped away.

target.name: Nephele
target.notes: Zeus, angered by Ixion who tried to seduce Hera, sent Nephele to Ixion with the appearance of Hera as a trap. He coupled with her incurring Zeus's wrath in the process who bound him to a burning wheel in the depths of Tartarus for eternity. The result of this coupling was a son, Centauros.

source.name: Eurytion
source.notes: One of the centaurs, he tried to rape Hippodamia at her own wedding to Pirithous. Centaurs, unaccustomed to wine, had caused abominable scenes at the wedding, which Pirithous had only invited them to for political expediency. Pirithous and his best friend, the hero Theseus, fought back and the centaurs galloped away.

target.name: Ixion
target.notes: Ixion, already angering the gods to breaking point by refusing one of their most strongly held beliefs, the spirit of hospitality, or xenia, and by killing his father-in-law, Deioneus, King of Phocis and committing the first blood murder, would go on to anger them even further. Invited to a banquet by Zeus he tried it on with his wife, Hera. An angry Zeus then tested him the day after by animating a cloud shaped Hera look-a-like and presenting it to Ixion. He duly impregnated her. This was the final straw and Zeus bound him to a wheel of fire and sent him down to the depths of Tartarus where he revolves, spread-eagled and roasting in agony to this day. "Thou art a soul in bliss,but I am bound Upon a wheel of fire, that mine own tears Do scald like molten lead." King Lear.

source.notes: One of the centaurs, he tried to rape Hippodamia at her own wedding to Pirithous. Centaurs, unaccustomed to wine, had caused abominable scenes at the wedding, which Pirithous had only invited them to for political expediency. Pirithous and his best friend, the hero Theseus, fought back and the centaurs galloped away.

target.name: Hippodamia
target.notes: nan

target.name: Pirithous
target.notes: King of the Lapiths and one of Jason's Argonauts. He heard of the exploits of Theseus and wanted to test them out. He raided his cattle and Theseus tracked him down, but instead of fighting it out they quickly realised they very much liked each other and so began one of the great friendships in Greek mythology. They had the crazy idea of kidnapping Persephone, Queen of the Underworld to be his wife. Hades had them cast into stone chairs, their buttocks glued to the seats. It wasn't until Heracles descended into the underworld during his twelfth labour to retrieve Cerberus, that they managed to be freed.

source.name: Caeneus
source.notes: Born a woman, Caenis, she was taken by Poseidon who offered her one wish. Taking no pleasure in being violated, she asked to be turned into a man to prevent it from ever happening again. Caeneus was present at the wedding of Pirithous and Hippodamia and fought the centaurs alongside Pirithous and Theseus where he was sadly killed.

target.name: Poseidon
target.god_of: God of Seas, Earthquakes, Floods, Droughts & Horses
target.notes: Swallowed by Kronos when born due to Ouranos' curse on him that "Your own children will overthrow you as you overthrew me". Giften the weapon of a Trident by the Cyclopes.
