target.name: Pirithous
target.notes: King of the Lapiths and one of Jason's Argonauts. He heard of the exploits of Theseus and wanted to test them out. He raided his cattle and Theseus tracked him down, but instead of fighting it out they quickly realised they very much liked each other and so began one of the great friendships in Greek mythology. They had the crazy idea of kidnapping Persephone, Queen of the Underworld to be his wife. Hades had them cast into stone chairs, their buttocks glued to the seats. It wasn't until Heracles descended into the underworld during his twelfth labour to retrieve Cerberus, that they managed to be freed.

source.name: Latreus
source.notes: A centaur who was present at the wedding of Hippodamia and Pirithous. He killed Canenus who was fighting on the side of Pirithous and Theseus, mocking him for once having been a woman.

target.name: Theseus
target.notes: Theseus discovered his father was Aegeus, King of Athens. He wanted to enter Athens a hero to finally meet his father, so he set out along the dangerous coastal route from Troezen. During his travels he cleared the route of all evil, slaying monsters and murderes alike to enter Athens held aloft by an adoring public grateful to have the road made safe once more. Aegeus' wife, Jason's widow, Medea, was adamant that her own son, Medus, and not Theseus would be the heir to throne of Athens so she persuaded Aegeus, who didn't know it was his long lost son at this point, to order him to kill the Marathonian Bull. Theseus accomplished this heroic feat, inventing ancient bull fighting in the process. Medea then contrived to have him poisoned. Aegeus agreed, believing Theseus' fame was a threat to his rule. Just as Theseus was about to drink the poison, Aegeus noticed his sword. It was the exact same sword that he'd buried back in Troezen for his son to find one day. He managed to stop him drinking the poison just in time and father and son were united. Medea fled Athens never to return. Theseus then went to Crete to lift the tributes that Athens had to pay. This was due to Aegeus sending Minos' (King of Crete) son Androgeus to kill the Marathonian Bull and getting killed. Minos threatened to raze Athens to the ground unless a tribute of seven maidens and seven youths were sent from Athens every year to feed the minotaur Asterion. Theseus sent himself as one of the sacrifical lambs where he fell in love with Minos' daughter, Ariadne. She gave him a ball of cotton which he used to find his way through the labyrinth to kill Asterion. He fled Crete with Ariadne to the island of Naxos. It was here that Theseus had a dream in which Dionysus warned him to leave Ariadne on the island as she was betrothed to him. He took the tough decision to leave her to save the Athenians he'd managed to save from being sacrificed to Asterion. He later took Antiope, an Amazon warrior as his queen kickstarting the Attic War, or Amazonomachy. They managed to defeat the Amazons but Antiope was killed in the process. He then had a sort of mid-life crisis, getting into all sorts of scrapes with his best friend Pirithous. They had the terrible idea one day of trying to kidnap Persephone, Queen of the underworld to be Pirithous' wife. Hades had them cast into stone chairs, their buttocks stuck to the seats. Heracles managed to free them during his twelfth labour to retrieve Cerberus. He married Phaedra, the younger sister of Ariadne. When visiting his son Hippolytus, Phaedra, Hippolytus' step-mother, was struck by a curse sent from Aphrodite in revenge for Hippolytus' neglect in all matters of love. Phaedra declared her love to Hippolytus but it wasn't reciprocated. Phaedra cried rape to Theseus who prayed to his father Poseidon for justice. Hippolytus was trampled to death in a chariot "accident". Upon hearing this Phaedra killed herself. Theseus was exiled from Athens for this unwitting role in the deaths of his son and wife. The end of his life was marked by shame and bitterness. He ended up as the guest of King Lycomedes of Skyros where one day he fell to his death over a cliff, pushed by Lycomedes but the reason is lost to us. His legacy wasn't tarnished however, Theseus goes down as one of the great heroes of Greek myth, and the greatest in all of Athens. His statue stands proudly in the centre of Athens today in Syntagma Square.

source.name: Latreus
source.notes: A centaur who was present at the wedding of Hippodamia and Pirithous. He killed Canenus who was fighting on the side of Pirithous and Theseus, mocking him for once having been a woman.

target.name: Caeneus
target.notes: Born a woman, Caenis, she was taken by Poseidon who offered her one wish. Taking no pleasure in being violated, she asked to be turned into a man to prevent it from ever happening again. Caeneus was present at the wedding of Pirithous and Hippodamia and fought the centaurs alongside Pirithous and Theseus where he was sadly killed.

source.name: Antiope
source.notes: Amazon warrior and wife of the hero Theseus. The Amazons didn't take kindly to one of their own being taken as a wife, being a fierce female band of warriors. Thus started the Amazonomachy, the war against the Amazons and Athens, also known as the Attic War. The Amazons were finally defeated at the battle on the Areopagus, the meeting place of the Athenian Council of Elders, also known as the Hill of Mars. Antiope was killed in the battle.

target.name: Hippolyta
target.notes: Queen of the Amazons, a fierce band of strong, independent female warriors, the daughters of Ares, the god of war, and Harmonia. They were the first warriors to ride on horseback and when they conquered a territory they would choose the best men for mating and kill them, raising only girls to join their group. Heracles was ordered to steal her jewelled girdle as one of his labours. When Heracles reached the Amazons news of his labours had spread far and wide and he was welcomed as a hero and equal. Hippolyta gifted her girdle to Heracles as a gesture of goodwill. Hera, incensed at the ease of how he achieved this labour, snuck amongst the Amazons and tricked them into attacking Heracles. Heracles killed Hippolyta thinking it was a trap sprung by her.

source.name: Molpadia
source.notes: Amazon warrior who fought in the Amazonomachy, the Attic War against Athens kickstarted when Antiope, an Amazon warrior, was taken by Theseus to be his bride. In the final battle on the Areopagus, Antiope was badly wounded, Molpadia put her out of her agony with a swift arrow through the neck. Theseus, seeing this, killed Molpadia.

target.name: Aphrodite
target.god_of: God of Love, Beauty, Pleasure & Procreation
target.notes: Child of Ouranos' genitals as they "impregnated" the sea when discarded by Kronos. Hence the image of Aphrodite emerging from the sea on a scallop (Botticelli). Kept safe by Zeus in the Titan War.

source.name: Hippolytus
source.notes: Son of Theseus and the Amazon warrior Antiope. He devoted himself to hunting and became a disciple of Artemis. He turned his back on love which ignited the ire of Aphrodite. When his father and step-mother, Phaedra, visited, Aphrodite had Phaedra declare her love for Hippolytus. He rejected her advances and she cried rape to Theseus. Theseus prayed to his father Poseidon for justice who had him trampled to death by his chariot. Upon hearing this Phaedra took her own life.

target.name: Artemis
target.god_of: God of Hunting, wild animals, children, & childbirth
target.notes: Goddess of chastity and hunting.

source.name: Hippolytus
source.notes: Son of Theseus and the Amazon warrior Antiope. He devoted himself to hunting and became a disciple of Artemis. He turned his back on love which ignited the ire of Aphrodite. When his father and step-mother, Phaedra, visited, Aphrodite had Phaedra declare her love for Hippolytus. He rejected her advances and she cried rape to Theseus. Theseus prayed to his father Poseidon for justice who had him trampled to death by his chariot. Upon hearing this Phaedra took her own life.

target.name: Phaedra
target.notes: Wife of Theseus and younger sister of Ariadne, Theseus' first love. She was struck by Aphrodite's curse when visiting her step-son Hippolytus. This was in revenge for Hippolytus' dereliction of duty in praying to the goddess. The curse made her declare her love for Hippolytus, who rejected her advances. She cried rape to Theseus who prayed to his father, Poseidon, for justice. Hipolytus was trampled to death in a chariot "accident". Upon hearing this Phaedra took her own life.

source.name: Phaedra
source.notes: Wife of Theseus and younger sister of Ariadne, Theseus' first love. She was struck by Aphrodite's curse when visiting her step-son Hippolytus. target.name: Minos II
target.notes: King of Crete. He demanded a yearly tribute from Athens for the death of his son, Androgeus, who died trying to subdue the Marathonian Bull on the King of Athens' orders (King Aegeus). Theseus, Aegeus' son, went to Crete as part of the tribute and killed Asterion the minotaur, the one for whom the tribute was for. Minos blamed Daedalus, the inventor of the labyrinth which imprisoned Asterion. Daedalus escaped but Minos eventually tracked him down to Sicily where he demanded King Cocalus hand him over. Cocalus' daughters, very fond of Daedalus, scalded him to death in the bath before he had chance to take him.

source.notes: Wife of Theseus and younger sister of Ariadne, Theseus' first love. She was struck by Aphrodite's curse when visiting her step-son Hippolytus. target.name: Pasiphae
target.notes: Queen of Crete, she mated with the Cretan Bull and bore the minotaur Asterion.

This was due to Aegeus sending Minos' (King of Crete) son Androgeus to kill the Marathonian Bull and getting killed. Minos threatened to raze Athens to the ground unless a tribute of seven maidens and seven youths were sent from Athens every year to feed the minotaur Asterion. Theseus sent himself as one of the sacrifical lambs where he fell in love with Minos' daughter, Ariadne. She gave him a ball of cotton which he used to find his way through the labyrinth to kill Asterion. He fled Crete with Ariadne to the island of Naxos. It was here that Theseus had a dream in which Dionysus warned him to leave Ariadne on the island as she was betrothed to him. He took the tough decision to leave her to save the Athenians he'd managed to save from being sacrificed to Asterion. He later took Antiope, an Amazon warrior as his queen kickstarting the Attic War, or Amazonomachy. They managed to defeat the Amazons but Antiope was killed in the process. He then had a sort of mid-life crisis, getting into all sorts of scrapes with his best friend Pirithous. They had the terrible idea one day of trying to kidnap Persephone, Queen of the underworld to be Pirithous' wife. Hades had them cast into stone chairs, their buttocks stuck to the seats. Heracles managed to free them during his twelfth labour to retrieve Cerberus. He married Phaedra, the younger sister of Ariadne. When visiting his son Hippolytus, Phaedra, Hippolytus' step-mother, was struck by a curse sent from Aphrodite in revenge for Hippolytus' neglect in all matters of love. Phaedra declared her love to Hippolytus but it wasn't reciprocated. Phaedra cried rape to Theseus who prayed to his father Poseidon for justice. Hippolytus was trampled to death in a chariot "accident". Upon hearing this Phaedra killed herself. Theseus was exiled from Athens for this unwitting role in the deaths of his son and wife. The end of his life was marked by shame and bitterness. He ended up as the guest of King Lycomedes of Skyros where one day he fell to his death over a cliff, pushed by Lycomedes but the reason is lost to us. His legacy wasn't tarnished however, Theseus goes down as one of the great heroes of Greek myth, and the greatest in all of Athens. His statue stands proudly in the centre of Athens today in Syntagma Square.

source.name: Caucasian Eagle
source.notes: Sent by Zeus to tear out Prometheus' liver day after day for eternity. Slain by Heracles.

target.name: Typhon
target.notes: A monstrous storm giant who laid siege to the heavens in the clash of the Titans but was defeated by Zeus.

source.name: Caucasian Eagle
source.notes: Sent by Zeus to tear out Prometheus' liver day after day for eternity. Slain by Heracles.

target.name: Echidna
target.notes: A monstrous she-dragon with the head and breast of a woman and the tail of a serpent. She represents the corruptions of the earth, rot, slime, fetid water, illness and disease.

source.name: Caucasian Eagle
source.notes: Sent by Zeus to tear out Prometheus' liver day after day for eternity. Slain by Heracles.

target.name: Prometheus
target.notes: Sided with Zeus in the Titan War. Prometheus means prescience or forethought. He formed the first humans out of clay from Zeus' orders (Metis pulling the strings). Athena would then breathe life into them. Zeus commanded Prometheus to not help them, specifically from teaching them how to make fire, "with fire they could rise up and challenge us" said Zeus. Prometheus lived with the humans but became concerned as to their lack of zest, he decided they needed fire, but not just normal fire, divine fire, which would enflame their sense of imagination and daring. He stole divine fire from Hephaestus's forge on Mount Olympus and taught mankind how to make use of it. Zeus would take his revenge by binding him on the Caucasus Mountains to be pecked at by vultures every day for eternity. As he was immortal he would heal overnight only to be tortured again the next day. He proclaimed that his love for mankind and seeing them flourish thanks to him would be balm for any pain. He would eventually be freed by Heracles and would tell him of his destiny to help the Olympians against the giants. He returned to Zeus and won his forgiveness.

source.name: Caucasian Eagle
source.notes: Sent by Zeus to tear out Prometheus' liver day after day for eternity. Slain by Heracles.

target.name: Heracles
target.notes: Born Alcides, son of Zeus and Alcmene. Zeus had wanted a child in the blood line of Perseus as Hera had prophecised that a child of Perseus would save the Olympians. Hera was so incensed at yet another affair of Zeus that she swore eternal enmity against Alcides. Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

source.name: Seirenes
source.notes: Three monstrous sea-nymphs with bodies of birds and heads of women. They lured sailors to their deaths with bewitching songs. They were handmaidens to Persephone but when she was abducted by Hades, Demeter gave them the bodies of birds to go and find her. They gave up the search and settled on the island of Anthemoessa where they would sing their song of doom. Orpheus drowned out their music to give the Argo safe passage.

target.name: Melpomene
target.notes: The Muses were the gods of music, song and dance and the source of inspiration to poets. Each muse was assigned a specific artistic influence.

source.name: Seirenes
source.notes: Three monstrous sea-nymphs with bodies of birds and heads of women. They lured sailors to their deaths with bewitching songs. They were handmaidens to Persephone but when she was abducted by Hades, Demeter gave them the bodies of birds to go and find her. They gave up the search and settled on the island of Anthemoessa where they would sing their song of doom. Orpheus drowned out their music to give the Argo safe passage.

target.name: Achelous
target.notes: River god who tried to woo Deianira. Heracles had promised her brother Meleager that he would be the one to marry her so he wrestled him into submission breaking one of his horns in the process. To get it back, Achelous offered in exchange the fabled Horn of Plenty, or Cornucopia.

source.name: Seirenes
source.notes: Three monstrous sea-nymphs with bodies of birds and heads of women. They lured sailors to their deaths with bewitching songs. They were handmaidens to Persephone but when she was abducted by Hades, Demeter gave them the bodies of birds to go and find her. They gave up the search and settled on the island of Anthemoessa where they would sing their song of doom. Orpheus drowned out their music to give the Argo safe passage.

target.name: Persephone
target.god_of: Queen of the underworld, god of Spring
target.notes: Was kidnapped by Hades in a chariot. This led to a great famine as her mother Demeter neglected her harvest duties to search for her. Helios had witnessed Hades kidnapping her and told Zeus. He demanded the return of Persephone to end the famine. Hades reluctantly agreed but not before feeding her six pomegranate seeds which fated her to return to the underworld for six months of each year. From this we get the seasons, six months of spring and summer growth as Demeter is overjoyed at the return of her daughter, and six months of autumn and winter of Demeter's grieving as Persephone is returned back to the underworld.

source.name: Seirenes
source.notes: Three monstrous sea-nymphs with bodies of birds and heads of women. They lured sailors to their deaths with bewitching songs. They were handmaidens to Persephone but when she was abducted by Hades, Demeter gave them the bodies of birds to go and find her. They gave up the search and settled on the island of Anthemoessa where they would sing their song of doom. Orpheus drowned out their music to give the Argo safe passage.

target.name: Butes
target.notes: One of the Argonauts. He was a Sicilian King, recruited for his bee-keeping skills which helped the crew's rations taste better. He fell to the Sirens charm on the return voyage. The Sirens sang to entice sailors onto their rocky cliff home where they would feast on them. He was rescued from their grasp by Aphrodite who whisked him away to Marsala in his home kingdom of Sicily, a place now famous for its honey-sweet wine. They became lovers and they had a child, Eryx.

source.name: Deimos
source.notes: Son of Ares, the god of war. Along with his brother, Phobos, they accompanied their father into battle, driving his chariot and spreading fear in his wake.

target.name: Aphrodite
target.god_of: God of Love, Beauty, Pleasure & Procreation
target.notes: Child of Ouranos' genitals as they "impregnated" the sea when discarded by Kronos. Hence the image of Aphrodite emerging from the sea on a scallop (Botticelli). Kept safe by Zeus in the Titan War.

target.name: Melisseus
target.notes: Gifted honey to Zeus and Hera at their wedding. He was rewarded with a sting to defend herself when collecting it, but such a selfish and hubristic demand of the Gods was punished with death if used. Meliss is still the Greek word for honey. A specially blessed honey is given the name Ambrosia, meaning immortality. In fermented, drinkable form, it is called Nectar in honour of the flowers it comes from.

target.name: Apollo
target.god_of: God of Mathematics, reason, logic, poetry, medicine, knowledge, prophecy, archery & music
target.notes: He kills a Python sent by Hera to eat him and his sister. The Python came from the landing site of the magnetite stone that Kronos ate thinking it was the infant Zeus. As the Python was born of Gaia and under divine protection he had to be punished by Zeus. He was exiled for eight years to the snake's birthplace beneath Mount Parnassus to replace the snake as guardian of the Omphalos (the spiritual centre of Greece, whose name he would change to Delphi and establish an oracle where anyone could come to ask the god or his appointed priestess, known as a Sibyl or Pythia, questions about the future) and to atone for his crime. Here he would go on to organise The Pythian Games every four years. Apollo was gifted music by Hermes (a tortoise shell with cow guts as strings, the first lyre) as a show of repentence after he stole Apollo's cattle.

target.name: Alcyoneus
target.notes: Stole Helios' cattle which kickstarted the Gigantomachy - the war of the Giants. He scaled Olympus and tried to rape Hera but Heracles arrived just in time to stop him. He buried him under Vesuvius where he grumbles to this day.

source.name: Methone
source.notes: One of the nymph-daughters of one of the Gigantes, Alcyoneus. When Heracles killed Alcyoneus, they cast themselves into the sea in despair and were transformed into kingfishers by the goddess Amphitrite.

target.name: Amphitrite
target.notes: Queen of the sea alongside her husband Poseidon.
